Ottawa, April 10, 1931.

Reverend Sir:

The Department wishes to arrange for the shipment of the electric battery, which is now surplus at the Duck Lake Indian Residential School, to one of our institutions in British Columbia, where a battery is now urgently required. Will you please employ Mr. William Urton, of Duck Lake, to assist your engineer and to properly prepare and pack the battery for shipment. This preparation and packing should be done carefully, otherwise the railway will not accept storage batteries. I understand they have to be crated in a certain manner. This battery should be addressed, freight prepaid, to,

Rev. J. M. Patterson, O. M. I.,
Principal,
Kootenay Indian Residential School,
Cranbrook, B. C.

In due course, please forward a certified account, in duplicate, covering Mr. Urton's services, and you may forward a voucher, in duplicate, in favour of yourself, for the freight charges. The freight receipt, of course, should be attached.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. H. Delmas, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Duck Lake, Sask.
Ottawa, April 10, 1931.

Sir:

I have to inform you that the Department is writing to the Reverend Principal of the Duck Lake Indian Residential School, at Duck Lake, Sask., asking him to prepare, crate and ship to Rev. Father J. M. Patterson, O.M.I., Principal, Kootenay Indian Residential School, Cranbrook, B. C., a complete set of electric storage batteries. These will be used to supplement the ones at present in use at the Kootenay Indian Residential School. Please inform the Rev. Principal and, after the batteries have been received and installed at the school, let me have a report.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

F. S. Ryckman, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Cranbrook, B. C.

The Canadian Junior Drying Tumbler

Single Motor — Belted Motor Driven

Size and Style
The inside cylinder shall measure 30 inches in diameter by 42 inches in length, constructed of galvanized woven wire, and shall be of (Reversing or Non-reversing) type.

Frames
Shall be of heavy cast iron, bolted together and connected by heavy stiffening angles, and shall support housing, cylinder, fans, coils and driving mechanism. Two heavy iron uprights, bolted to frames at each end of machine, shall provide bearings for an overhead shaft and motor, and starting device shall be attached to same.

Housing
Shall be of No. 16-gauge sheet iron, riveted to iron frames and made tight to prevent the escape of heat and air. The door shall be constructed of No. 16 galvanized sheet iron, hung on heavy wrought-iron strap hinges and securely latched by malleable-iron clamps, making it close fitting and preventing the leakage of air and heat. Shall be provided with cleanout door at bottom between fans. Two upright castings shall be bolted to top of frames for tub door to rest against when open.

Cylinder
Shall be constructed of No. 21½-mesh, .110-inch diameter, galvanized wire, rolled after being woven, so that the intersections shall be interlocked. Shall be riveted tightly projecting clear of trunnions and reinforced by wide hoops. Shall be further strengthened by channels riveted to trunnions. Shall be constructed with 3 galvanized cast-iron ribs protruding inches into cylinder, securely riveted to the woven wire and bolted to the trunnions. Door of No. 16 galvanized sheet iron, perforated, hung on heavy hinges, and fitted with heavy latches.
The Canadian Junior Drying Tumbler—Continued

Single Motor — Belted Motor Driven

Coils
Shall be located within the housing at rear and consist of 202 lineal feet of one-inch iron pipe, connected at each end with right and left return bends.

Fans
Shall be equipped with 2 single fans of the multi-blade type, 7½ inches in diameter, mounted on fan shaft beneath cylinder, for circulating air through the coils and thence through the cylinder and out through an 8-inch duct, leading to rear of machine. Shall be fitted with screened air intakes.

Gearing
Gears shall be machine cut from solid blanks of sufficient width and diameter, and provided with suitable cast-iron gear guards. Shall be equipped with hand wheel gear lock for bringing cylinder door into position and locking same.

Driving Mechanism
Reversing type shall consist of one tight and two loose pulleys, each 10 inches in diameter, requiring 1-inch and 1½-inch belts, operating in conjunction with a worm and cam movement, producing a fixed number of reverse revolutions of the cylinder.

Non-reversing type shall consist of one tight and one loose pulley, taking a 1-inch belt to operate cylinder. Cylinder shall revolve in one direction only.

Driving mechanism shall be mounted on cast-iron adjustable swiveling arm, bolted to machine, and embody strength, simplicity and reliability. Shall be 3-inch diameter tight and loose pulleys on fan shaft, taking 1-inch belt to operate fans. Fan belt shall be equipped with foot-treadle shifter and shall be protected by sheet-metal guard.

An overhung shaft shall be supported by two cast-iron uprights bolted to the frames of the machine and shall be equipped with pulleys of proper size for belting to fans, motor and driving pulleys.

Electrical Equipment
Shall be furnished for the following power characteristics:

(a) — Direct Current
   110 volts.
   220 volts.

(b) — Alternating Current
   Single phase, 110 volts — 220 volts, 50 cycles — 60 cycles.
   Two phase, 110 volts — 220 volts, 50 cycles — 60 cycles.
   Three phase, 110 volts — 220 volts, 50 cycles — 60 cycles.

Motor
Shall be Canadian design, of ample capacity and proper speed to insure quiet running, guaranteed to meet operating characteristics of machine and shall be mounted on tumbler, driving same by belt to overhung shaft.

Both direct and alternating current motors shall be horizontal type and insulated to withstand heat and dampness incidental to laundry machinery.

Direct Current
Shall be furnished with grid covers, as protection to commutator and brush rigging.

Alternating Current
Shall be squirrel-cage, constant-speed type.

Starting Device
(a) — Direct Current
   Consist of enclosed, automatic starter with two-button, push-button station.

(b) — Starting Current
   Consist of enclosed magnetic switch with two-button, push-button station.

Wiring
Shall be run in conduit between motor and starting device. Proper terminals for line connection shall be at starting device.
The No. 1 Canadian Handy Flat Work Ironer

Motor Driven

Padded Roll and Chest

Shall be one padded roll, 43\(\frac{1}{2}\) inches in diameter, when padded, operating in a steam chest.

The ironing surface shall be not less than inches in width, and shall be concave in shape to conform to the padded roll, ground and polished; and shall be tested at 200 pounds hydrostatic pressure and designed for 100 pounds working steam pressure, fitted and mounted true, making a smooth surface over which the pieces to be ironed shall pass. The back of chest shall be covered with asbestos, protected by planished sheet steel to prevent loss of heat by radiation.

The heated surface shall be as follows:

Frames and Gears

The two end frames shall be cast iron, of neat and substantial design, with four supporting legs and equipped with bearing boxes; also devices for adjustment of pressure. Roll shall be provided with driving gear on one end. All gears shall be machine-cut from solid blanks and covered by solid paneled guards.

Pressure Device

Pressure shall be regulated by springs, encased in spring boxes working on the end of eccentric rods, with compensating attachment for light and medium pressure. The eccentric rods shall be controlled by large eccentric operated by hand wheel, for applying and releasing padded roll from contact with steam chest and admit the variation of the pressure suitable for the fabric being ironed. It shall be possible to remove the padded roll seven (7) inches from contact with steam chest, to allow for thorough cleaning of polished surface of chest.

Feed and Delivery

The construction of machine shall be such that the operator not only feeds the goods into the machine, but takes the goods off, thereby allowing the machine to be placed, if necessary, against the wall and save floor space.

Goods shall be fed in over the top of the roll and returned to the feeder at the bottom of same. Shall be provided with a wooden delivery box, mounted on brackets. This box shall be equipped with curved brass plate for conveying goods from steam chest.
The No. 1 Canadian Handy Flat Work Ironer — Continued

Motor Driven

Automatic Safety Guard
Shall be applied to the feeding side, constructed of nickel-plated tubing, and delicately swung the full width of machine, directly in front of and over the feeding point, and pivoted at each end by bracket. This guard shall be provided with a special mechanism, connected with the power in such a manner that the swinging of guard toward feeding point shall cause the entire machine to stop instantly.

Electrical Equipment

Motor
Shall be of Canadian design, of ample capacity and proper speed to insure quiet running, guaranteed to meet operating characteristics of machine. Shall be mounted on iron bracket integral with the machine, driving by belt. Both direct and alternating current motors shall be horizontal type and insulated to withstand heat incidental to laundry machinery. Belt and pulleys shall be completely covered by a metal guard.

Direct Current
Shall be protected on commutator end by grid covers.

Alternating Current
Shall be squirrel-cage, constant-speed type.

Controller — Direct Current
Shall consist of a manual speed controller in an approved enclosing case with line switch and fuses.

Alternating Current
Shall consist of approved enclosed line switch and fuses.

Wiring
Shall be furnished with all wiring run in conduit between motor and controller or switch, and suitable terminals shall be provided for line wires.

The Globe Wood Washer

36" and 40" Diameter — End Header

Single Geared

Size

The inner cylinder shall be inches diameter by inches in length, and shall have doors and partitions, and hinges, latches and hoops.

Cylinder

Shall have heads and staves of Crown Prime Long Leaf Yellow Pine, with ribs of hard Maple.

Staves cut from 1\(\frac{1}{2}\)-inch stock shall be nailed to heads cut from 2-inch stock.

There shall be three large lifting ribs, each cut from stock 2\(\frac{1}{2}\) inches by 4\(\frac{1}{4}\) inches; also a rib cut from 2\(\frac{1}{2}\) x 3-inch stock placed at front and back of door opening, rabbeted to receive door. Door shall be 15\(\frac{1}{2}\) inches wide. Door battens shall be cast brass.

Hinges are wide and heavy and well-ribbed and shall rest on cylinder hoops the full length of hinge. Latches shall have wide lips. Cylinder shall be banded with wide, heavy hoops fastened to the staves by brass screws.

Tub

Shall be constructed of Clear and Better Fir, with staves cut from 2-inch stock.

Staves shall be tongued and grooved and gained to fit over heads cut from 2-inch stock, to which they shall be nailed.

A galvanized-iron sliding door shall operate in grooves provided on adjustable encircling bands or hoops. Brass apron shall be fitted at bottom of door opening to protect staves.

A gauge glass shall be mounted on left tub head.

Iron Frames

Cast-iron frames of heavy design, rigidly bolted to the tub heads, shall support the weight of the inside cylinder and outside tub and the driving mechanism shall be bolted to these frames. Frames shall be bolted to the tub heads.

Inlet and Outlet

Located in the center bottom of the tub shall be a cast-iron flange tee, through which the steam and water shall enter and waste water be discharged. Steam shall enter washer through an annular over.

Steam passage cored in the tee without coming in direct contact with the wood or linen. Connected with the flange tee shall be an outlet pipe, on the end of which a 3-inch quick-opening valve of the hollow taper plug type shall be fitted.

Provision shall be made for 2-inch water and 1½-inch steam connections.

Trunnions and Bearings

Cast-iron trunnions shall be attached to cylinder heads by means of brass-covered bolts and inside of cylinder heads shall be fitted with two brass trunion rings. The journals of trunnions shall operate in solid bored bearings equipped with easily accessible lubricators. Journal bearings shall be supported by the cast-iron frames.

Gearing

Shall be machine cut from solid blanks and provided with solid paneled gear guards. The main gear shall be of the split-hub type, bolted and keyed to trunion shaft. A gear lock shall be provided for holding cylinder door in position while loading and unloading.

Automatic Reverse Mechanism

Shall consist of three 16-inch diameter pulleys and a worm and cam movement, producing a fixed number of reverse revolutions of the cylinder. Entire shifting mechanism shall be mounted on heavy cast-iron swiveling arm, adjustable to belt at various angles. Header shall be supported by bracket arm bolted to cast-iron frame and shall embody strength, simplicity and reliability, and be arranged for 1¾ and 2-inch belts.
The American Underdriven Solid Curb Extractor

Laundry Type — Angle Countershaft

Size
Inside basket shall be inches in diameter.

Basket
Shall be constructed with shell of Monel Metal (.078-inch) perforated with sufficient number of holes to permit free discharge of extracted water, and riveted to top and bottom of basket.
Top shall be of steel, reinforced by a steel ring spun in place, and heavily galvanized inside and out.
Bottom shall be of cast-iron, of double web construction, truly machined, upper surface covered with sheet copper, heavily tinned.
Shall be reinforced by steel bands shrunk to shell.
Shall be tested for running balance at rated speed.

Curb and Base
Curb shall be an extra-heavy, one-piece casting, equipped with drain openings in bottom, and fitted with a detachable cast-iron top ring.
Base shall be an extra-heavy, one-piece casting and shall support the curb, balancing and driving mechanism.
Curb and base shall be securely bolted together, becoming in effect one solid, rigid casting.

Safety Cover
Shall be equipped with hinged safety cover.

Safety Bumper and Spindle
Rubber safety ring shall be fitted on bottom of basket and so arranged that when basket is unevenly loaded the rubber safety ring shall engage with curb bottom, thus preventing basket from striking outer curb when finding its balance. Basket shall be supported on spindle-steel spindle.

Laundry Type — Angle Countershaft

equipped with driving pulley. Spindle shall be turned and ground to size and taper fit in basket bottom. Shall be secured by a brass lock nut. Lower end of spindle shall have a siphon arrangement, consisting of a hollow chamber, forming an oil reservoir, for circulation of oil around the spindle. (See sectional views below.)

Balancing Device

Base casting shall be equipped with detachable well casting, securely bolted to base, for receiving the balancing device. Within well casing shall be fitted a phosphor-bronze sleeve bearing for receiving spindle, provided with flange, above and below which shall be located rubber stuffing cushions, engaging a flange on well casting and held in place by a spanner nut threaded in well casting. Shall be provided with three hardened, double-convex, tool-steel buttons at bottom of bearing, on which spindle shall rotate. Removable flanges shall be fitted on top of bearing in such a manner as to feed oil to spindle and furnish a tight joint, to prevent oil from coming in contact with rubbers.

Brake

Extractor shall be fitted with a friction foot brake attached to base, working on spindle pulley. Shall be equipped with locking device, to prevent sudden shock and hold brake in position until basket stops revolving.

Countershaft and Idlers

Shall have countershaft bolted to curb and base, forming a self-contained part of the machine. Shall consist of cast-iron bracket supporting the shaft, with its tight and loose pulleys and friction driving pulley, and also guide or idler pulleys. One of the idler pulleys shall be equipped with an adjustable device for taking up slack in belt.

Dear Sir:

We take pleasure in advising you what our recommendation would be in connection with the Laundry at the St. Eugene Mission School.

We have in our tender figured on two machines which would be more in keeping with the capacity of the work they have to do than those which are in use at the present time.

The extractor, also is very old and we have given you a quotation on a new up-to-date model with self oiling device and all the improved features of this machine.

We would arrange to take these three pieces and make an allowance on same against the price of the new washroom equipment.

You will note from the sketch enclosed that we would plan on having the machines laid out somewhat differently to the present washroom, although using the existing motor, line shaft and belting to drive same.

We are also quoting you on a steam heated Drying Tumbler which would be much more adaptable to your purpose than the present rack type which is in use. You will note that this tumbler which we are quoting you on is equipped with its own motor and we would suggest placing it in the room next to the present washroom.

We have figured on steam heated Flatwork Ironer, having one roll 66" long 14" in diameter and operating in a concave steam heated chest. This machine will be driven by its own motor and can be placed either in the same room as the Drying Tumbler or in the one next to it.

We have also figured on the Boiler having 8 H.P., which we estimate would be sufficient to supply the steam required for our machines, dish washer and a coil for heating water in your storage tank.
F. PARKS & CO.

HARDWARE, MILL and MINING SUPPLIES, COAL,

You will note that the proposal is for delivering in the Laundry and setting in position, including our engineers expenses, ready for operation when steam and return, water and electricity are brought into the laundry room.

We hope that the enclosed proposal will meet with your approval and we will be very glad indeed to hear from you if we may fill your order.

We might say that on this job we will have our own engineer go to the Mission and put the machines in place and make the connections, as indicated above, to our equipment after same has been brought to the laundry rooms.

For your information we are enclosing a list of the Indian Schools which are using our equipment and we hope we will be successful in adding your name to the list.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir;

During the last year I have called the attention of the various Department Inspectors who visited the school to the condition of the school laundry, and pointed out the unsatisfactory conditions under which the girls are doing the laundry work as well as the state of the present equipment, and its inadequacy for doing the work.

I find that the gearing of the present washers is badly worn, and also of the extractor. There is no flatwork ironer provided, and all the ironing must be done by hand. The three stoves for heating the present laundry work are a fire hazard and also cannot be used to do satisfactory work. The flue drafts have never been successfully controlled so that the laundry is filled with smoke whenever the stoves are lighted, and this smoke spreads up to the upper floors causing considerable damage to the walls of the building.

As a number of our girls are under tubercular treatment only the stronger pupils can be given the laundry work, and it is imperative that the work be lightened for them as much as possible. At the present time about three days a week are used in completing the laundering. It is also necessary for sanitary reasons that the clothing be well washed—which at present is practically impossible.

Sir: Re - St.Eugene School (near Cranbrook)
Water Supply.

Following your instructions, investigations of a suitable supply for St.Eugene School were continued along the lines suggested in my report number 254, dated June 25, 1930.

SYNOPSIS OF PREVIOUS REPORT

St.Mary's river and St.Joseph's creek are the most readily available sources of supply. St.Joseph's creek, however, is very badly contaminated throughout the year.

The St.Mary's river water was found, after investigations extending over a year, to be contaminated for about one-half of the year, with the probability of an increase in the degree of pollution in the future. It was concluded that only in the event of failure to secure a suitable supply from underground sources should the St.Mary's be developed.

SUBSEQUENT DEVELOPMENTS

Since the submission of that report an underground supply has been located on the school property at an approximate distance of three-quarters of a mile from the school buildings. While it may have been possible to secure a similar supply in closer proximity to the school, the possibility of contamination through seepage from St.Joseph's creek had to be considered.

C.F.Webb, Esq.,
District Chief Engineer,
Dom. Water Power & Hydrometric Bureau,
759 Hastings Street, West,
Vancouver, B.C.
This prospective source of supply provides a flow of approximately 25 g.p.m., sufficient for all domestic requirements. Tests of the water bacteriologically and chemically found it suitable in all respects for domestic use.

The springs rise at a lower elevation than where the school is situated and although it is possible to provide a gravity flow to within three hundred feet of the school, pumping would be necessary to service the school.

FIRE PROTECTION

This source of supply can not readily be developed to provide for fire protection for the following reasons. The delivery from the springs is so small that storage to the extent of approximately 60,000 gallons would be necessary to provide for minimum requirements, which for such an institution should be a rate of flow of 500 gal. per minute for a period of 2 hours. Such a large amount of storage is not very desirable for domestic purposes, especially so as the average rate of use does not exceed 4000 gals. per day, and as all water in this area has a slight alkalinity, short storage periods are most desirable.

In view of the limited rate of flow of these springs investigations were extended to a consideration of procuring an additional supply for fire protection from either St. Joseph's creek by gravity, or from the St. Mary's river by an auxiliary pumping plant. The system to be adopted for this purpose will,
to a large extent, control the design of the system for supplying domestic requirements.

DEVELOPMENT FOR DOMESTIC WATER SUPPLY

Neglecting the problem of fire protection for the moment a suitable supply of water for domestic use may be developed by making use of the present plant at an estimated outlay of $5660.00.

In this development the water would be conveyed from the springs by pipe line to a storage reservoir of 5000 gals. capacity at point on the suction line of the present system from which it would be pumped as required. The cost of a new engine is included as the present one is worn out and is not of a type which may economically be rebuilt.

This system would work satisfactorily for some years, or until such time as the pneumatic tank or the suction line would have to be replaced. As these are buried at an average depth of 13 feet below ground surface, it is not possible to determine with any degree of accuracy their present condition. The least expenditure, however, would be incurred by adopting this system.

Estimate of cost of proposed development is attached marked Appendix I. Plan of development and profile of pipe line are included under Appendix II.

DEVELOPMENT OF GRAVITY SUPPLY FROM ST. JOSEPH'S CREEK FOR FIRE PROTECTION

The cost of developing a gravity supply from St. Joseph's Creek for fire protection in conjunction with the system for domestic supply from the springs has been estimated at $27,527.00.
The present equipment consisting of pneumatic tanks, compressor, etc., would be made use of for the purpose of supplying domestic needs, the same system being adopted as is at present in use. Suitable housing, however, would be provided for this equipment.

The system for fire protection would consist of a reservoir in the creek bed of approximately 100,000 gal. capacity, and a pipe line slightly over a mile in length with a head of 135 feet, which would deliver 500 g.p.m. continuously at a hydrant pressure of 45 lbs.

The reservoir is necessary, although the flow of the creek does not fall below 500 g.p.m., the rate required for fire protection, to avoid possibility of interference with other users during the irrigation season.

Two standard two-way outside hydrants are provided with suitable shelters, hose and equipment, and in addition one inside hydrant with hose and hose rack would be installed on each floor of the school building.

Included in this estimate is an amount of $1200.00 for development of power from the pipe line during the non-irrigation period. The purpose of the power installation is for pumping the domestic supply, and it would in addition provide for school lighting for the greater part of the year.

This power development could only be made possible by the adoption of the gravity system, as otherwise it would be uneconomical to install.
Plan and profiles of pipe lines as well as detailed estimate of cost are attached hereto, marked Appendix II.

There is, however an impediment to the immediate development of this project owing to the existence of a record for the development of power. While there are also prior rights for irrigation purposes, these are all held by the school or for the benefit of the school.

Negotiations have been instituted with the holder of this power record for the relinquishment to the school of prior rights to sufficient water to fill the requirements for fire protection. Should it not be possible to affect such an arrangement, the projected development would be undesirable.

DEVELOPMENT OF SUPPLY FROM ST.MARY'S RIVER FOR FIRE PROTECTION PURPOSES.

The cost of developing a system capable of providing for fire protection requirements from St.Mary's river together with the system for domestic use from the springs is estimated at $21,110.00.

This development would provide for the accumulation of 10,000 gals. of spring water at a low elevation to be pumped to a higher elevation for a gravity supply to the school. Storage at the reservoir would be about 15,000 gals., sufficient for daily requirements and a reserve available for emergency. To provide for fire protection an additional pump of 500 g.p.h. capacity would be installed with its intake in the St.Mary's river.
The present pump would be used for supplying domestic requirements. Duplicate pipe lines would be laid as far as the school to avoid the possibility of the domestic supply being contaminated by that from the St. Mary's river.

The pump house to shelter both sets of equipment would be located one-quarter mile from the school.

Plan, profile and estimate of cost are attached, marked Appendix III.

COMPARISON OF SYSTEMS

In submitting these two proposals for consideration an attempt was made to maintain as nearly as possible, the same standard for each service.

This has been maintained in the domestic supply but in the case of the supply for fire protection, the service would not be quite on the same basis of comparison. Whereas the gravity supply could be maintained indefinitely at full capacity, the pressure is limited to 45 lbs. at the hydrant. The service is, however, available instantly and would fill all requirements for fire protection, except possibly in the case of a high wind.

In the case of the pumping plant, it is of necessity located at a considerable distance from the school. To offset this, however, storage has been arranged to provide for the time lost in placing the fire pump in operation. The pumping plant would have an equal rate of flow to that of the gravity system but would deliver at 60 lbs. hydrant pressure when in operation.
It will be noted that without considering capital cost and depreciation that the gravity system would show a saving of about $400.00 per year to the institution over the pumping plant installation, due to its ability to take care of the pumping and electric light load for from 8 to 9 months in the year.

A comparative statement of carrying charges, depreciation and operating expenses is attached, marked Appendix IV.

CONCLUSIONS

For such an institution where adult assistance is limited, the absence of one individual required to operate a pump in the event of a fire would be a considerable handicap. In all, it is considered that the gravity system would prove the more suitable.

Your obedient servant,

W. G. Warren,
Assistant Hydraulic Engineer.

In further reference to your letter of November 7th last regarding proposed domestic water supply at the Kootenay Indian Residential School, near Cranbrook, B.C., I enclose herewith a copy received from Mr. Webb dealing with this project. It is to be noted that a small power development using a 3 kilowatt generator, is possible with the gravity supply, which may be operated when water is available during the non-irrigation period.

The development of the gravity supply for fire protection is contingent upon acquiring a satisfactory water right on St. Joseph's Creek for this purpose. A prior licence exists at the moment for power purposes on St. Joseph's Creek at the site of proposed dam but no development has been done. It is possible the power licensee may waive his power right at this point. Negotiations in regard to priority of water licence are proceeding.

Dear Sir:

Re: Water supply for Cranbrook School.

In connection with the report of the Dominion Water Power and Hydrometric Bureau in regard to the installation of a domestic water system as well as one for fire fighting purposes for the Cranbrook School, which report no doubt you have perused by this time, I beg to say that a few days ago I had a visit from Reverend Father Patterson, the Principal of the School, and allowed him to read the report which takes into consideration the following proposals:

1. Underground supply for domestic use only... $5,600.00

2. Domestic supply together with a gravity system from St. Joseph's Creek................. 27,527.00

3. Domestic supply together with a pumped supply from St. Mary's River for fire protection................................. 21,111.00

At the moment I was more favorably inclined to the third proposal, but in view of the fact that the Reverend Principal stated there was great need for other work being done on the school this year such as new fencing and painting, repairs to the barn and new laundry equipment which will run into a considerably large sum, I have now come to the opinion that for the time being the best thing to do would be to concentrate on obtaining a first-class domestic water supply at the estimated cost of $5,600.00 and while fire protection service is extremely important, in the interests of the health of the pupils, I realize it would be very difficult indeed for the Department to obtain sufficient money during the coming fiscal year to put in one of the more expensive water systems as well as giving attention to the needs of the exterior of the building and the laundry.

LAUNDRY:

Clothes to be washed are at present boiled in containers. This is more or less of a homemade system. There are fires under each container. The smoke from these fires is supposed to be carried into an old furnace system. This system is defective, and as a result smoke makes its way right through the school.

The equipment of the laundry is obsolete. The two washing machines, driven by electric power, are now worn out. The replacement of the gears, now worn out, is not warranted by the condition of the rest of the plant.

The extractor has been in use for a number of years, and is now worn out.

There is no ironer for flat work. The ironing work is far too heavy for the number of children available. A number of the children at this school are in a very delicate state, and are quite unfit for this sort of work. This puts too great a strain on the few available.

The drier in use is a hot air homemade appliance. It is quite impossible to dry clothes with it.

I wish to recommend that two washers, one extractor, one flat work ironer, one drying tumbler, and one vertical boiler for the necessary steam pressure be supplied to the school. A careful estimate has been prepared by F. Parks & Co of Cranbrook. This is now in the hands of the Indian Agent. This estimate calls for a total expenditure of $6107 with a $300 rebate on the present equipment, leaving a net cost estimated at $5807.

The laundry is in my opinion far too dark. Several new windows should be constructed.
Water Supply:

At present the domestic supply of water is obtained from a small spring, which is liable to contamination. The bugs carry the water in buckets from this spring about 400 yards to the school. This water is used for drinking. St. Mary's River supplies the remainder of the domestic water. This is obtained through a pumping plant. The engine which works the pump requires renewal. It is quite worn out. There have been two break-downs in the last month.

It is vital that a proper supply of domestic water be supplied. I went into the whole question with the Indian Agent, and have read the Report prepared by Mr Warren on this matter. I personally examined the new springs, which have been located above the school. These have been cleared out a little more since Mr Warren's visit. He I think estimated the flow as 25 gallons per minute. I think that now that the main spring has been cleared the flow is nearer 50 gallons per minute. The water simply boils up in the spring from the rock to a height of about 8 feet through fine sand. If this water were piped down to below the school on the St Mary's River side, it could be pumped to the school through the existing pipe line. This pipe line is buried to a depth of seven or eight feet and I do not know what condition it is in.

To protect the school from a serious fire, it would be necessary to have a supply of water from some other source, and this has been fully dealt with in Mr Warren's Report. If I may be permitted to do so, I should like to say that the less expensive scheme of pumping the water from the St Mary River appears to me to be the better of the two plans. Though the question of fire protection is of course important, it is vital that the school be supplied at the earliest moment with an adequate domestic supply.

LIGHT:

The electric light engine has been overhauled during the last year. It is a 15 H.P. Otto, and with the attached dynamo is now in good condition.

The light supplied to the school is poor. This is due to the fact that the batteries need to be renewed. They will not hold a charge. I wish to recommend that new batteries be supplied this summer. The old batteries are now in use for the past three years.

HEATING:

This is by a hot water system. The system is working well. The fire brick in the furnace needs to be renewed, as the bricks are quite burned out.

PAINTING:

The exterior woodwork of the school needs repainting. This of course would be a contract matter. If the funds now available for repairs at this school are low, I should think that the painting might be postponed for another year.

Dear Sir;

We recently made an inspection of the batteries just shipped to the Mission Industrial School and beg to report the following.

The batteries when shipped were improperly packed and the electrolyte has spilled over in every crate. It is a total loss and will have to be replaced.

The battery lugs were left projecting thru the top of crates and when the crates were stacked the jars in twenty six of the units were broken beyond repair.

In the broken jars the plates have already a coating of sulphate which will be difficult to remove.

We have not the prices immediately available to use in arriving at the cost of putting these batteries in shape. We sincerely believe that it would too expensive as the resulting batteries would be far from first class shape.

We also examined the bank of batteries now in use at the school, and find the following.

The electrolyte has a specific gravity of only 1050. It should be when charged 1280.

The plates are in very good condition although they have suffered a great deal of abuse.

The unit is not cleanly kept nor is it dry. This results in a leakage which accounts for the inability of the persons in charge to keep the batteries charged.

The electrolyte being so weak will not allow the batteries to attain their full voltage or amperage after being placed on charge. This means that the assembly is only working at about half capacity all the time and results in very unsatisfactory operation.

We respectfully advise that the electrolyte be changed in the batteries now in use and the same being brought up to full charge. This we feel confident would give the school a very fair set of batteries and would be better and cheaper than attempting to repair the damaged ones.

There is also some wiring to be replaced on the battery rack which is necessary to efficient operation of the plant.

We would be pleased to give you an estimate on this work and will give you it as soon as we receive prices on the required acid.

Sincerely,

I went over the school (St Eugene's Residential) and farm with the Agent and Principal. The bread baking oven needs renewing. It smokes badly, and is really worn out, being 18 years old. Memorandum to Mr. Webb:

Re: St. Mary's School, Mission,
Water Supply.

An inspection was made of the reservoir of the above mentioned water system on the 24th of May. I found that repairs had been effected to the leak in the reservoir by the school authorities but that a leak was occurring through the creek bank above the reservoir which would not allow it to fill completely.

As I was unable to see the Principal of the school at the time of my visit, I interviewed Mr. M. Purcell who has charge of the system and under whose supervision repairs to the reservoir were carried out. He stated that the probable cause of the leak was the presence of poor ground at a point about two feet up from the bed of the reservoir and in close proximity to a large tree. This poor material as well as the tree root was removed and the locality refilled with good material and tamped down. Mr. Purcell informed me of another leak above the reservoir of which he stated he was aware and also that he expected to repair the leak shortly.

So long as there is sufficient water for the use of the school services no damage is likely to occur as a result of such leaks. The volume of water stored is not large and there is sufficient drainage to take care of such occurrences. The material in which the reservoir was excavated has held water successfully for over twenty years with very small loss, if any. It has been owing to the enlargement of the original pond and the breaking into new ground that resulted in uncovering the weak spots in the soil. Since these have been remedied as they have occurred, at very small cost, there is no reason to suppose that the reservoir will not hold water successfully.

[Signature]

W.C. Warren

Dear Sir:

Referring to your claim of 16th June, $689.00, account damage to shipment described as:

- 20 crates wet storage batteries (Second Hand)
- 1 box fittings

Made by Indian School, Duck Lake, Sask., 5th May, consigned to Rev. J. M. Patterson, Principal, Kootenay Indian Residential School, Cranbrook.

There is no question as to the existence and extent of damage, as this has been confirmed by inspection made initially by our Cranbrook Agent, Mr. Noir, but subsequently by joint inspection by Mr. Noir and myself on the 11th July, on which date you were away from home.

However, the position carriers must take is that the damage was not due to any act of commission or omission on their part.

My investigation reveals that the shipment was well braced in car at Duck Lake, and report of Salgar upon arrival, Calgary, indicates: "Jars well braced - good job done," that bracing was intact, but that all crates were more or less leaking. On account of this condition this Company at first refused to accept shipment, but upon representation of Principal of Indian School at Duck Lake and his written request of Agent at that point that shipment be permitted to go forward at owner's risk, prepaid, we eventually accepted it and carried it to destination. On arrival at Cranbrook my information is that the car was well sealed and well braced, the bracing being intact and in its original position.

As you know, the jars were not equipped with tops, with the result that the acid would spash out from the ordinary oscillation of car, and the loss of acid from the jars would more readily permit the plates to strike and break jars.

My information, obtained from shippers who have handled this same style of jar, is that they would not think of shipping the jars and plates together, that is, the plates enclosed in jars, as in this case, but would ship the jars separate from the plates.

For all the above reasons I do not believe it can be consistently maintained that the damage was due to any rough or improper handling on the part of carriers, in view of which I must respectfully decline your claim.

Yours truly,

"F. E. Clarke"

Freight Claim Agent.

Dear Sir:

I regret very much that there has been a delay in the installation of our domestic supply of water, and that, on account of the lateness of the season the work may be delayed till spring.

The installation of a suitable sanitary supply of water is an absolute necessity in this school as the spring from which we have been carrying water daily is used by a number of people and the number is increasing every year. After every shower of rain the water cannot be used and a supply must be secured from the springs three-quarters of a mile distant. It is difficult for me to ask the people to send their children to the school as long as this condition lasts.

I wish to point out too, that our pumping engine in present use is worn out, as was stated in Mr Webb's report, many small repairs had to be made to it last term and in all probability it will not last through the winter. If it breaks down through the winter a serious situation would arise, as our heating system as well as our water supply depends on the proper functioning of the water pumping engine. I would urge the Department to install a new engine without delay.

Trusting that you will bring this matter to the attention of the Department at your earliest convenience, I remain,

Yours faithfully,

Sir: St. Eugene (Kootenay) Residential School

As directed in your telegram of even date, I am enclosing for payment by the Indian Department, interim certificate No. 1 amounting to $1866.27, being payment on account of A.E. Jones contract for water supply system for above school, made up of contract $1475.55 and extras $410.72.

With reference to this extra $410.72 I am informed by our engineer in charge, under date of November 23rd that the concrete reservoir was poured on November 21st and unfortunately a sudden change in the weather took place, the temperature dropping to ten degrees below zero that night and sub-zero temperature continued until November 25th, which condition destroyed the concrete.

I quote hereunder from Mr. Archibald's letter of November 29th covering this work:

"On Saturday, Nov. 21st, concrete was poured for the reinforced reservoir. There was no apparent great change in weather conditions from the previous few days but during the night the temperature fell very suddenly to approximately ten degrees below zero, and sub-zero temperatures continued till Wednesday, Nov. 25th.

On that day I removed portions of the inner form of the reservoir and found that the frost had destroyed the set of the cement.

On Thursday I gave the contractor a work order to remove the frozen aggregate and as quickly as possible to prepare to reconstruct the reservoir. This work has been done and everything is in readiness for reconstruction when the weather permits.

Today is considerably milder than for the past week, and as there is a report of rain in Alberta I am in hope that there will be a definite break in weather conditions here very soon. Enquiries have shown that such a sudden and severe cold snap at this time of year is almost without precedent, but what has happened proves that it unsafe to initiate a project in this description, in this district, later than October 15th."

Enc.

J. T. Johnston, Esq., C.E.,
Director,
Dom. Water Power & Hydro. Bureau,
Department of the Interior,
OTTAWA.
Our latest information is that this reservoir has now been poured under more favourable weather conditions. I sincerely hope that the job will now be satisfactorily completed.

I would recommend, however, in future, that no concrete work be undertaken in the interior during the winter months as there is always the possibility of difficulty such as has arisen on this concrete job.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd) C. W. Webb,
District Chief Engineer.

Dear Sir;

Mr A.F. Jones asked me to write you regarding the new engine he has just installed at the mission school. I have examined the engine and must say it is a very rough job.

(1) The piston is a very poor fit for the cylinder with a clearance of .015 fifteen thousand undersize which causes a very pronounced piston slap:

(2) The cylinder is a very rough job in the bore far from having the proper finish.

(3) The cylinder head has a small blowhole from the outside to the water jacket causing a small water leak:

(4) The exhaust valve action is very noisy.

(5) The connecting rod large end bearing has a flaw in it.

Yours very truly,

Sir:

Acknowledgment is made of your letter of the 15th instant, with enclosed correspondence as stated, with reference to the new Gilson engine recently installed in the Kootenay Indian Residential School in connection with the new water supply system.

As I have already informed you this matter has been under consideration since the report was received of the unsatisfactory condition of the Gilson engine as installed.

In view of all the circumstances and following consultation with Mr. Indian Commissioner Ditchburn, I have decided not to accept the Gilson engine and have arranged with the B.C. Equipment Company, who supplied it, for its return. In its place the B.C. Equipment Company have kindly offered to furnish a latest type Petter Arnold Diesel 7 H.P. engine. This is a cold starting diesel engine of a new type which was not available when tenders were called for this project.

I have arranged with the B.C. Equipment Company that they will remove the Gilson engine and ship it back to the factory. They will then install the new Petters at a total cost installed, to us, of $750. This work will be carried out at once. The new engine will require a larger exhaust pipe than at present installed. The cost of this item will be in the neighborhood of $30.00.

I will therefore require a further $385. to cover the cost of the purchase and installation of the improved engine. You will of course appreciate that this engine is of a much higher grade than the Gilson engine which is being returned, and is of British manufacture.

I am enclosing a statement showing my account with reference to the installation of engine.

Dear Sir:

I wish to submit herewith a list of necessary improvements for our school property with a view to securing the aid of the Department. Many of these improvements can be carried out with school labor, thus it is not necessary for us to supply the labor cost but only the estimate of material required.

School Building

Laundry.

At the present time laundry work is done without adequate facilities. The present equipment is badly worn and entails much labor to handle the ordinary school washing. An estimate of proposed installations was given to the Department during the past year.

Fire protection.

It is recognized that the school now has satisfactory fire protection for the lives of the staff and children. Exits have been provided and sufficient chemicals to give protection, as well as careful patrolling. However the value of the property warrants a much greater system of fire protection. The present chemical system is entirely inadequate for the needs of the building.

Two alternate proposals for a suitable system have been outlined by the Waterpower and Hydrometric Branch and were submitted to the Department some time ago. One of these called for the securing of power rights on Joseph's Creek. Steps have recently been taken to secure all available power on this creek and we hope to have something definite on the subject during the year.

Painting.

The exterior of the main school building is badly in need of
paint. The approximate cost of doing this work is $375.00. There is considerable window and gable work and therefore it would not be advisable to have the work done by the school pupils. This estimate includes therefore, the cost of labor and materials.

Entrance Repairs.

Attention should be directed to the entrances to the basement and side doors on each end of the main building. The steps leading to the basement are constructed of cement and have no overhead protection from water or snow dropping or sliding from the roof. They are protected by guard rails only which are not sufficient, especially in the case of the younger children. Unless these entrances are watched continually while the children are in the recreation grounds there is danger of a serious accident as there is a drop over the guard rails of about ten feet to the cement steps below. The estimated cost of an iron bar guard of sufficient strength for the purpose is approximately $750.00 for both entrances installed. This includes a roof guard over the top to shed water and snow or ice.

In the winter both entrances to the basement in their present state cannot be used at all.

Painting, Interior

In order to keep the interior of the building clean and to prevent depreciation it is necessary to do some painting and varnishing every year. Practically all of the basement walls except the dining room need resalting and this would take a supply of salamone estimated to cost approximately $75.00, the work to be done by the school instructors and students.

School Desks.

The desks which are in present use in the junior room are of the double type and should be replaced by single desks for the more efficient handling of pupils. Approximately 40 desks are required.
School Estimates (3)

Farm buildings and grounds.

Barn.

Considerable alterations and repair work are necessary to the barn as well as painting both the interior and exterior. An estimate of these proposed improvements was forwarded to the Department last year. However if the materials only were supplied I think that this work could now be carried out under the direction of the instructors with the aid of the senior boys. Approximately $500.00 worth of materials would be needed for the work.

Poultry and piggery houses.

The present poultry house is large enough for only 50 birds. It is much desired to have a total of 200 birds for the use of the school. A much larger building would be necessary. We have no accommodation other than the barn for raising hogs, and housing hogs along with dairy stock is not a satisfactory proposition.

If sufficient lumber were supplied it would be possible to construct both of these buildings with the help of the school instructors. The estimated cost of the materials for both buildings would be $700.00

Fencing.

An estimate of $349.00 was submitted last year for fencing for hog pastures. In order to protect our farm crops it is necessary to provide suitable fencing.

To improve the appearance of the buildings, considerable fencing for the school grounds is necessary. It is estimated that the present fencing which has served its purpose and is badly dilapidated can be replaced at a cost of $700.00

In placing these estimates before you I realize that we can hardly hope to make all of these improvements this year. However I would suggest that all of these are necessary and should be carried out at the earliest opportunity.

Yours faithfully,

Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith a letter received from the Reverend J. M. Patterson, Principal of Kootenay Residential School, in connection with necessary improvements to the school, grounds and outbuildings.

I beg to respectfully recommend that in order to prevent deterioration, both the exterior and interior of the school should be painted. I beg to suggest that the painting and entrance repairs recommended are of first importance, and I trust that funds will be available to have this work done during the present fiscal year.

The fencing and repairs to the cow barn, piggery and poultry houses are also badly needed, and it will be of great assistance to the school if these repairs can be made. As pointed out by the Reverend Principal, the greater part of this work can be done by the instructors and the senior boys in the school.

The school laundry equipment is in very poor condition, but I feel that it is possible to get along as at present for another year and that other repairs are of more importance.

In the matter of providing adequate fire protection for the school, I regret that a certain amount of difficulty has been encountered in securing the power rights on Joseph creek, but when the necessary arrangements have been made I trust the Department will give this important matter their earnest consideration.

I beg to submit that after having examined the entrances to the basement and side doors at the school Messrs Sainsbury & Ryan, Contractors, stated they were very dangerous in their present condition and that the repairs should be made before next winter.

The above is respectfully submitted.

In the kitchen I noticed that the floor was very much worn. This is a very bad state of things in a school like this where there are several diseases prevalent, and everything must be kept in a perfectly sanitary condition. I would strongly recommend that a new floor of about 30 feet by 14 feet be laid down in the kitchen. The Department will best know the type of flooring which is giving the best results in the most modern schools.

The sinks in the kitchen are not in good condition, being much worn with the glaze off in many places. To save money, these might last for another year or two, but they should be replaced by modern sanitary sinks at the first opportunity. FOR HEALTH REASONS I wish to strongly recommend a cooks or kitchen table with a METAL TOP for this school. This table should be about 10 feet by 3 feet. My own opinion, which is not shared by the school authorities, is that a new table (Kitchen) with a sheet of galvanized metal neatly fixed to the top and bent over the edges to be nailed on the under-side of the table top, would cost less and be quite as sanitary as some expensive hospital pattern of table with an enamelled top.

Laundry:

This was reported on at length in my last report on this school. The girls spend three half days a week in the laundry. This laundry room is TOO DARK & NOT WELL VENTILATED, and I have no hesitation in saying that work in the laundry is very bad for children who are not strong, or with any signs of lung or eye trouble. In fact, it is very bad for anyone and urgently calls for change. A new small building will be required to take the following new laundry machinery, which most certainly is now required at this school:

2 washing machines; 1 extractor; 1 drier (steam) and 1 flat ironer. All the machinery here is now far too old and worn; but something would be allowed for it by a firm supplying new machines. The Indian Agent went into this matter with me with great care, and will forward estimates when necessary to the Department. I asked that the laundry be kept in a more tidy state than that in which I found it.

Sir:

I beg to report that a forest fire that started about three miles west of Cranbrook on July 22nd swept north towards Kootenay Indian Residential School and St Mary's Reserve, and on July 27th the school and outbuildings and the Indian dwellings and Church at St Eugene village were in great danger of being destroyed. Strong winds fanned the flames and sparks flew long distances, and for two days not very little hope was entertained of saving the buildings. Almost every able bodied Indian on St Mary's Reserve and the school staff worked day and night until the danger was over, and I am pleased to report that the only damage to property was the loss of the fence on one side of the farm owned by the Oblate Fathers and operated by the Reverend Principal of the school.

Two lengths of fire hose were borrowed from the City of Cranbrook, but although we telephoned as far as Fernie, B.C., no more hose could be procured. As sparks were falling constantly near the school cow barn and other outbuildings and the hose would not reach near enough to the danger spots, I took the liberty of purchasing 100 feet of hose from Messrs F. Parks & Co. and this, together with the borrowed hose, enabled the Indians standing by to keep a stream of water on the roofs of the buildings and to quench the sparks as they fell. We were also very short of fire fighting tools, and as the Forestry Department were using all their equipment at this and other fires in the district I also purchased six shovels, two mattocks and 1 pick for the use of the Indian fire fighters. The only other cost to the department was a small quantity of food supplied to six Indians who remained for two days and nights at some distance from their homes to prevent the fire jumping the St Mary's River and destroying the reserve timber. The account for food, amounting to $4.47, is included in the account for relief submitted by the Cranbrook Trading Company and forwarded on Voucher No. 1447 under separate cover. I beg to enclose the accounts submitted by Messrs F. Parks & Company, amounting to $34.00 and $12.89 herewith.

I trust the action taken in making these purchases will meet with the approval of the Department.

The above is respectfully submitted.

I have the honour to be

Dear Sir:

Re: Inspection of Boilers and Machinery,
Indian Residential School, Cranbrook, B.C.

On July 22nd and 23rd, 1933, I made a careful inspection of this school's machinery. This plant consists of:

Two return tubular boilers, 54" diameter and 10 ft. long, having 60 4" x 10' tubes, rated at 74 H.P. each. Longitudinal joint, double rivetted lap, built in 1913, making them now 20 years old. They are adapted to supply hot water heat to the school and numbered 1869 and 1870 B.C.

The lighting plant consists of one 7 H.P. Petter Gasoline engine, direct connected to a 4 K.W. 125 V., 55 Amp. D.C. Generator.

Power for the laundry is supplied by a 15 H.P. Otto Gasoline engine, direct connected to a 10 K.W. 125 V., 60 Amp. Canadian Westinghouse generator.

The water service is supplied by a 5" x 6" Gould Triplex Pump, operated by a Fairbanks-Morse Z Type Gasoline Engine of 7 H.P.

There is also a Fairbanks-Morse direct connected to Air Compressor No. 3.

BOILERS NO. 1869 & 1870 B.C.

I gave these boilers a hammer test and external and internal inspection and found that they were in good condition. Very little corrosion was showing and all joints, rivets, appeared quite tight.

The 6" return pipes from the system have been renewed and are now in first class condition.

There is a black deposit showing on internal parts of the boilers, but it does not appear to be doing any harm, but will need watching and again reported on next year.

The whole brickwork is in good condition and will need no repairs. Some of the firebars are starting to buckle, but as a whole are very fair.

All the auxiliary machinery is apparently in good condition, but next inspection these pistons should be drawn and inspected.
The laundry machinery is not in very good condition and should be attended to as soon as possible.

The whole of this plant is in a very fair condition with the exception of the laundry.

I have issued a Certificate for the boilers as in good condition.

Yours respectfully,

P.J. Arnall

Dear Sir:

Re: Inspection of Boilers and Machinery,
Indian Residential School, Granbrook, B.C.

BOILER No. 1869.

I beg to report that on July 17th I gave this boiler a careful internal and external inspection and hammer test and found it in very good condition. The black deposit on the tubes and boiler shell is very much more pronounced than last year, although there is no noticeable effect on the metallic surfaces. I have a sample of it with me which I will analyze and again report at a later date.

I have issued a certificate allowing a pressure of 15 lbs. and condition good.

BOILER No. 1870.

On the same date I gave this boiler a similar inspection and found it in very good condition as No. 1869. New relief valves should be installed on two branches of the mains. The positions I pointed out to the attendant also two new gauges are required.

The brickwork and firebars are in very fair condition and will need no repairs.

I have issued a certificate allowing a pressure of 15 lbs. and condition good.

AUXILIARY MACHINERY.

The auxiliary machinery is in a very good condition. The whole plant is very much improved over last year's inspection and I must compliment the attendant in charge for cooperation and the interest he takes in his duties.
In my last report I stated that the Laundry Machinery was not in the best of condition. It is much improved but a new high pressure steam boiler is very badly required as the means for drying the clothes is very meagre, and if a high pressure boiler is installed and a rotary steam dryer is installed a very considerable difference would be obtained. This is absolutely necessary, as all the clothes must be properly sterilized and with the present methods it is utterly impossible to do so.

I thought at one time that for the interests of economy that one of the high pressure boilers from one of the other schools could be installed, but upon further consideration I would recommend a boiler of a submerged tube type as the only fuel available is wood and the short length required for a vertical boiler would be quite expensive and uneconomical, whereas with a submerged type longer lengths could be used.

Yours respectfully,

T. J. Amall,
Engineer.

Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith voucher No. 2262 for $143.70, in favour of Messrs Sainsbury & Ryan, Cranbrook, for material and labour making repairs to the roof of the boiler and engine house, putting in an exhaust stack and connecting it with the engine and repairing ventilators, etc., at Kootenay Residential School.

I regret to report that after this work was started it was found that a galvanized iron pipe from the engine exhaust through the roof of the boiler room was not, as at first thought, heavy enough. It expanded with the heat, the joints opened, and in addition to filling the engine room with fumes set the roof on fire and burned out a piece about six feet in diameter before it was discovered. It was then decided that a much heavier pipe of rolled steel must be put in, and this, of course, brought the cost much higher than was anticipated. As the pipe weighed about 400 pounds it was necessary to put in supports in order to take the weight off the engine, which also added to the cost. However, the work has been well and thoroughly done and has resulted in eliminating danger of fire from the exhaust, and although the total cost is $43.70 more than the authority granted in Departmental letter of November 14, 1935, file No. 155-0-5, I trust that under the circumstances the Department will pass it for payment.

Respectfully submitted,

I have the honour to be,
Sir,

Dear Sir:

As requested by you we examined the generator and battery equipment at the KOOTENAY RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL. We also made an examination of the wiring throughout the building and beg to report as follows:

The present battery equipment has outlived its useful life. They are in such condition that the cost of repairing them would be far greater than the cost of a new and more efficient unit. They are of old style construction and even when in the best of condition they would not compare with the improved type now available. We strongly recommend the installation of the newer IRON OXIDE battery which carries a SEVEN YEAR GUARANTEE. This battery when properly installed and maintained gives exceptional trouble free service.

The generating equipment is in quite fair condition. It requires considerable cleaning and a few minor adjustments but is otherwise capable of giving excellent service. The switchboard and control panel has been tampered with to some extent and requires attention. Many of the connections are loose and improperly made. Some of the contacts are in poor shape and the complete switching arrangement needs a good going over. The transfer arrangement to the auxiliary generator is incorrect and requires a separate field rheostat and reverse current relay. The wiring from the switchboard to the batteries is badly corroded and very poorly insulated. It is in fact in a dangerous condition. The battery room is poorly ventilated and the gases arising from the cells while they are charging is highly explosive. Should a short circuit occur during the charging operation it might easily have disastrous results. This condition has been caused by the fact that the batteries now in use are the old open jar type and during charging electrolyte vapors are released into the air. As these vapors are highly corrosive they attack the terminal connections and wiring and deteriorate them very rapidly. This condition is not met with when the new closed in type battery is used.

The large OTTO gas engine used to drive the generator is in fair shape. The great drawback with this unit is its high cost of operation. When compared to the new diesel engines now available it becomes very expensive indeed. In fact the engine room layout could be altered with the installation of a diesel which would effect a dual saving well worth considering. We outline our suggestion below.

At the present time a seven horse power diesel is used to pump water and operate the small auxiliary generator. The large gas engine must be used to effectively charge the batteries. The combined operating cost of these two units are quite high. We would advise the installation of a sixteen or eighteen horse power diesel to be connected to the large generator. On this diesel there is a power take off which could be belted to the pump through a small line shaft. All pumping and generating could then be done from the one power source and at a cost of ONE THIRD LESS THAN THE COST OF OPERATING THE GENERATOR ALONE. The saving thus effected would soon pay for the cost of the unit. In addition it would leave the auxiliary equipment instantly available in case of emergency.

With regards to the wiring within the building we wish to mention that several switches and extensions have been added to the original installation in a manner contrary to the CANADIAN ELECTRICAL CODE. These additions have been wired in with cotton lamp cord which is nailed to the wooden casings. We would recommend that these be either removed or wired in properly as they present a real fire hazard.

Trusting this report supplies the information that you require we remain,

YOURS TRULY

[Signature]

Dear Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 16th instant No. 155-0-5 requesting a report for the urgency of supplying new batteries for the Kootenay Indian Residential School.

In reply I wish to advise you that the Rev. Principal and myself are agreed that the batteries should be purchased and installed without delay. The lighting system in its present condition is very poor, the battery cells and plates are badly corroded and in state of collapse. It is necessary to run the big engine for six hours in order to charge the present batteries, whereas with new batteries half an hour would be sufficient, this of course greatly increases the cost of running the plant.

I wish also to draw to your attention that when the plant is running at its best the lights are very dim and the strain is effecting the eyes of the pupils and staff, and being winter time the lights are in demand for approximately sixteen hours out of twenty four. I therefore beg to report the present lighting equipment would not be satisfactory for a further period and recommend that new batteries be installed as soon as possible.

Yours faithfully,

Robert Howe

EXTRACT from Inspector Barry's Report regarding his visit to the Kootenay Indian Residential School on October 22, 1936 - Original on File 155-0-6.

While inspecting the sewing room, the Sister in charge showed me that of the five Singer machines, three are very old and one quite useless. The Sisters were very anxious to have two new machines. I would recommend that one tailor machine and one ordinary Singer machine be supplied. The Sisters have a very heavy programme in front of them in bringing this school up to the standard of the other Residential Schools in British Columbia, from which it appears to have fallen away greatly since my last inspection.

Fire Protection:

The school has two fire escapes located one at each end of the building. Fire Drills are held regularly, but I would ask the Department to satisfy itself that instruction is given in the use of the FIRE ESCAPES FROM THE DORMITORIES. I held a Drill when the children were in school, but this was only possible from the various classrooms, as the children do not appear to have been instructed lately in making use of the escapes from the dormitories. Instruction should be given in this at a time other than that of inspection. The drill was well conducted and the school cleared in under one minute FROM THE CLASSROOMS.

I went over the whole school with the Principal. Toilets Wash Rooms, Kitchens and Boiler Room, etc., were perfectly clean. It appears to me that during the period following my inspection of last year, and previous to the new arrangement under which the Sisters of Charity from Halifax took charge, the school was allowed to fall below its previous high standard. The Sisters are working hard to have everything up to standard. The Kitchen is dark, the floor even more broken than last year, and the whole place full of flies. I asked that some effort be made to keep these flies out or to destroy them. Were screens to be put over the kitchen windows there would not be sufficient light. I would ask that some money be spent on the kitchen in renewing the floor tiles, replacement of old wash tubs for washing plates, etc. At present the kitchen does not appear to me to be in a sanitary

(over)
condition, though the Sisters tell me they are doing all in their power to keep it clean, and that the particular Sister in charge of this part of the school is heartbroken with conditions in the Basement Kitchen. I feel certain that the Department will do something about remedying the poor conditions complained of in this part of the school.

St Eugene Mission Indian Residential School.

At the date of my visit, the 21st of April, there were 89 children in the school. Only a few being still on the T.B. list and kept segregated. This is from the health point of view, a great improvement over a number of years ago, and the main credit for this must be given to the late principal and Dr. Green.

I found the fire fighting apparatus in good order, extinguishers filled, fire escapes easy of access. Fire axes need to be placed at partitions. The dormitories were clean and in good order, as were the class rooms.

The children had had for breakfast Cereal, bread, honey, coffee.
Dinner: Beef stew, spinach, potatoes.
Supper: Macaroni-cheese, bread and jam.
With milk three times a day.

Since my last visit, a number of Sisters had been placed in the school, and everything was much cleaner, and tidier than for many years. They have certainly pulled things together, though for various reasons, working under a great handicap, as will be shown later in this report. It is time, therefore, and only fair to them that these matters be given consideration.

Firstly: The floors throughout the dormitories are a disgrace, worn out through age, and impossible, with the best will in the world to keep clean and sanitary. The floor in the kitchen, laid in small ceramic tiles, is constantly coming to pieces. It should be relaid in cemented linoleum tile, or crushed or polished marble terrazine, I think it is called. In addition, this is a small and dark kitchen, with unsanitary walls. They should be white tiled anyway half way up for cleanliness and light. Sinks for washing up dishes, etc are totally inadequate. Two more sinks for this purpose should be placed in the dining room (no room elsewhere). This is important too, in that there are still some T.B. cases. A wheeled serving table should also be supplied as at other schools. The kitchen stove wants repairs. The hot water supply is quite inadequate, both for washing up and the laundry. A steam boiler for this purpose should be installed. Further, as regards the laundry, the clothes drying closet is out of order and not in use for want of steam to heat same. New steam pipes should be installed at the same time as the boiler. Further, there is no form of refrigeration in this school and in the summer, or winter for that matter, food is apt to go bad. An electric refrigerator should be installed. However, this is impossible, as the present electrical power is inadequate for the needs right now. The engine is old, worn out, and costly to run. I should suggest a 12 H.P. Deisel engine.
In fact the whole school wants repairs, replacements, and improvements if it is to be continued as a Residential school. A thorough survey by an architect or competent person should be undertaken. Personally, I think, four day schools would be more satisfactory, except perhaps for the prevalence of T.B. in this agency.

Lavatories on the Girls' side of the school were clean and well looked after. On the boys' side they were a disgrace. Excreta caked hard on many of the seats. I must say in most of the schools I find the boys' toilets more or less unsatisfactory. It would seem as though the class of men placed in charge were insufficiently trained in cleanliness, or careless in the matter.

Geo. S. Pragnell.
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

On January the 26 Captain Gerald Barry, of Vancouver, Inspector of Indian Day and Residential schools for the province of B.C., paid a one day visit to Cranbrook and inspected the Kootenay Indian Residential school. The Inspector's impressions regarding progress during the year made by the school in general, due to the constant efforts of a well trained and highly efficient teaching staff, will doubtless be noted in his report. Also improvements in the building, the new Monelmet sinks in the kitchen, repairs to tile floors, kitchen stove etc., the moving of a partition between the storeroom and kitchen burlap in the hall, painting and enamelling kitchen and storeroom. Dear Sir: Re: Engine at St. Eugene Indian Residential School, Cranbrook, B.C.

In answer to letter from Major D. M. Mackay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., dated February 8th, 1938, I beg to report as follows. On looking at my records of the above school, I find that the following machinery is in operation:

School Lighting Plant.

This plant consists of a 7 H.P. Fetter Horizontal Gasoline Engine directly connected to a 4 K.W. 125V. 32A.D.C. Generator. The current from this floats through the batteries.

Laundry

The Laundry Machinery is operated by a Motor and the power is supplied by a 15 H.P. Otto Gasoline Engine directly connected to a 10 K.W. 125V. 80A. D.C. Canadian Westinghouse Generator.

Water Service

The water service is supplied by a Gould 5" x 6" Triplex Pump, belt connected to a 7 H.P. Z type Canadian Fairbanks Morse Gasoline Engine, also a No. 3 Canadian Fairbanks Morse air compressor used to provide air pressure in the storage tank for the fresh water system.

From the above it is somewhat difficult to judge which engine is partly out of commission, and unless the Z type engine has a special fuel pump installed, the fuel feed is generally supplied by suction from a small tank. In either case the fuel pump plunge or piston is only from 3/8" to 1/2" in diameter and about 4" long. Possibly the difficulty in taking it out is caused by the piston being somewhat worn and having a ridge inside the gland.

I would ...
I would suggest that the Engineer take the whole Engine down and take off the fuel pump casting and take it to a Garage or Machine Shop and have it reground or renewed. In either case the cost should not exceed $10.00. While the engine is down the valves should be reground and the piston rings and other internal parts thoroughly cleaned out.

When I visit the school next summer I will make an inspection of this engine and report on same.

I remain,

Yours respectfully,

"T. J. Arnall."

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of April 28th, File No. 155-0-5 with reference to Laundry equipment, Tubular boiler and Refrigerator for the Kootenay Indian Residential School, I can only say that I regret the delay in supplying this information for you but enclose herewith a letter from Mr. H. S. Barnes, General Manager for Parks & Company, which explains itself.

Mr. Barnes visited the Kootenay Indian Residential School with me early in May and found, on investigation, that a suitable tubular boiler of sufficient size called for by the Reverend Michael Murphy, O.M.I., Principal of the School, would be wholly inadequate to do the work required and, if installed, would later have to be replaced by a more powerful steam boiler such as described in his letter of July 4th.

Mr. Barnes, therefore, decided to take no move in the matter before consulting a Mechanical Engineer with respect to the type of boiler required to supply sufficient steam for the Laundry equipment and domestic hot water for the School.

Mr. Stanley B. Jamieson, Mechanical Engineer of Metals Limited, Calgary, arrived in Cranbrook on Saturday, July 2nd, and in company with Mr. Barnes, Reverend Michael Murphy and myself made a thorough investigation of the heating requirements of the School and his report, which deals minutely and in much detail with the above, I herewith enclose.

I also enclose a catalogue showing the Kelvinator system of Refrigeration together with a letter of evaluation regarding details in connection with this system, also prices and cost of installation. With this information before us I feel that if it is not possible to meet the suggested expenditure this year it might be well to defer the purchase until 1930 rather than to install less expensive systems which would not give the same satisfactory results. A boiler for instance which, according to expert advice, would not be capable of supplying sufficient hot water to meet the requirements of the School.

Aside regretting the unavoidable delay in replying to your letter, I am,

Yours faithfully,
