Dear Major MacKay:

I am returning herewith a letter from Indian Agent Irwin, No.2-10 dated October 25th 1938 and a copy of a report made by Fire Chief Adams of Cranbrook which was forwarded to you by Mr. Irwin.

In accordance with your instructions the circumstances under which the Fire Chief made his investigation were inquired into, and the various recommendations made in his report of October 25th were checked with great care while I carried out my own inspection of the Kootenay Indian Residential School on November 9th and 10th. With Indian Agent Irwin I called on Mr. Adams at the Cranbrook Fire Hall, and there discussed his report with the Fire Chief.

The inspection made by Fire Chief Adams at the Kootenay Indian Residential School on October 14th last was made at the request of the Indian Agent and the Reverend Principal of the school, but as far as I could learn the Indian Agent asked Mr. Adams to visit the Residential School and report on what he found there with regard to fire hazards and equipment etc. This was in connection with Fire Prevention Week.

Mr. Adams is Fire Chief of Cranbrook, and as such an Assistant Fire Marshal for B.C. He admitted to me that he had no jurisdiction over Dominion Government Buildings even in Cranbrook. He had visited the Kootenay Indian School on former occasions. The Cranbrook Fire Department had responded to fire calls from the school on three occasions, the last time being over eight years ago as they have not been there since my appointment as Inspector of Indian Schools in February 1931. If asked to inspect a building he has jurisdiction, but not over Government Buildings. On this occasion he was requested to visit the school by the Indian Agent.

There is some plaster off a few walls and ceilings as stated by the Fire Chief. In my opinion this is not any worse here than in many other Indian schools in B.C. The Principal stated to me that he would make an effort to have necessary repairs made by the school staff and boys.

As mentioned in my report on the school it would be well to have the electric light wiring examined by experts and replaced when found in poor condition, the necessary insulation being supplied when missing. The wiring is not in good repair, but I did not see any great danger hazard.

The stove pipes in laundry and drying room are old and might well be replaced by rivetted lengths properly supported by wires. This would not cost much. In the Bakery I have recommended in my report that a piece of zincor tin plate be placed under the ovens so that the floor under the fire boxes and in front of the same be protected. The bricks suggested by the Fire Chief would be an added protection but are not in my opinion absolutely necessary.
I am in agreement with the statements of the Fire Chief with regard to the necessity for an adequate Fire Alarm System. I have recommended the provision of six 10 inch Fire Gongs. There should be two of these gongs on each floor including the basement, one being at each end of the school. Seven break-the-glass alarm boxes will be required one near each gong, and one in the main hall near the front door. There would also be of course a switch in the Principal's office for drill purposes. The whole of the wiring system in connection with the proposed new gongs needs replacement.

The question of PANIC BOLTS was discussed with the Fire Chief and I understand that these are being placed on all exits in public buildings in B.C. They cost from $10.00 up per door. I suggest that this question be looked into by the Department with a view of having these modern safety bolts on all doors opening to Fire Escapes in our Indian Residential Schools. If the Department agree with me that such bolts should take the place of all locks and other means of securing exits to Fire Escapes arrangements could no doubt be made through Indian Agents to have this work done in all our Indian Residential Schools and the same approved pattern of panic bolts used throughout our schools. Electric alarms could be attached when desired by school authorities.

The oil mentioned on the floor of the engine room was caused by the defect in the diesel engine previously reported by me and now rectified.

The openings in the ceiling of the Battery Room can be made by the Manual Training Class by boring a few holes. That is all that is necessary to take the gas if any away. It should be noted however that the gas chlorine is a heavy gas and holes should also be made in the lower part of the doors of the room. This is not important.

The gasolene pump should be in the open. The windows between the Garage and the Bakery should be filled in.

I do not agree with the Fire Chief in regard to the provision of standard or any other sort of stand pipes or the provision of any hose for the protection of the outbuildings. The Department is well aware that the system of DOMESTIC WATER SUPPLY recommended in one of my reports five or six years ago has been chosen as against a more expensive alternative system. The present domestic water system is giving excellent service. It is quite inadequate in the case of fire fighting for which it was never intended. Stand pipes and hose will only be required when the Department has funds enough to install a new fire fighting water system the plans of which are on file with the Department. I can not recommend that this be done at the present time.

In conclusion I may say that in much that the Fire Chief has reported there is an element of what I may call exaggeration. Conditions are not as poor as he makes out. Two items not mentioned by him are of much greater importance than many that are mentioned. I have mentioned them in my report on the school. They are the need for having the soda type extinguisher inspected and if necessary refilled each year and such work certified on tags attached to each extinguisher; and the very urgent need that the children be practised in fire drill down the escapes before winter weather makes this impossible. All snow should be kept off the escapes by cleaning these after each fall. The wisdom of having outside inspectors inspect our schools without Departmental authority is open to doubt.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Berry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.
Dear Sir:

I enclose a special report by School Inspector Barry upon the fire protection question at the Kootenay Indian Residential School. You will note this question arose through a report made by the District Fire Marshall, Mr. Adams, of Cranbrook.

In connection with this report I would like to recommend that the matter of the electric wiring throughout the school should be thoroughly examined and reported upon by experts so that whatever happens to be of doubtful safety can be rectified.

Secondly, the stove pipes in the laundry and drying-room should be immediately attended to, as they are a danger of fire.

The installation of a proper fire alarm system with gongs is necessary here. This should be along the line of the same installation as has been made in other schools.

The floor of the bakery should be attended to by having sheet iron put down on top of the wood floor,—an easy matter, though it is possible that a cement floor would be the safer and better in the long run.

With reference to the matter of panic bolts, this is a new question to ourselves, though apparently now being installed in other public buildings. The cost, too, is probably high, as it would mean installation in all other Residential Schools. Of course, as suggested, we might start with the Kootenay Residential School, but if they are of real necessity there, it would appear to me as though they were of possibly equal necessity in the other schools.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

I ......
I sometimes think that a set of fire protection regulations should be drawn up and issued to the Principal of every Residential School. By so doing, it would, I should think, obviate some protection measures not being missed out,—for instance, the locking of any fire escape doors or windows at any time unless the key were suspended handy in a glass case, the proper testing yearly of the fire extinguishers, and hose, etc. I mention this because on inspections it is so easy for some little point to be missed out, as it is also easy for the School Principal or Indian Agent to forget something; whereas if they have a properly drawn up set of rules, their administration would at least be uniform.

Yours faithfully,

G. S. Pragnell.

AGENT'S REPORT ON KOOTENAY AGENCY FOR NOVEMBER 1938.

Fire Protection.

Many of the recommendations submitted by Mr. Percy Adams, Chief of the Cranbrook Fire Department, concerning fire hazards at the Kootenay Indian Residential School have been adopted and endorsed by Captain Barry in his latest report. These improvements, in my opinion, are urgently needed in order to facilitate rapid and safe movement of the staff and children in the event of a fire. As stated in the Inspector's report, the present water supply would be quite inadequate to fight a fire which means that, in the event of so great a disaster under present conditions, it would be little short of a miracle if the buildings could be saved. In view of these facts protection of human lives, protection of the property investment would indicate the necessity of further efforts to secure a water supply adequate to reduce to a minimum, the ever present risk and danger of fire and the consequent loss in property, if not in human lives, that would be sure to follow.

Dear Sir:

We take pleasure in enclosing herewith our report and estimate on the cost of installing a FIRE ALARM SYSTEM and making repairs to existing wiring in the Kootenay Residential School.

We have made a very careful survey of the wiring system in this school. Accurate tests were made of all the circuit on each floor to determine the condition of the wires in the concealed raceways. Tests were also made on every circuit and feeder wire for shorts and grounds.

Certain hazardous conditions exist which have been largely caused by additions and extensions to the present system. These defective extensions consist for the most part of outlets wired in cotton lamp cord strictly against the code requirements. We have itemized these defective parts and quoted on the cost of placing all wiring in first class shape.

Perhaps the greatest cause for inefficiency of this system lies in the method of current distribution at the main panel or switchboard. At the time of installation the demands were fairly light and ample battery and generator capacities were available. The system was connected as a straight battery charging system and the bulk of the load was handled by batteries alone after the plant was shut down. Also the large gasoline driven generator could easily handle the battery charging load and the complete house load if necessity arose. To this end the batteries were connected for charging through a switching arrangement that allowed them to be charged in parallel. This means that the battery unit consisting of fifty-six cells of two volts each would be connected in two groups of twenty-eight cells for charging and would be charged back to one unit of fifty-six cells for discharging or operating the system. For stability a limiting resistor was introduced in the battery circuit for charging. If lights were required when the batteries were on charge they were obtained directly from the generator.

As noted above this was fairly satisfactory when the load was comparatively small. With the introduction a few months ago of electrical refrigeration and the normal increased use of appliances the overall load is considerably higher. To further aggravate the condition a diesel driven generator of only half the capacity of the original job is used to charge the batteries. With the hook up already described the charging load and house load far exceeds the capacity of the diesel generator and many times the equipment is working far below its normal voltage output.

We would strongly recommend that this entire set up be reconnected so that at peaks the batteries would aid the generator and at minimum demands sufficient current would be introduced into the batteries to keep them fully charged.

The manner in which a changeover is made from the gasoline generator to the diesel generator is very poor and does not comply with the electrical code in any respect. The wiring from the diesel generator to the switchboard is ensnared in ordinary water pipe and the wiring is dripping with fuel oil. No terminal fittings of any sort are provided. The generator itself is thoroughly soaked in fuel oil and badly needs cleaning.

Certain new wiring is badly needed and we have listed this separately. This consists of lights in the garage, toilet, and engine room etc.

We thank you for this opportunity of quoting and trust that the information supplied is that which you require. Please call upon us if any further data is required.

REPORT AND ESTIMATE ON WIRING AT KOOTENAY RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

THIRD FLOOR

Wiring from panel distributed in four circuits. Tests show no grounds and normal voltage drop. Three defective conditions were noted as follows:
(1) An underfloor outlet wired to bedroom with cotton lamp cord partly enclosed in water pipe. No boxes or fittings installed.
(2) A surface extension wired in cotton lamp cord stapled to ceiling.
(3) Two defective floor plugs and one socket.

Estimated cost of executing above work to code requirements-
Material $5.91 Labor $4.25 TOTAL $10.16

SECOND FLOOR

Wiring from panel distributed in eight circuits. Tests show no grounds normal voltage drop and good distribution. Hazardous conditions exist as follows:
(1) Outside light and switch wired in cotton lamp cord stapled direct to woodwork with no other insulation.
(2) Long length of cotton cord in bedroom stapled to woodwork.
(3) Outlet box covers missing and several untaped joints left exposed in ceiling boxes.
(4) Convenience outlet in surgery and offices all wired with lamp cord in dangerous condition.
(5) 6 volt bell system connected to 112 volt house current through a small resistor lamp. Very dangerous.
(6) Several cords used as switch legs and some defective and loose fixtures.

Estimated cost on eliminating above and bring same to code requirements-
Material $19.20 Labor $17.75 Total $36.95

First Floor

Wiring from panel in six circuits. No Grounds indicated. Normal voltage drop.

Hazardous conditions exist as follows:
(1) Broken receptacles in lavatory
(2) Conduit in laundry loose from ceiling. All drops equipped with brass sockets instead of porcelain. No wall switches provided.
(3) Poor wiring in kitchen controlled by obsolete open knife switch enclosed in rough wooden box. Very dangerous. No porcelain fittings on conduit from starter or motor.
(4) Defective fixtures in dining room.
(5) Separator motor in bad condition and wiring thereto improperly done.
(6) Several broken fittings require replacing

Estimated cost-
Material $27.26 Labor $20.50 TOTAL $47.76
Boiler Room

Entrance to this room from both in the building and outside is by steps down; this room is dark at all times and entrance must be made to this room in darkness. Switches controlling the lights from either entrances are code requirements and badly needed. Other wiring is in poor condition and requires repairs to bring up to standard.

Estimated cost for this work-

Material $17.50 Labor $8.50 Total $26.00

Engine Room

This requires a complete going over to obtain maximum efficiency. Switchboard wiring is badly mixed up and reverse current relay requires repairing to place it in operating condition. Wiring from diesel generator to the switchboard is extremely dangerous and should be replaced. The small generator requires dismantling and cleaning and adjusting.

Estimated cost of this work-

Material $25.84 Labor $24.00 Total $49.84

Barn

The barn requires replacing of several switches and fittings, also the renewing of the wire to the cellar. The main switch box is badly damaged and requires renewing.

Cost of this work to put barn wiring in good condition-

Material $12.20 Labor $5.60 Total $17.80

Dear Major MacKay:

I have read Departmental letter 155-0-5 of the 21st instant with reference to repairs at the Kootenay Indian Residential School as requested.

As the sum provided for repairs at this school is limited, I consider that it would be much better to have a new domestic hot water system this year.

The new electric wiring previously recommended including the provision of large fire gongs is badly needed, but I do not believe that the children would suffer much hardship by having this particular work delayed one year. The proper supply of hot water is a necessity in any large school, and I would recommend that it take precedence over the fire alarm system.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.
Dear Sir:

Re Your File 155-0-5.

I have to refer to Mr. Hoey's letter of February 21st regarding repairs and improvements to the Kootenay Indian Residential School.

As only $700.00 has been provided in the appropriation for the fiscal year 1939-40 for such undertakings at this school, I consider the installation of an adequate domestic hot water system more urgent and important than improvements to the fire alarm system. The existing fire alarm system should, with the exercise of reasonable care and precaution, be made do for another year. I would therefore recommend that a new domestic water supply system be provided from the $700.00 set aside for this school. A copy of Inspector Barry's letter on the subject is attached for your information.

Dear Sir:

Last Fall we submitted to you to be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs our estimates for the Kootenay Residential School for the year 1939-1940. Of the various items listed, one has already been granted, namely, the installation of domestic hot water; for which we are extremely grateful. At the present moment, work on this project is going forward.

Of the other items requested, we have heard nothing. We feel that all are necessary for the upkeep of the building. The revision of the electric wiring and the installation of the fire-alarm system cannot be left for another year. The floors of the dormitories are in a disgraceful conditions due to twenty eight years of hard usage, and are sadly in need of replacement. Perhaps the greatest need of all is the necessary material to fix up our two fine attics into suitable Preventoriums for the school children who are to be segregated. Since the latest examination by the T.B. travelling clinic, six additional children have been placed upon the segregation list. If we are to continue to fight T.B. among the children, we should be given the means to do so. Segregation is one of the main weapons and the two well-lighted attics, if properly built up, will supply two fine dormitories for the boys and girls on the segregation list.

We trust that the Department will grant us the necessary material very soon in order that we may have the opportunity of doing the necessary work on the dormitories and preventoriums during the Summer vacation in preparation for the return of the school children in September.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Principal.

Dear Sir:

Since I was named principal of the Kootenay Indian Residential School, I have found that the lighting system is very poor. A short time ago I had an expert make a complete check-up of all the electric devices and lights used at the school and connected to the plant, with the following findings.

Maximum light load possible Winter conditions: 12KW.
Maximum day load covering Laundry, Kelvinator: 7KW.
Potential Load maximum that could be imposed on the plant: 19KW.

To carry this load the school has a plant equipped with two generators if the following specifications:

(1) Crossman Generator:
Output ........... 4 KW.
Voltage .......... 125
Amperage ......... 32

This unit is equipped with a 7 HP Petter Diesel engine and is quite economical in operation but is heavily overloaded.

(2) Westinghouse Generator:
Output ........... 10 KW.
Voltage .......... 125
Amperage ......... 30

This unit is operated by a very old Fairbanks Morse 15 HP, single cylinder engine, in extremely poor shape and consequently wasteful in both lubricating oil and fuel (Gasoline), which renders it useless for economical generation of electrical energy.

The plant is also equipped with a set of storage batteries of 250 ampere hour rating. These are acid batteries, however, and are limited to a discharge of 10 amperes or a load of 1.12 K.W. which they will carry for a period of 25 hours.
Inspection shows that these batteries are in rather poor shape with considerable sediment collected in the bottoms of the jars and the plates badly warped from overload conditions. It is very doubtful if these batteries will last another season. From experience at the plant, it has been noticed that a sixty watt lamp operated from the batteries gives very little light and over a period of two hours reduces itself to a red glow, the only other device in use at the same time being the refrigeration plant.

Under present conditions at the school, the procedure is to use the 4 KW. motor generator set for all normal operations as it can be operated most economically. This is hardly a fair procedure as this machine is too small to meet with the requirements even with the help of the storage batteries. The result is that this unit and the batteries are heavily overloaded, especially during the Winter months.

Originally this plant consisted of the 10 KW. plant only and it is quite apparent that this was installed to take care of definite load conditions. These loads have been increased considerably in the past few years, but no arrangements have been made to take care of them; in fact, the capacity of the plant has been reduced to where a 4 KW. plant and battery set are expected to carry the load that was previously carried by a 10 KW. plant and the same set of batteries.

Suggestions for the improvement of the power plant.

That a new Diesel power unit be purchased of 15 to 20 HP., and installed to operate the two generators. This power plant could also be connected to a line shaft so that it could be used for pumping water also, thereby serving a dual purpose. The unit recommended is illustrated in cuts attached. Caterpillar Tractor. This power plant can be operated at approximately $0.15 per hour for fuel, and under existing load conditions should give service without more than minor adjustments for from five to seven years. The cost of this unit FOB Cranbrook, Sales Tax included, would be $1520.00. Installations costs would amount to $75.00

For this installation a speed reduction unit would also be required, and this could be supplied for $225.00

Installations of proposed line shafts to transmit power to other devices, pumps, etc., could be carried out complete with belts and pulleys for $275.00

Trusting that you will submit the above in your estimates to the Department.

Yours very truly,

[C.J. Collins, L.M.I.]
Principal.

Dear Major MacKay:

As requested I have given consideration to a letter 2-10 dated April 20th 1940 from the Indian Agent at Cranbrook, and have examined the estimate from the Parks Hardware Co., of Cranbrook in regard to the provision of an iron fire escape at the rear of the Kootenay Indian Residential School.

The provision of a fire escape to take care of the children in the new T.B. dormitory and the proposed T.B. dormitory on the boys' side, these rooms being located on the attic floor of the school, was recommended on Page 5 and in the covering letter of my report on this school dated February 28th 1940.

I am very anxious that the Department should not be put to any avoidable expenditure, particularly during the continuation of the present war, but I at the same time am anxious that the children have all possible protection in case of a fire at the school.

Dear Sir:

We have received your telegram requesting specifications necessary to complete our tender on the diesel and battery equipment to be supplied the KOOTENAY RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL near Cranbrook.

These specifications were unfortunately omitted when the tender was mailed. They are included herewith.

For several years we have supplied equipment to and serviced the electrical plant at this institution. We have quoted on equipment that experience with this load indicated to be best. We would refer you to a report made by us for the DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS about February, 1939. In this report the present inefficient manner of battery charging is fully covered and it is pointed out how this could be considerably improved. Since this has a large bearing on our selection of satisfactory we are mentioning it now with the sincere wish that it may be of service.

The present operator at the school feels that he should have a large engine to keep his batteries charged. This is not in accordance with best practices as a sixteen horse power engine will more than handle the generator it is intended to drive. The peak demands of this building are still lower than the capacity of the generator plus the battery reserve, consequently the use of a larger engine would result only in greater initial cost, greater operating cost and greater maintenance, with no material benefit gained. The major part of the time the engine is used as a straight battery charger with the generator delivering thirty six amperes at one hundred twenty volts. This load of thirty six hundred watts converted to horse power is barely five horse power. This still leaves a full ten horse power reserve for peak demands when required.

Please accept our thanks in holding your tenders for the arrival of our specifications and we hope the bit of information contained herein will be of some slight value to you.

With reference to your letter of the 16th instant and previous correspondence regarding the new lighting unit and batteries for the Kootenay Indian Residential School some further information is required before the Purchasing Branch can proceed with this purchase.

I find, on reviewing our files, that a 13 plate 56 cell 200 ampere hour battery unit carrying a seven-year guarantee was supplied to this school at a cost of $765.00 by J.A. Ward, Proprietor, Modern Electric, Cranbrook, B.C., in January, 1936.

In writing to Indian Agent Irwin in a letter dated August 3, 1939, requesting inclusion in the estimates for 1940-41 of sufficient funds for the purchase of new batteries the Principal, Rev. P.J. Collins, O.M.I., wrote in part as follows:

"The plant is also equipped with a set of storage batteries of 250 ampere hour rating. These are acid batteries, however, and are limited to a discharge of 10 amperes or a load of 1.12 K.W. which they will carry for a period of 25 hours. Inspection shows that these batteries are in rather poor shape with considerable sediment collected in the bottoms of the jars and the plates badly warped from overload conditions. It is very doubtful if these batteries will last another season. From experience at the plant, it has been noticed that a sixty watt lamp operated from the batteries gives very little light and over a period of two hours reduces itself to a red glow, the only other device in use at the same time being the refrigeration plant."

Major D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.
You will note from the above that there was a seven-year guarantee on the batteries that are at present in use at the school. Has the Principal at any time brought to the attention of the Modern Electric Co. that the present set of batteries have become practically useless? Is the present condition of the batteries due to careless supervision? If so, what guarantee has this Branch that a new set of batteries will receive better attention? I think you will agree with me that four years is a rather short life for a set of batteries guaranteed to last seven years.

You will also note from the last part of the quotation from the Principal's letter that apparently the operation of the refrigeration plant is a drain on the batteries. Instructions have been issued on many occasions to all Principals of Indian residential schools that the batteries should only be used for lighting purposes. Dear Sir:

Your File 155-0-5.

I have to refer to your letter of October 29th regarding the set of batteries at present in use at the Kootenay Indian Residential School.

It is observed that these batteries were supplied in 1936 and carry a seven-year guarantee. There is no record here of this transaction and it would appear that purchase was made by the Department through the local Indian Agent without reference to this office.

I should say that it is fairly obvious from Principal Collins' report of August 3, 1939, to Mr. Indian Agent Irwin that the present condition of the batteries was brought about by excessive load and lack of necessary attention. The presence of sediment in the jars and warped plates would certainly suggest these as the main causes, and under the circumstances, the Modern Electric Company could not reasonably be held responsible for replacement under their guarantee.

If the batteries were charged regularly and overcharging avoided, and distilled water added when required, the extra load necessary to carry the type of refrigerator in use at the Kootenay Residential School should not have lessened to any material extent the life of the batteries. However, if the above mentioned precautions were not taken, the batteries would, of course, rapidly deteriorate. The red glow referred to by Principal Collins could be caused by short circuits created through a lumpy, uneven surface of sediment deposit in the jars.

The Principal, under whose direct control the school is operated, has a very definite responsibility in seeing to it that those of his staff entrusted with the care and operation of the lighting plant and its various divisions carry out their duties efficiently. The Indian Agent is also

I am in receipt of your letter of December 24th regarding power supply to the Kootenay Indian Residential School near Cranbrook.

First I must tell you something of the history of the building of the Wasa line. This line and the substation supplying it was built for the Department of Transport at their expense and they retain the ownership of the line and equipment supplying it. We have just completed the line and got it into operation.

The transformer in the substation is of sufficient capacity to supply the Indian Mission as well as the airport providing your Department can make satisfactory arrangements with the Department of Transport. Unfortunately the location of the substation is further from the Mission than it would have been if built to supply the Mission only. Therefore, three and a half miles of transmission line is required to supply the School.

Assuming that the School requires a single phase service, which I believe will be satisfactory, the cost of building this line which would have to be built and owned by yourselves would be $6,200.00 according to our estimate.

This estimate is higher than we expected due (1) to increased cost of material; and (2) to the fact that we discovered very difficult digging conditions when building the Wasa line. Although it is only gravel digging, this gravel is cemented together by lime making some of the hardest digging we have ever encountered. The route followed by the line to the Mission is through identical country as that followed by the Wasa line to the airport.

I would advise you that in this connection I have also received a similar enquiry from Mr. Walker, Supervising Engineer in Banff and will forward a copy of this letter to him.
Regarding an arrangement between your Department and the Department of Transport, I would advise you that the rate you actually pay for power will depend largely on the Department of Transport officials as they will expect to include in the rate some rental for their equipment that is necessarily used to supply you.

We have been able to make an agreement whereby the Town of Cowley is able to get a small amount of power through the Department's equipment supply the Cowley Airport and I, therefore, see no reason why you should not be in a better position to make a similar arrangement with another Department of the Government.

Should you require three phase power, which I believe is unnecessary at the present time, I can give you the cost on a three phase line at a future date.

Yours very truly,

East Kootenay Power Co. Ltd.,

G.E. Elkington,
General Manager.

Dear Sir:

We have received your telegram requesting specifications necessary to complete our tender on the diesel and battery equipment to be supplied the KOOTENAY RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL near Cranbrook.

These specifications were unfortunately omitted when the tender was mailed. They are included herewith.

For several years we have supplied equipment to and serviced the electrical plant at this institution. We have quoted on equipment that experience with this load indicated to be best. We would refer you to a report made by us for the DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS about February, 1939. In this report the present inefficient manner of battery charging is fully covered and it is pointed out how this could be considerably improved. Since this has a large bearing on our selection of satisfactory we are mentioning it now with the sincere wish that it may be of service.

The present operator at the school feels that he should have a large engine to keep his batteries charged. This is not in accordance with best practices as a sixteen horse power engine will more than handle the generator it is intended to drive. The peak demands of this building are still lower than the capacity of the generator plus the battery reserve, consequently the use of a larger engine would result only in greater initial cost, greater operating cost and greater maintenance, with no material benefit gained. The major part of the time the engine is used as a straight battery charger with the generator delivering thirty amperes at one hundred twenty volts. This load of thirty six hundred watts converted to horse power is barely five horse power. This still leaves a full ten horse power reserve for peak demands when required.

Please accept our thanks in holding your tenders for the arrival of our specifications and we hope the bit of information contained herein will be of some slight value to you.

Yours truly,

(Sgd.) John A. Ward.

Dear Sir:

We take pleasure in enclosing herewith our report and estimate on the cost of installing a FIRE ALARM SYSTEM and making repairs to existing wiring in the Kootenay Residential School.

We have made a very careful survey of the wiring system in this school. Accurate tests were made of all the circuit on each floor to determine the condition of the wires in the concealed raceways. Tests were also made on every circuit and feeder wire for shorts and grounds.

Certain hazardous conditions exist which have been largely caused by additions and extensions to the present system. These defective extensions consist for the most part of outlets wired in cotton lamp cord strictly against the code requirements. We have itemized these defective parts and quoted on the cost of placing all wiring in first class shape.

Perhaps the greatest cause for inefficiency of this system lies in the method of current distribution at the main panel or switchboard. At the time of installation the demands were fairly light and ample battery and generator capacities were available. The system was connected as a straight battery charging system and the bulk of the load was handled by batteries alone after the plant was shut down. Also the large gasoline driven generator could easily handle the battery charging load and the complete house load if necessity arose. To this end the batteries were connected for charging through a switching arrangement that allowed them to be charged in parallel. This means that the battery unit consisting of fifty six cells of two volts each would be connected in two groups of twenty eight cells for charging and would be changed back to one unit of fifty six cells for discharging or operating the system. For stability a limiting resistor was introduced in the battery circuit for charging. If lights were required when the batteries were on charge they were obtained directly from the generator.

As noted above this was fairly satisfactory when the load was comparatively small. With the introduction a few months ago of electrical refrigeration and the normal increased use of appliances the overall load is considerably higher. To further aggravate the condition a diesel driven generator of only half the capacity of the original job is used to charge the batteries. With the hook up already described the charging load and house load far exceeds the capacity of the diesel generator and many times the equipment is working far below its normal voltage output.

We would strongly recommend that this entire set up be reconnected so that at peaks the batteries would aid the generator and at minimum demands sufficient current would be introduced into the batteries to keep them fully charged.
The manner in which a changeover is made from the gasoline generator to the diesel generator is very poor and does not comply with the electrical code in any respect. The wiring from the diesel generator to the switchboard is encased in ordinary water pipe and the wiring is dripping with fuel oil. No terminal fittings of any sort are provided. The generator itself is thoroughly soaked in fuel oil and badly needs cleaning.

Certain new wiring is badly needed and we have listed this separately. This consists of lights in the garage toilet and engine room etc.

We thank you for this opportunity of quoting and trust that the information supplied is that which you require. Please call upon us if any further data is required.

Yours Truly

"John A. Ward"

Dear Sir:

Since I was named principal of the Kootenay Indian Residential School, I have found that the lighting system is very poor. A short time ago I had an expert make a complete check-up of all the electric devices and lights used at the school and connected to the plant, with the following findings:

Maximum light load possible winter conditions: 12KW

Maximum day load covering Laundry, Kelvinator: 7KW

Potential load maximum that could be imposed on plant: 19KW

To carry this load the school has a plant equipped with two generators if the following specifications:

(1) Crossman generator:
Output: ............. 4KW
Voltage: ........... 125
Amperage: .......... 32

This unit is equipped with a 7 HP Petter Diesel engine and is quite economical in operation but is heavily overloaded.

(2) Westinghouse Generator:
Output: ............. 10KW
Voltage: ........... 125
Amperage: .......... 80

This unit is operated by a very old Fairbanks Morse 15 HP single cylinder engine, in extremely poor shape and consequently wasteful in both lubricating oil and
fuel (gasoline), which renders it useless for economical generation of electrical energy.

The plant is also equipped with a set of storage batteries of 250 ampere hour rating. These are acid batteries however, and are limited to a discharge of 10 amperes or a load of 1.12 K.W., which they will carry for a period of 25 hours. Inspection shows that these batteries are in rather poor shape with considerable sediment collected in the bottoms of the jars and the plates badly warped from overload conditions. It is very doubtful if these batteries will last another season. From experience at the plant, it has been noticed that a sixty watt lamp operated from the batteries gives very little light and over a period of two hours reduces itself to a red glow the only other device in use at the same time being the refrigeration plant.

Under present conditions at the school the procedure is to use the 4 KW motor generator set for all normal operations as it can be operated most economically. This is hardly a fair procedure as this machine is too small to meet with the requirements even with the help of the storage batteries. The result is that this unit and the batteries are heavily overloaded, especially during the winter months.

Originally this plant consisted of the 10KW plant only and it is quite apparent that this was installed to take care of definite load conditions. These loads have been increased considerably in the past few years, but no arrangements have been made to take care of them. In fact, the capacity of the plant has been reduced to where a 4 KW plant and battery set are expected to carry the load that was previously carried by a 10KW plant and the same set of batteries.

SUGGESTIONS FOR THE IMPROVEMENT OF THE POWER PLANT

That a new Diesel power unit is purchased of 15 to 20 HP., and installed to operate the two generators. This power plant could also be connected to a line shaft so that it could be used for pumping water also, thereby serving a dual purpose. The unit recommended is illustrated in cuts attached. Dear Sir:

In reply to your question about the installation of the Lister engine, I beg to state that Father Collins, who objected to its installation, has now left this School. He wished to have power supplied from a power line but, in my presence, Mr Phelan told the Very Revd. Father Scannell that the cost, approximately $6000.00 was prohibitive. As a second choice, Father Collins wished to have another make of engine less costly than the Lister but, in his opinion, more efficient. What his objections to the Lister engine were, I do not know. In several letters to Officials of the Department, he explained them. The only objection which I would have had is that we had one at the Kakawis School and I was told that repair parts are very hard to get as they are said to come from England. I mentioned this to Mr Philip Phelan, when I was in Ottawa recently and he replied that the Prairie Schools appeared to have no difficulty in getting parts.

After talking the matter over with Father Collins, we spoke to the gentleman who has the contract to install the Lister engine and asked him to install it. I do not know whether this engine or the one Father Collins wanted installed is better but I do know that we need an engine in a hurry and I suggested that we take the Lister so as to avoid the delay which would occur were the engine not installed before the end of the fiscal year.

Unfortunately, it does not seem to have been pointed out to the Department that the engine was required for pumping water as well as for supplying light. However, the man who is installing the engine is having a pulley made at his expense and this pulley can, I understand, be so fitted up that water can be pumped.

I have not seen the contract but hope that it calls for the removal of the present engine.

Power supplied by the power line would have been better and cheaper in the long run but that is out of the question now.

Trusting that I have fully answered your question,

I remain yours truly,

G. Forbes,
Principal.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

As you are aware, the latest diesel engine was installed about 3 weeks ago. I was going to write to you at that time but was informed that the Department was supplying us with flooring for the dormitories. This flooring has just been unloaded here and I wish to thank you and the Department for the engines and flooring. Both were very much needed and they are really appreciated.

We intend to start laying the flooring on Monday and that is just the right time as our friend Mr. Berry tells me that he & Mr. Maclean will be here on the 25th. They will see the boys at work on the floor. All the boys will not be employed at this work as I shall have to detail a few to look after Barry's affairs so that the Department will not have to pay, as it was once requested to pay, for 1/2 an hour of workers.

I have found a letter here, dated August 1st, 1939, from the Fred M. Beatty Co. of Vancouver, which seems to indicate that the following matter was brought to the attention of the department at about that time. Some four or five years ago, there was a severe earthquake...
March 16th morning or less one that evening. As a result, the foundation (cement) of the barn is severely damaged and there are several cracks in the building. It is possible that no serious damage was done but I would suggest that a survey of both buildings be made. According to the letter, a survey was at least prepared for the Spring of 1940. So far as I know nothing was done—no great deal of cold & draught came in through these cracks & though the poorly fitting windows, the letter mentioned a survey of the cracks & windows also suggested how the condition might be remedied. Only a rough survey was made at the time. The real survey was to have been made in the Spring. I am finding no further correspondence on the matter.

In my annual report, I stressed the fact that there was practically no fire alarm system here. There are a few ordinary door bells which, when they ring, might easily be mistaken for the telephone or door bell. The Department, if I understand a letter on file, had Mr. Ward (Modern Electric Co., Brandon) quote them make a report & submit estimates for a real fire alarm & proper wiring of the building. The wiring system is far from proper wiring of the building. The wiring may have been exaggerated but I am told that the wiring is not in good condition. I believe that the Department, like myself, would feel more at ease if they knew just what danger there is or there is not here.

There is a house, owned by the Oblate here, which has been partly torn down. I am trying to get permission...
To use the rest of the lumber to build a blacksmith shop & a jigging. We have to scrape & save here to make ends meet.

Even the Indians are rationed up at present.

This allowing the Indians to enlist is not to their real advantage if, what I believe, is true. Their drinking propensities seem to increase. It is a bad thing to take the husbands away from their wives at least in some instances. The money paid to the wives and dependents is not beneficially used. Of course, there may be exceptions to these new objections.

With kind personal regards,

I remain Yours Truly,

Indians Fight Fire at Mission Near Cranbrook

(From Our Own Correspondent)

CRANBROOK, B.C., May 3—Fire first noticed about 10:30 p.m. completely destroyed the carpenter and blacksmith shop at the St. Eugene Mission, seven miles from Cranbrook.

With no fire fighting facilities in the village the Indians of the school and mission fought it to the best of their ability but it had already gained too much headway. The Cranbrook fire department was summoned but they could not control it either.

The damage is estimated at about $3,000. The buildings were the property of the department of Indian affairs, who have made no decision about rebuilding yet.
Ottawa,
May 12, 1941.

AIR MAIL

Dear Sir:

Information has just reached the Department that the carpenter and blacksmith shop at the Kootenay Indian Residential School was destroyed by fire on April 29. I have also received today a clipping from the Lethbridge Herald dated May 3 in which the newspaper states that the damage done by the fire is estimated at $5000.00.

No report of this fire has been received from your office. It is difficult to understand why any Indian Agent should not report immediately any damage caused to any of the Departmental buildings in his Agency either by fire or any other cause.

I will expect to receive a complete report regarding this fire from you by return mail and at the same time you should explain fully why you have delayed forwarding this information.

Yours truly,

Extract from letter written to Mr. Doucet by Rev. G. Forbes, O.M.I., Principal of the Kootenay Indian Residential School.

You may have heard that on the Tuesday night following your visit our carpenter and blacksmith shops were entirely destroyed by fire. At great risk to themselves, Fr. Murray, the carpenter and an Indian saved quite a few of the carpenter tools but none of those in the blacksmith shop. Bro. Cullen looked after those in the school building, and I looked after the older boys. All we could do was to stop the fire from spreading. We and the Indian Agent tried to have the Fire Dept. come but they would not. The Agent got two policemen to come with two extinguishers but they came too late to do any good. Finally one fireman and a fire truck came but this was much too late. One good hose with sufficient pressure would have saved at least the carpenter shop together with the tools and the 4800' of flooring all lost. To save as many of the school tools as possible, Fr. Murray and Reiferscheid made no attempt to save the tools owned by the Oblates and Mr. Reiferscheid.

About 20 people came from Cranbrook to see the sight but not one offered to help us. Perhaps they felt that it was useless. The police and the lone fireman did what they could.

What pleased me was that there was no panic -- discipline was perfect and the boys did just as they were told. They wanted to go into the burning building to save tools and lumber and they could have saved some of each but I told them to stay out of the building as I did not want any casualties.

On the whole, we were very fortunate. The wind blew the flames and sparks away from the barn. Fire started on an old play hall but it was put out. Had the wind blown from the opposite direction, there would have been a general clean-up.
I do not know how the fire started. It started in the blacksmith shop. One of the men used the forge, I am told, earlier in the day and two boys told me, during the fire, that they had seen a fire in the blacksmith shop in the afternoon. Against this story is the fact that Bro. Cullen went to the blacksmith shop between 5 and 5:30 p.m. and saw or smelt no fire. He noticed the fire while making his rounds at 10:30. The blacksmith shop had been used as a sort of storeroom. I found cardboard boxes, papers and rags there but had them removed and burned a couple of days after I came here. I had a pile of rubbish, on the other side of the carpenter shop, burned several days before the fire.

I hope that my next letter will carry better news. Anything you can do to get us new shops, to have the lost tools replaced and flooring sent in place of that which was destroyed will be greatly appreciated. The boys would build the shops and lay the dormitory floors as part of their training.
April 30th, 1941

Mr. A. Irwin,
Indian Agent,
Cranbrook, B.C.

Dear Sir:

As you are aware, fire completely destroyed our blacksmith and carpenter shops last night. All the contents of the blacksmith shop were destroyed or badly damaged as it was impossible to get into the building. The only thing we could do was to try to save the carpenter shop and its contents. We failed to save the building and about 5000' of flooring, just received from the Department, but we did save some of the tools. A detailed list of the tools lost is being prepared. If any were saved, it was due to what I must call the heroic efforts of Father Murray, Mr. Reifferscheid (the carpenter) and Toby Morigeau. Mr. Townsend, the engineer, worked frantically to save the carpenter shop. Jerome Joseph also rendered valuable assistance. The Chief and other Indians came too late to help. About 20 White people came but did not offer to help. The two policemen and the one fireman rendered what assistance they could but they did not arrive on time.

May I suggest that you request that the Indian Department show its appreciation for the work done by the two Indians, Toby Morigeau (who went into the building several times, with Father Murray and Reifferscheid, and saved many tools although the building was in flames) and Jerome Joseph who did not spare himself?

While making his rounds at 10.30, Brother Cullen noticed the fire and immediately notified me after awaking an employee (Mullins, whose hard work I forgot to mention) and the senior boys. I asked him to telephone to you and to the Fire Department and he did so while I took a look at the fire and decided not to awaken the girls or the smaller boys as the fire was at a distance and the wind was not blowing towards the main building. Brother Cullen turned on all lights in the building, notified the Sisters and took charge of all in the school. He did this without causing any excitement.

With the older boys, I took what fire extinguishers had been left by the men who were already fighting the fire and we did what we could. I am pleased to say that there was perfect discipline, that the boys did exactly what they were told and remained cool. While they might have saved more from the carpenter shop, had they gone in, I ordered them to remain outside.

We soon saw that the buildings could not be saved and, so, we tried to prevent the fire from spreading. The water just dribbled out of our garden hose and so the boys carried pails and pails of water. Fortunately, the wind was in our favor. It did start fires on the roof of the root cellar and on an outside playhall as well as on fences and trees but Mr. Townsend worked as he had done on the other buildings but, this time, he was successful. Had the wind been in the opposite direction, it would have been impossible to save the barn, pig pen (such as it is), ice house, chicken coops, horses, cows, pigs, chickens, etc. There would also have been serious danger to the school building particularly on account of a reason I shall give later.

And a real fire hose with plenty of pressure would have saved everything!
With regard to the origin of the fire, I cannot as yet make a definite statement. An immediate investigation would likely produce no results. I have reason to believe that, if a boy started the fire, the truth will come out later. At present, I do not believe that it was deliberately started. It may have been. I am told that a man used the forge and, although he is careful, he may not have entirely extinguished the fire.

Several hours later, a boy was sent to the blacksmith shop (where the fire originated) and was slow returning. If there was fire in the forge (and this is doubtful) he may have fanned the flame. A young boy (truthfully or to make himself important?) told me that he had seen the fire in the afternoon. If this is true, why did I, several employees and the boys not see it as we were within sight of the building until 8 or 9 p.m.? Surely by that time the fire would have been noticeable. I am told that the fire started on the floor and not in the forge. Of course, fanning the flame might have made sparks fall on the floor. I expect that more will come out later.

When I came here, I found that cardboard boxes were stored in the blacksmith shop and I had them removed and burned.

I know of no reason for which anyone would seek to burn down the blacksmith shop (except myself in the hopes of getting a better one). I have not been harsh with the children. I have not cut down on their food; they all seem contented. Sometimes, pupils set fire to a school so that there will be no school and, consequently, they will have to go home. The burning of the blacksmith shop, situated as it is far from the school building, would not accomplish that object. However, if that boy really saw the fire and did not report it, certain things may be possible. But the efforts that they made, the more efforts which they wished to make to save the buildings and contents... Nothing adds up!

It is not necessary to make suggestions. Both you and I saw the lack of fire equipment here and we did what we could to have this remedied. This is not a criticism of "Ottawa". Money is scarce. But you, I and Ottawa would not like to read the Papers with all the publicity they would give us if there were a holocaust here. I was through a $40,000 fire in a college and I am afraid of fire in an Indian School.

Sufficient protection can be had but it will cost money. If that money is not spent and if there is a fire here, we shall all of us regret not having spent the money.

In addition to the suggestions I made in my recent report to the Department, I now suggest that the gasoline tank, which is now immediately adjacent to the school building, be removed to a safe distance. This is an underground tank but, if the fire had spread to the barn and nearby buildings, the heat might have expanded the gasoline so that it would have risen through the pipes and... goodbye all of us. A second suggestion is that the Department come to an agreement with the Cranbrook Fire Dept., so that they come when needed. I know part of the efforts you made (and suspect the rest) to have them come here last night. They just refused to come until you insisted and insisted and they finally sent one man (who really worked) and a fire engine that, due to their unwillingness, arrived too late. If it did cost money... well an M.P., a friend of mine, had me give certain details on another case to the Minister and Mr Creara appreciated it. I do not want to
flatter the Department, to tell them that the Indians are the apples of their eyes, etc., but I do know that they take an interest in the Indians and that they are afraid of a fire and the possible resultant holocaust. They would be heartless and fools if they were not afraid.

I have tried not to say anything of what you did for us last night but I assure you that what you did to try to have the fire department come, to have the policemen with their fire extinguishers come, your coming here and offering all possible assistance are duly appreciated.

Yours very truly,

G. Forbes
Between 10.30 and 11 P.M. on the night of April 29th, a phone call was received at the Agency, from Brother Gullen of the Kootenay Indian School, informing me that the School Blacksmith and Carpenter Shops were on fire, and that such protection as they had, was of little or no account to cope with the growing flames. The Fire and Police Departments were immediately notified, but before they could reach the scene of the fire, the Buildings were completely enveloped and could not be saved.

The Boys of the School were well disciplined, and did excellent work with a few Fire Extinguishers and many Buckets. The Reverend Principal, the Rev. Missionary, Mr. Murray the Carpenter- Mr. Reifferscheid Mr. Townsend- the Engineer, and two of the Indians- Jerome Joseph, and Toby Moriceau, all gave a very fine account of themselves in their efforts to save as many of the tools of the Carpenter shop as possible.

Included in the contents burnt was about 5000 feet Flooring recently provided by the Department to cover the floors of the Boys' and Girls' Dormitories, also quite a number of Tools. When the list has been completed by the Principal, I shall forward the same to the Department.

By great good fortune the wind was in our favour, otherwise the Barn, and all other out-buildings would have been destroyed;

I enclose herewith a most descriptive and very accurate account of the fire, but the Rev. Principal Forbes, which stresses among other things, the well known fact that a fire at the Kootenay Indian Residential School is something far beyond our power and ability to deal with successfully with such hopelessly inadequate protective equipment as we now possess. A fire once started, would be almost certain to result in a Building burned.

I trust, therefore, that the Report submitted by the Principal for the reasons given, at whatever the cost, may receive the most careful and serious consideration.

Andrew Irwin,
Indian Agent.

Kootenay Indian Residential School. Apr. 30th. 1941

Mr. A. Irwin,
Indian Agent,
Cranbrook, B.C.

Dear Sir:

As you are aware, fire completely destroyed our Blacksmith and Carpenter Shops last night. All the contents of the Blacksmith Shop were destroyed or badly damaged as it was impossible to get into the building. The only thing we could do was to try to save the Carpenter Shop and its contents. We failed to save the Building and about 5000' of Flooring, just received from the Department, but we did save some of the tools. A detailed list of the tools lost is being prepared. If any were saved it was due to what I must call the heroic efforts of Father Murray, Mr. Reifferscheid (the Carpenter) and Toby Moriceau. Mr. Townsend the engineer worked frantically to save the Carpenter shop. Jerome Joseph also rendered valuable assistance. The Chief and other Indians came too late to help. About twenty white people came but did not offer to help. The two policemen and the one fireman rendered what assistance they could, but they did not arrive on time.

May I suggest that you request that the Indian Department show its appreciation for the work done by the two Indians, Toby Moriceau, who went into the building several times with Father Murray and Reifferscheid and saved many tools, although the building was in flames) and Jerome Joseph who did not spare himself?

While making his rounds at 10-30, Brother Cullen noticed the fire and immediately notified me after waking an employee (Mullins, whose hard work I forgot to mention) and the senior boys. I asked him to telephone to you and to the Fire Department, and he did so while took a look at the fire and decided not to awaken the girls or the smaller boys as the fire was at a distance, and the wind was not blowing towards the main building. Brother Cullen turned on all lights in the building, notified the Sisters and took charge of all in the School. He did this without causing any excitement.

With the Older Boys, I took what Fire Extinguishers had been left by the men who were already fighting the fire, and we did what we could. I am pleased to say that there was perfect discipline, that the boys did exactly what they were told and remained cool, while they might have saved more from the Carpenter Shop had they gone in, I ordered them to remain outside.

We soon saw that the buildings could not be saved, and so we tried to prevent the fire from spreading. The water just dribbled out of our garden Hose and so the boys carried pails and pails of water. Fortunately, the wind was in our favor. It did start fires on the roof of the root cellar and on an outside play-hall as well as on fences and trees but Mr. Townsend worked as he had done on the other buildings, but this time he was successful. Had the wind been in the opposite direction, it would have been impossible to save the Barn, Pig Pen, (such as it is) Ice House, Chicken Coops, Horses, Cows, Pigs, Chickens etc. There would also have been serious danger to the...
School building, particularly on account of a reason I shall give later.

And a real hose with plenty of pressure would have saved everything.

With regard to the origin of the fire, I cannot as yet make a definite statement. An immediate investigation would likely produce no results. I have reason to believe that, if a boy started the fire, the truth will come out later. At present, I do not believe that it was deliberately started. It may have been. I am told that a man used the forge and although he is careful, he may not have entirely extinguished the fire. Several hours later, a boy was sent to the Blacksmith's shop (where the fire originated) and was slow returning. If there was fire in the Forge, (and this is doubtful) he may have fanned the flame. A young boy (truthfully, or to make himself important?) told me that he had seen the fire in the afternoon. If this is true, why did I, several employees and the boys not see it as we were within sight of the building until eight or nine p.m.? Surely, by that time the fire would have been noticeable. I am told that the fire started on the floor and not in the forge. I expect that more will come out later.

When I came here, I found that cardboard boxes were stored in the Blacksmith's shop and I had them removed and burned.

I know of no reason for which anyone would seek to burn down the Blacksmith's shop (except myself, in the hopes of getting a better one). I have not been harsh with the children. I have not cut down on their food. They all seem contented. Sometimes pupils set fire to a school, so that there will be no school, and consequently, they will have to go home. The burning of the Blacksmith's shop, situated as it is far from the school building, would not accomplish that object. However, if that boy really saw the fire and did not report it, certain things may be possible. But the efforts that they made, the more efforts which they wished to make to save the buildings and contents... nothing adds up.

It is not necessary to make suggestions. Both you and I saw the lack of Fire Equipment here, and we did what we could to have this remedied. This is not a criticism of "Ottawa" Money IS scarce, but you, I, and Ottawa would not like to read the papers with all the publicity they would give us if there were a holocaust here. I was through a $40,000 fire in College, and I am afraid of fire in an Indian School.

Sufficient protection can be had, but it will cost money. If that money is not spent, and if there is a fire here, we shall, all of us regret not having spent the money.

In addition to the suggestions I made in the recent report to the Department, I now suggest that the Gasoline Tank, which is now immediately adjacent to the School Building, be removed to a safe distance. This is an underground tank, but, if the fire had spread to the Barn and nearby buildings, the heat might have expanded the gasoline, so that it would have risen through the pipes and... goodbye, all of us. A second suggestion is,
Mr. Andrew Irwin,
Cranbrook, B.C.

Department came to an agreement with the Cranbrook Fire Department, so that they come when needed. I know part of the efforts you made (and suspect the rest) to have them come here last night. They just refused to come, until you insisted and insisted, and they finally sent one man (who really worked) and a fire engine that, due to their unwillingness, arrived too late. If it did cost money... well, an M.P., a friend of mine had me give certain details on another case to the Minister and Crerar—appreciated it.

I do not want to flatter the Department, to tell them that the Indians are the apples of their eyes, etc., but I do know that they take an interest in the Indians, and that they are afraid of a fire and the possible resultant holocaust. They would be heartless, and fools, if they were not afraid.

I have tried not to say anything of what you did for us last night, but I assure you that what you did to try to have the Fire Department come, to have the Policeman with their fire extinguishers come, your coming here and offering all possible assistance, are duly appreciated.

Yours very truly,

Signed.... G. Forbes.

P.S. I now find that Brother Cullen was in the Blacksmiths' Shop between 5 and 5-30 p.m. and that there was no sign of fire then. G.F.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER.

Indian Agent Irwin reports that the blacksmith and carpenter shops at the Kootenay Indian Residential School were totally destroyed by fire on the night of April 29.

In addition to the destruction of these buildings by fire, $436 worth of lumber, necessary to repair the floors in the main school building, was also destroyed. This lumber was recently purchased (see purchase order No. 6619).

The Indian Agent in his report states:

"The boys of the school were well disciplined and did excellent work with a few fire extinguishers and many buckets. The Principal, a Missionary, the carpenter, the engineer and two Indians, Jerome Joseph and Toby Morigean, all gave a very fine account of themselves in their efforts to save as many of the tools at the carpenter shop as possible. By great good fortune the wind was in our favour; otherwise the barn and all other outbuildings would have been destroyed".

It is estimated that between $8,500 and $2,000 will be required to replace these buildings. The Kootenay Residential School is operated by the Department in cooperation with the Roman Catholic Church, and has at this date an enrolment of 90 pupils. The origin of this fire has not been determined.

Director.

Dear Sir:

In replying to your air-mail letter of the 18th, I am at a loss to know why you did not receive any Report of the fire at the Kootenay Indian Residential School before the date mentioned in your letter, having been mailed, as it was, on the 6th inst., together with a very full and complete Report by the Reverend Principal of the School. Later, a detailed accounting in triplicate, of all Tools Lumber etc., lost in the fire as well as those that were saved, was forwarded to the Indian Commissioner, Major D.M. Mackay.

I felt that the Reverend Principal's Report which was attached to mine, gave the Department a very full and complete account of the fire, apart from detail in respect of losses in Tools which could not be accurately estimated until later.

When, and after your letter arrived, I was absent on the Reserves for two days, and hence could not answer immediately.

I am sure the Department have long since realized the dire necessity of providing more adequate and dependable fire protection at the School, and the longer it is delayed, the longer the School must continue a constant dread.

What actually caused the fire I do not know; the Principal does not know, although it is stated in his Report that the Forge in the Blacksmith Shop had been used in the afternoon of that day, and that the fire might not have been entirely extinguished. He also states that a Boy was sent to the Blacksmith Shop several hours later where the fire originated, and was slow returning. Inferring that, if the fire was still alive he might have fanned the flames, causing sparks to fall on the floor which, later, might have started the outbreak. It is all conjecture; no one actually knows, but what we do know is this, had there been proper fire protection at the School, the buildings could easily have been saved.
In this respect, as in others, the Principal's statement is correct, when he insists that a REAL FIRE HOSE WITH PLENTY OF PRESSURE would have saved everything.

May I quote from a statement issued by the Acting Chief of the Cranbrook Fire Brigade to his Worship the Mayor, and Members of the City Council, with respect to this fire. He states:

A very serious fire hazard exists at the Kootenay Indian Residential School. The School itself, a large two storey building is without Fire Escapes, and exposed to danger from several frame out-buildings such as Barns etc., which are quite near. There is practically no fire protection whatever. The pressure is so low in the domestic water supply, that it is of no use for fighting fire. The situation is very dangerous, and should have the attention of those in authority."

So has written the Acting Fire Chief of the Cranbrook Fire Department.

There is not a soul in the Cranbrook district familiar with the School who fails to realize the ever lurking danger of a holocaust. There is grave responsibility somewhere in the event of a serious fire, for the protection of the Children and the Staff, and yet, in the words of the Acting Chief, a very serious fire hazard exists, and needless to say, will continue to exist until there is sufficient equipment and water power to fight a fire.

The Cranbrook Fire Department sent one man and a Fire Engine. They were not too easily pressed into service, but did good work when they got there. The Provincial Police also turned out with Fire Extinguishers and did their best, which simply was not good enough to make any impression; without a water supply the Buildings just had to go.

If we are to have any protection at all against a recurrence of what happened the other night, I would most respectfully suggest that
an agreement should be arrived at with the Cranbrook Fire Department to respond immediately when called, otherwise we would not have a chance, and even with the fullest co-operation from the Fire Department there can be no guarantee of security or safety from the worst that easily could happen unless dependable pressure to make the best use of fire fighting equipment is supplied.

I enclose herewith itemized statements from the Cranbrook Sash & Door Co., quoting on the materials required to re-build the Carpenter and Blacksmith Shops at respective costs of $523.59 and $151.80.

In addition to this, I would point out as shown in previous reports, about 5000 feet Flooring lost, that had recently been purchased to re-floor the Dormitories. This also is urgently needed.

The enclosed statements of cost in respect of all materials required to replace Buildings burned, are furnished only in the hope that they may be helpful to the Department as a means of supplying accurate information as to the cost of re-building, should they decide to do so.

I/L

INSPECTION OF THE ST. MARY'S INDIAN SCHOOL
MISSION, CHANBROOK, B. C.

October 25, 1938.

PLASTER OFF WALLS AND CEILINGS.

The plaster is in very bad condition in many places in the School, particularly in the entrances or exits of both boys and girls basement sides. Also sewing room, main dining room, and hall-ways. This in itself is a very bad fire hazard, and should fire break out it would be drawn up through the walls and ceilings through the places where plaster is missing, and run under the floors all over the building before anyone would be aware.

ELECTRIC WIRING.

The electric wiring throughout the school is very old and quite out of date, and has apparently been repaired or altered at different times by persons other than electricians.

Sockets missing in several places and the live wires not taped, ordinary drop cord wiring running through holes in walls and partitions without any protection whatever in the way of insulation of any kind. Floor sockets installed in a poor manner, loose and dangerous. Most of the drop cord wiring is so old that it has perished, the insulation being all cracked.

STOVES, STOVE-PIPES AND OVENS.

The stove pipes in the laundry and drying room are very old and a very bad hazard. The pipes should all be renewed and on account of the length of some, would suggest that they be rivetted so that there will be no danger of coming apart.

In the bakery room there is no protection between the fire boxes of the ovens and the wooden floor. Would suggest that two layers of brick, layed flat be placed the full length and width of the ovens, with a four inch space left at front and sides running clear through the top layer of bricks for ventilating purposes, also that some sheet iron or tin be placed on floor in front of fire box doors. At the present time the hot ashes fall out onto the wooden floor.

FIRE ALARM GONGS.

There are several small two inch bells scattered about the building, most of which not even working, and therefore in case of fire of no use whatever.

There certainly should be an up to date fire alarm system installed immediately, as at the present time the lives of the Staff and the children are at stake.
The British Columbia Fire Marshal Act, under which we work are not satisfied with fire gongs or bells less than 10" in diameter, and where buildings are more than two stories in height, there must be a gong on each floor with a break-the-glass station at each gong.

Attached also is an ordinary electric switch in the principal's office for testing purposes, and also used when holding fire drills. This saves breaking the glass or removing same when testing gongs.

FIRE ESCAPES.

Panic bolts should be placed on all exit doors, so that in case of fire there will be no chance of the doors being either locked or hard to open. This matter is also compulsory under the British Columbia Fire Marshal Act.

PLASTER OFF WALLS AND CEILINGS.

The plaster is in very bad condition in many places in the School, particularly in the entrances or exits of both boys and girls basement sides. Also sewing rooms, main dining room, and hall-ways. ELECTRIC WIRING.

The electric wiring throughout the school is very old and quite out of date, and has apparently been repaired or altered at different times by persons other than electricians.

Sockets missing in several places and the live wires not taped, ordinary drop cord wiring running through holes in walls and partitions without any protection whatever in the way of insulation of any kind. Floor sockets installed in a poor manner, loose and dangerous. Most of the drop cord wiring is so old that it has perished, the insulation being all cracked.

The stove pipes in the laundry and drying room are very old and a very bad hazard. The pipes should all be renewed and on account of the length of some, would suggest that they be rivetted so that there will be no danger of coming apart.

In the bakery room there is no protection between the fire boxes of the ovens and the wooden floor. Would suggest that two layers of brick, layed flat be placed the full length and width of the ovens, with a four inch space left at front and sides running clear through the top layer of brick for ventilating purposes, also that some sheet iron or tin be placed on floor in front of fire box doors. At the present time the hot ashes fall out onto the wooden floor.

There are several small two inch bells scattered about the building, most of which not even working, and therefore in case of fire of no use whatever.

There certainly should be an up to date fire alarm system installed immediately, as at the present time the lives of the Staff and the children are at stake.
The British Columbia Fire Marshal Act, under which we work are not satisfied with fire gongs or bells less than 10" in diameter, and where buildings are more than two stories in height, there must be a gong on each floor with a break-the-glass station at each gong.

Attached also is an ordinary electric switch in the Principal's office for the testing purposes, and also used when holding fire drills. This saves breaking the glass or removing same when testing gongs.
