AIR MAIL

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letters of the 21st and 23rd instant reporting on the loss by fire of outbuildings and equipment at the Kootenay Residential School and commenting on the necessity for additional fire protection. I have carefully noted the second paragraph of your letter of the 23rd instant and in view of the limited amount available in the current year's appropriation it will not be possible to proceed with the project that you mention. I have also noted that you do not recommend making an endeavour to enter into an agreement with the Cranbrook Fire Department.

You should, however, arrange for the immediate installation of a fire door equipped with panic bolts.

I also trust that, as requested in my letter of the 21st instant, either yourself or Mr. Coleman will find it possible to visit the Kootenay Residential School at an early date. At that time you should confer with the Agent and the Principal with a view to minimizing as much as possible any fire hazard at the school. When you visit the school you may consider it advisable to secure some additional fire extinguishers. If so, you may arrange for their purchase.

You have already been authorized to purchase the material required for the re-erection of the carpenter shop. The Purchasing Branch here

Major D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.
has arranged for the purchase of the flooring, paper and nails to replace the same articles destroyed by fire.

I am also communicating with the Surveys & Engineering Branch with regard to the recommendation contained in the last paragraph of your letter of the 21st instant.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Memorandum:

DIRECTOR

Surveys & Engineering Branch

Re: Kootenay Indian Residential School, Cranbrook, B.C.

I have been corresponding with Indian Commissioner MacKay in connection with providing additional safeguards at the above-mentioned school against the risk of fire. Commissioner MacKay writes to me in part as follows:

"I would recommend that when Mr. Warren of the Dominion Water and Power Bureau is carrying out irrigation work provided for on the adjoining St. Mary's Reserve that he be asked to report on the possibility of the installation of an engine and pump on St. Mary's River, with a pipeline to the school, to provide water for fire protection. It is contemplated that this might occupy the same site as that shown by a dotted line and marked 'Suction Line Existing System' on the plan accompanying his 'Report on Water Supply for St. Eugene School' dated March 4, 1931."

I should appreciate it if you would issue the necessary instructions to Mr. Warren in order that he may be in a position to report fully to this Branch.

Director.
Dear Sir:

The Principal of the Kootenay Indian Residential School has requested a plan of the septic tank that was installed at the school in 1911. The records here would indicate that although the plan of the school, which no doubt included the septic tank arrangements, was sent here (See your file 11656/5, dated April 7, 1911) these were returned to the Department, as requested.

It would be appreciated if a tracing could be made of that part of the plan dealing with the septic tank and its location, and sent to the Principal.

Yours faithfully,

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Sir:

Re: Engines in Power Plant
Indian Residential School, Cranbrook, B. C.

The Gasoline Engine which was used to operate the lighting generator has been disconnected and a new Lister Diesel Engine installed in its place. This new engine is Lister - Size C.E. 24/17 - Serial 363580 - 16 H. P. at 1200 R.P.M. It is now in operation but will require much further work before the installation is complete.

The Petter Engine which was used to drive the Triplex pumps which supplied the School with fresh water and incidentally the fire service is out of commission and at present the pump is operated from the new Lister Engine by means of a counter shaft. This arrangement would be fairly satisfactory if it was properly installed but the shaft now in operation is made out of a piece of pipe and is very much out of line and when in operation constitutes a bad danger hazard.

I would suggest the following for consideration if the present type of installation is to be continued. Install proper steel shaft and cast-iron bearings and hanger brackets or, better still, send the Petter engine to a reliable firm either at the Coast or Calgary, Alberta for a complete overhaul and reinstall it in its present position and keep the Lister for the Light Generator.

I remain,

Yours respectfully,

T. J. Arnall
S.F.F. Engineer, D.F.W.
Public Building,
Victoria, B. C.

Sir:

As requested in your letter of June 7th I today made an inspection of the domestic water system at St. Eugene Indian School with a view to providing additional water for fire protection. In this connection I wish to report as follows:

PRESENT SYSTEM

The existing system comprises a Fairbanks-Morse 5" x 5" triplex displacement pump driven from a line shaft by belt connection to a 16-H.P. Lister oil engine, which alternately drives the generator of the electric lighting plant. The probable capacity of the pumping plant at present is 20 to 25 gallons per minute.

The pumping plant is located in a room adjoining the boiler room, about 14 feet below ground level. A pneumatic tank, 4-1/2 feet in diameter and said to be 30 feet long, buried 14 feet in the ground outside the pump house, provides for distribution throughout the school building. The estimated available water from the pneumatic tank based on the above measurements is 1600 to 2000 gallons. The 3-inch suction pipe of the pump extends about 1200 feet, to a tank of 5000 gallons capacity near St. Mary's river, where water collects by way of a 4-inch pipeline about 3000 feet long from springs which provide a varying flow of 25 to
50 gallons per minute.

No outlets are available on the distribution line in the school for fire hose connections.

HISTORY OF DEVELOPMENT

There is little information to be obtained locally on the initiation and development of the present system prior to 1923. Sometime previous to 1923 St. Joseph's creek was abandoned as a source of supply due to contamination by sewage from the town of Cranbrook about seven miles distant, in favour of the St. Mary's river. In 1923 a new intake well and inlet from St. Mary's river was constructed.

In 1932 St. Mary's river was abandoned as a source of supply due to contamination by sewage from Kimberley and the present source (springs) was developed. At that time also a new pumping engine (now out of service) was installed. The present hook-up of engine and pump was apparently made a year or more ago and is not an efficient arrangement.

Most of the equipment although 20 years old or more appears to be serviceable. Pressure tests up to 130 lbs. within the past year indicate no weakness in the pneumatic tank, pump and connections, except the relief valve and water level indicator which do not function according to the school mechanic.

FIRE HAZARD

The value of the buildings on the school premises is probably not in excess of $110,000 of which the school alone represents more than 90%.

The principal outbuilding, a frame barn, is almost certain to be a total loss in the event of a fire within it. There are a number of other
small frame structures closer to the school building but of comparatively small value.

The school is a concrete-block building 30 years old. Danger of fire would be entirely within the building provided all unnecessary hazards were removed from the immediate vicinity.

It is very likely that the building would be a total loss if an inside fire could not be extinguished within one hour.

There are four male members of the staff ordinarily resident at or near the school who would be available in the event of a fire. An Indian rancheria at a distance of about one-quarter mile could provide some assistance and the Cranbrook fire department, I am informed by the school principal, will, and have on occasion, lent assistance.

WATER FOR FIRE PROTECTION

There are only two possible sources which will provide water in sufficient quantity for fire protection purposes without large capacity storage. These sources are St. Joseph's creek and St. Mary's river. Both streams are contaminated by sewage and a supply for fire protection purposes secured from either would require facilities independent of the works existing for domestic service.

A gravity supply from St. Joseph's creek through a pipeline about one mile in length, would provide sufficient water at 45-lbs. hydrant pressure for fire protection. Such an installation although meeting certain requirements better than any other, probably cannot be considered on account of the high cost, estimated to be $16,275.00 with complete fire equipment.
Although St. Joseph's creek passes close to the school it would not be a desirable source for a pumped supply. There would be difficulties of an assured supply during the irrigation season and probably during the winter months.

A supply obtained from the St. Mary's river by pumping would cost approximately $8800. A suitable installation would provide water under 65 lbs. hydrant pressure at a rate of 500 gallons per minute.

PUMPING PLANT FOR FIRE PROTECTION

The high cost of a pumping plant is due to the particular conditions which must be met in obtaining water from the St. Mary's river for fire purposes. Such a plant must operate instantly under all adverse conditions, otherwise the investment is wasted.

In order to provide the greatest efficiency in operation a pumping plant should be located as near the source of supply as practical. Although it would be possible to install a fire pump in the present engine room of the school I do not believe it would be desirable and the cost would not be lessened.

Possibly the best and most convenient site for a pumping plant is near the site of the old intake, where the depth of water at low stage is about 2½ feet at a distance into the stream of 60 feet, from the well. This depth is barely sufficient for protection during winter when temperature is likely to drop as low as -40° F. Ice jams are likely to occur at any point along the river for a mile or more.

A pump house requires to be sufficiently below ground level to provide protection for the machinery in an operating condition when the temperature is low and at the same time be above highwater stage.
The range between low and high stages is about 7½ feet. Such a site necessitates long intake and suction pipelines, as well as a screen chamber. The old intake well would probably be a source of trouble if used as a screen chamber as it is built on the gravel and has no bottom. I believe it would cost less to construct a new one rather than try to make the old one serviceable.

Records indicate that winter temperatures as low as -40°F may be expected and that low temperatures are likely to prevail for lengthy periods. Consequently pipelines should have a depth of cover of about 7 feet and hydrants 8 feet, as well as being suitably housed.

The present pumping plant is free from frost difficulties due to its proximity to the school heating plant. An auxiliary heating plant for a detached pump house becomes a necessity even if operated only a few times during the winter.

ALTERNATIVE SUGGESTION

It should be realized that the present water works equipment has been in service about 20 years and may require complete renewal within the next 5 or 10 years.

Under the most favourable conditions the supply from the existing plant is limited to about 50 G.P.M. and there are no means of making use of the plant capacity for fire service.

Regardless of whether a pumping plant for fire protection purposes only is to be installed now or in the future, I would recommend that the domestic plant be overhauled to make it function to its full capacity and that hydrants be installed within the school.
building, to make available, in the event of a fire, a supply of 50 gallons per minute. This is estimated to cost $1200.00. The cost of the pumping plant would be reduced by a like amount if this work is done now.

As an alternative to the fire pump installation I would suggest that when renewal of the pressure tank and suction pipe is indicated that a high level tank of 25,000 gallons capacity be substituted for the present pneumatic tank and the domestic pumping equipment be stepped up to 100 gallons per minute capacity, equipment to be housed as at present, and outside hydrants provided. Such an installation would assure a supply of 500 gallons per minute for a period of one hour and would meet the requirements of a situation the school staff are likely to be able to deal with successfully.

The cost of this suggested installation is estimated at $8700 exclusive of the cost of inside hydrants, hose and new engine. Assuming that all of the old plant will require renewal shortly at an estimated cost of $4100 the net investment for the degree of fire protection afforded would be about $6600.

While preparing this report I have not had an opportunity of making new plans to accompany it. However, all of the essential information is contained in the plans accompanying my report of March 4, 1931. Should it be necessary, detailed plans can be prepared of any or all of the proposals advanced.

Yours truly,

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill,

Re: Fire Protection, Indian Residential School, Cranbrook, B.C.

With reference to your memorandum of May 29th, this matter was referred to our Engineering and Construction Service, and for your information, I enclose copies of a memorandum from the Chief Engineer, Mr. Mills, dated August 15th, of a letter from Mr. Webb, dated July 30th, and of a report by Mr. Warren, dated June 19th.

With regard to Mr. Warren's report, it should be noted that a slight revision is necessary. Instead of 2-inch hose, it is intended to provide 1½-inch standard linen hose for use inside the school, and 2½-inch cotton rubber-lined hose for use outside, the latter being the same size as is used by the city of Cranbrook.

Mr. Warren's report discusses three possible schemes. In order to make a fair comparison of the cost of these schemes, they have been analyzed from the point of view of the capital expenditure that would be necessary in each case within the next five or ten years. Briefly, the schemes are as follows:

1. To build a pump house near the St. Mary's River, install in it a new fire pump and 60 H.P. engine together with another new 7 H.P. engine and the pump now installed in the school and supply water for fire protection from the river and for domestic use from springs, as at present, through separate mains.

This scheme would provide 500 gallons of water per minute for fire protection purposes for an indefinite period. Its cost would be -

For fire protection (immediate outlay) $8,900.
For renewal of existing installation (outlay in 5 or 10 years) $3,400.

Total $12,200.
2. When the present suction pipe and pressure tank require replacing, to eliminate the pressure tank, increase the pumping capacity to 100 gallons per minute from the present source of supply, springs, and erect a 25,000 gallon high level storage tank, the pump to be installed in the building as at present. Its cost would be -

For fire protection and domestic water supply (outlay in 5 or 10 years) $8,700.
For additional inside fire protection equipment 500.
Total $9,200.

This scheme does not contemplate any fire protection until the pressure tank needs renewal at some future time. If installed, it would provide 500 gallons of water per minute for about one hour only.

3. To increase the present pumping capacity to 50 gallons per minute, and to install inside hydrant stacks, hose, etc. This would make use of the present source of supply, springs. Its cost would be -

For fire protection and domestic water supply (immediate outlay) $1,200.
For renewal of existing installation (outlay in 5 or 10 years) $4,100.
Total $5,300.

If installed, this scheme would provide 50 gallons per minute, for possibly several hours.

Scheme No. 1 is recommended if funds can be made available. Its advantages are, that it provides a comparatively large supply of water for fire protection purposes for an indefinite period, and that the engines and pumps are in a separate building, not subject to destruction by a fire in the school building.
Scheme No. 2 is not recommended. It is comparatively expensive, would provide the same amount of water for fire protection as Scheme No. 1 - but for one hour only, and the engine and pump would be in the school building as at present, an additional fire hazard.

Scheme No. 3 is recommended only if funds for Scheme No. 1 cannot be made available in the near future. It has the advantage of immediate and total low cost, but will provide only 50 gallons per minute for possibly several hours. The engine and pumps would remain in the school building as at present, an additional fire hazard.

Would you please advise me of your wishes in this matter.

J.M. Waddell

Director.

Dear Father Forbes:

With reference to your letter of the 17th instant the Department has no objection to your securing a moving picture machine if you can do so.

Owing to lack of funds it is not possible for us, at the present time, to consider supplying moving picture machines or films. Our purpose in issuing the questionnaire was to obtain up-to-date information on the machines of this kind that are at present in residential schools, as it is our intention to carefully study the matter and as soon as finances permit we hope to be able to give favourable consideration to encouraging visual education by supplying films and possibly purchasing some machines. Memorandum:

ACTING DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

Re: Purchase order No. 5746, Feb. 24, 1941.

The above covered the supplying and installation at the Kootenay Indian Residential School of a new lighting plant. The business was given to the Modern Electric, Cranbrook, B.C. I am today in receipt of a letter from the Principal of the Kootenay School, dated March 10, which reads in part as follows:

"I regret to have to state that the new Diesel engine supplied by the Indian Affairs Branch only about a year ago is not giving complete satisfaction and has had to be repaired twice. A complete job was not done the first time and a second repair job was finished yesterday after we had been without lights for over a week. This job does not appear to have fully remedied the trouble. This was reported to the Indian Agent this morning."

I am communicating with the Principal with regard to this matter and on receipt of his reply you will be further advised. In the meantime I thought it advisable to bring the matter to your attention.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Ottawa,
March 17, 1942.

AIR MAIL

Dear Sir:

I am today in receipt of a letter from Reverend Father Forbes, Principal of the Kootenay Residential School, in which he points out that the new Diesel engine purchased by the Department in February, 1941, is not giving satisfaction. The Principal states that he has had to have it repaired twice. The last repair job was only completed on the 9th instant, after the school had been without lights for over a week. He further advises that this latter repair job does not appear to have remedied the trouble.

I was very much concerned at receiving this report. The equipment that was installed should operate in good order for many years. It was supplied by the Modern Electric, Cranbrook, B.C.

Has this firm done the repair work to which the Principal refers in his letter? Have you interviewed them and ascertained why this installation is not operating satisfactorily? I would like to have a complete report from them regarding the installation and the reason for its failing to function in the proper manner. I presume that the engineer at the school is fully qualified to handle the equipment that the Department has supplied.

I should appreciate an early reply to this letter, a copy of which is being sent to the Principal.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

REPORT ON 7 H. P. ATOMIC PETTER ENGINE FROM CRANBROOK SCHOOL.

The above Engine has been torn down and inspected and condition is as follows:

Crankshaft bearing surfaces are badly cut up and should be re-finished and ground.
(We were asked to supply a new Crankshaft but this is not available and with an old Engine would not recommend this large expenditure, and believe a good job can be made by grinding as stated above.)

Cylinder - this found to be .026" over size, therefore, will require re-boring.

Piston - this badly scored and, of course, will have to be replaced after cylinder is re-bored.

Piston pin and Rings will have to be replaced.

Nozzle holding down studs in cylinder head have been welded and should be replaced.

Main Bearings in poor shape but can be re-babbitted to fit re-ground shaft.

Connecting Rod Bearing same as main bearings.

Oil gauge feed glasses required.

Connecting Rod lower end bearing to be re-babbitted.

Fuel Pump to be repaired or replaced.

Fuel Nozzle same as above.

Gaskets - new throughout.

Cylinder head has been welded on the outside; to be tested under pressure and believe can be used again.

Sundry material, studs, nuts, etc. required.

Dear Sir:

Re: Engine Cranbrook School.

In accordance with your instructions our Diesel mechanic has made an inspection of the above Engine and we enclose herewith a copy of his report.

When we first received inquiries regarding this Engine it was suggested that a new crankshaft be supplied, but as this old engine has operated for many years we do not think the expense of a new crankshaft would be justified and it would be difficult to get, and we expect to make satisfactory repair by re-grinding this shaft and refitting the bearings to suit. We give below an estimate of this work, and after re-fitting the engine should continue to give you satisfactory service for a considerable time as this overhaul will cover all the main working parts.

This size of engine is no longer made and the nearest we have in stock at the present time is a 10 H. P. Engine which sells for $592.00, and at time of writing we have only one on hand. We quote as follows:

Dear Sir:

We are presenting herewith a report on the Diesel equipment purchased from us last year. This unit was a 16 H.P. Lister Diesel and was belt coupled to your generator at the Kootenay Residential School. It was placed in service on March 27/41.

At the time of installation everything was done to make a first class job. The units were placed on an exceptionally solid foundation, properly secured and neatly finished and painted. The engine operated excellently and handled the total load with ease. We had a representative of our supplier (Bruce Robinson Electric, Calgary) call and check the installation in order to be sure that no detail had been overlooked. He expressed himself as well satisfied with the job and cautioned that the correct type of oil be used at all times. To cover this we had Bruce Robinson Electric write the principal of the school on April 17/41 advising him of the type and grade of oil that would guarantee continued performance.

Some three months after completing the installation the operator complained of a leaky head gasket and fuel line. We immediately obtained these parts for him and when we delivered them we noticed the engine covered with dirt and oil and the whole installation showed every sign of lack of attention. We took it upon ourselves to send a workman down to the school and completely clean the job over again. We also asked the operator to keep the engine in proper condition. The oil filter was extremely dirty and we ordered two replacements by long distance phone in order that this important detail could be attended to at once. These replacement filters were received and delivered within twenty-four hours.

We heard no more from the job until October. The operator called at our shop and mentioned that he was going to have a diesel mechanic look at the engine as there was a 'knock' in it. We were immediately concerned and very surprised that a complaint was not made to us at once. We went at once to the school with a first class mechanic to investigate. We found that a connecting rod bearing had completely burned out and that the other bearings were quite loose. The cause of the bearing failure we found the engine sumps were so filled with heavy slimy sludge that the oil pump intake was completely blocked.
MODERN ELECTRIC

Electrical Merchandise and Contracting

CRANBROOK, B.C.

The oil filter was completely saturated with filth and incapable of performing its function. A new replacement filter was lying unopened on the shelf.

This sludge could not possibly have formed to this extent short of several weeks. Had ever reasonable care been given this engine its presence would have been detected and crank case would have been cleaned long before any damage could result. Further if sludge was consistently forming we should have been notified and an investigation would have been promptly made.

We checked at once on the oil used and a sample was taken. Our supplier informs us that it is of a type entirely unsuitable for this work. It emulsifies due to a slight condensation formed in the crank case on cold starting and forms a sludge. We cannot understand why an incorrect oil was used despite our having a special letter sent to the school recommending the proper type. (We might say in passing that since the repairs were made and the correct oil used there is not a trace of sludge to be found.)

We obtained a new set of connecting rod shell bearings by phone but were unable to obtain any other parts from the same source. As the school needed the engine at once we had the mechanic install the new connecting rod shells only. He was unable to make a first class job of this as the operator had at some time previous to this experienced trouble and had filed the connecting rod cap in an effort to lighten the burned bearing. This was admitted to the mechanic by the operator after that it was apparent that it could not be concealed. The new precision shells could not be held in place by a cap that had been filed out of shape. We wish to point out at this time that it is unreasonable to assume that an operator of an engine would go to the great trouble of removing and filing a bearing cap if he had a just reason to complain about an engine under guarantee.

We obtained and kept in stock for many weeks the parts necessary to put this engine in good condition. We did not receive however an order from the school to have this work done.

When it was necessary to overhaul the engine properly a short time ago we removed the crankshaft and had the crank throw bearings precision ground to a standard size. This was necessary as the throw bearings had been scored by the burned bearing shells. Without this consistent trouble would have been the result.

The engine is now in good shape and operating properly. It will not continue to operate unless it is given proper attention. An operating instruction book was supplied at the time of the installation. If this is followed the engine will perform excellently as several others of the same design are doing in this district. The engine must be kept clean at all times above all else.
MODERN ELECTRIC
Electrical Merchandise and Contracting
CRANBROOK, B.C.

The filthy conditions under which this engine has been operated in the past will only cause further failure. We will at any time do anything possible to help this unit give service and satisfaction. We cannot however be responsible for failure when instructions are ignored.

Yours very truly,

COTENAY INDIAN SCHOOL
CRANBROOK, B.C.

Dear Mr. [Name],

You may recall that you recently sent me the latest report on the status to which the new diesel engine had been submitted. According to the latest report, the costly breakdown was due to the carelessness and lack of cleanliness of the operator and, ultimately, to the oil used—according to the report on which you based your covering letter, a representative of the suppliers had O.K.'d the installation of the fault was all ours—

I went into his office but did not get far—I wrote to the suppliers & asked what qualifications his representatives had to examine the installation & declare it excellent. That was several weeks ago—so far, no supplier has not replied—That makes me suspicious—In another School, a "representative" called to check upon our boiler plant. It turned out that he was only a sales agent & knew nothing of the boiler plant—I had similar experience here with the partial rewiring of the School—

It is possible that the representative who called in really competent but, to date, his company has not be—

Stalled the engine (a really competent man), the Indian agent, the operator himself. The meeting was to have been held on Monday. The operator & I were here but no one came. After two days later, the gentleman who mistook the agent came and the operator was absent.

At the meeting, Mr. Ward, who installed the engine, repeated that he faulted Warden to the oil and it's to the incompetence or negligence of the operator. It would take a long letter to go into all the details. If you wish to know them, you can get in touch with me by phoning St. Joseph's Rotary, Ottawa, on June 1st as I shall be there.

I knew nothing of Diesels but I do know that it is hard to get at the bottom of this matter. Statements alleged have been made by others, some are denied by those who are said to have made them.

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing receipts (5) and an itemized bill recently received from Patmore Bros. I would greatly appreciate it if the Department would refund this money.

Would you please mention to the Department that I am fully aware that they insist that a Principal should have no work done, unless he pays for it, until he has received permission from the Department. In the present case, the state of the Pupils' Toilets (and two others) of some pipes and sinks, was called to my attention less than a week before the opening of school, and there was no time to write to Ottawa and get a reply before school opened. Several Toilets could not be used, and others were used only through make-shift arrangements. Patmore Bros sent out a good man—for the work he did, I expected that his bill would be higher than it is.

I have written to Dr. MacQuarrie as you suggested, about the Travelling Clinic, and I have taken the occasion to give him a health report on the school, which is favorable.

I regret to have to report that Patrick Moses met with an accident just before supper. He and other boys had just brought in a load of hay. Mr. Townsend was by the load of hay outside the barn, and had just had it pulled up. As Patrick is the boy he trusts most, he sent Patrick up to the loft to see that all went well. As the Carrier was taking the hay to the back of the loft Patrick appears to have decided to take a ride by holding on to the cable. He fell, or jumped, missed the hay and hit the floor. I fear that he has a badly broken leg or ankle. He was immediately taken to the hospital after the hospital and Doctor has been asked to meet him on his arrival. I have notified his Father.

Dear Sir:

Unless I am mistaken, there is still in Ottawa some of the grant made for repairs at this School. I would recommend that this money be used for the following purposes:

(1) Certain rooms, such as the Disciplinarian's, the Sisters', the Chapel, some halls, etc., are very cold owing chiefly to poorly fitting windows and doors. In some of these rooms, water freezes. After an experiment I would suggest that all windows and doors be fitted with weather-strip. "Ladore" weather-strip has proved the best and most lasting. It will take a little less than 4000' and will cost 4 cents per foot less a small reduction which will more than pay for tacks. It would cost less if it could be bought wholesale, but this is impossible at present. McLennan, McFeeley & Prior of Vancouver inform me that they have had it on order for a long time, but have been unable to get any and they do not know if or when they will be able to get any. On account of danger to health (colds, pneumonia which may result from the cold and drafts coming through the doors and windows) I have taken it upon myself to buy up as much of Ladore weather-strip as possible (about 1000' feet to date) locally, and to ask the local Hardware stores (Parks, Hewre, Coy, McBrides) to try to pick up the balance. Prior to doing so, I asked McLennan McFeeley & Prior for a quotation so as to submit it to the Department. When they replied that they had none and had been unable to get any and could neither quote on it or guarantee to supply any, I bought up as much as I could and trust that the Department will approve of my action and pay for the weather-strip out of the money on hand.

(2) There will not be sufficient money to make all the repairs needed on the barn—reshingling, repainting, renewing half of the floor, replacing practically all the storm windows etc. (Some or all of these things were seen to be necessary by the Commissioner, Mr. Doucet and Captain Barry individually or collectively.) There will not be enough money for all of this but I would suggest doors for the Barn. The two large doors in the Hay-loft (about 16' by 14') have been missing for years. They are, and must be sliding doors and it is for them that most of the Hardware mentioned below is required. Some small doors are also missing in the Hay-loft, and two large double doors as well as two smaller doors (about 7' x 3½') require a little repair work in the barn proper.

At no expense to the Department, I have had nearly 100 panes of glass put into the windows of the barn, but even with this and with work done on the doors of the barn, it is very cold in the barn. This is no good either for the boys who milk early in the morning, or for the cows. I would submit, that even if it did take $50.00 or $100.00 more that remains of the appropriation, this money would be well spent; there would be more milk (all of which is used here) and the boys milking would not have to go...
from their beds into a cold barn. This Barn by the way is Government property. All work, of course, would be done by the School.

With regard to the costs:

(1) The Ledore weather-strip will cost approximately 4 cents per foot, or a very little less. I got 250' at 3 cents.

(2) The doors:

Dear Mr. Shelton,

You may recall that, when I was in Ottawa, you asked me about the condition of this school building and that I told you that the plaster was badly damaged in two (and somewhere in a third dormitory) areas. I am not going to exaggerate this, but I can say that, in the main girls' dormitory, there is a competent man who can assure us that the plaster may fall on anyone at any time. It will fall in this or another dormitory at any time but not on people. Remembering your request, I made inquiries through the local council. I made inquiries through the local council. It is a metal roof in Cranbrook that has been removed. His verdict was that a "Crest Architect," Mr. Murray, had nothing to do with the fall of the plaster and designed the building and that he did not want the job because he could not guarantee success. He went back with his Indian agent friend as I did not want to take the responsibility of having a man do a job which he would not guarantee. (By the way, my job of accompanying the boys over the engineering was good.)
To the man who put the log on the School—a Mr. Lundy. He removed this day less than a quarter of an inch. The cost of it, I understand, about $100. It looks like it will come. I have let Mr. Drivin do what he can. I shall be glad to hear from you.

About a month ago, the Inspector of Indian Affairs, Mr. Coleman, was here. I spoke to him & Mr. Drivin about the roof, & they looked over it. Mr. Coleman suggested that I get in touch with the French people who own the roofs, free of charge, I understand, and exact nothing more although they would like to humour me. I wrote to these people and mentioned Mr. Coleman's name. They got in touch with him & came last night—I know what a report they will send, although it may be more clever than I expect. Besides, the leak of which I spoke (due to faulty architecture,—a valley which back up water), they found (& I know that it is true) some rust. The cost of repairs will be heavy, but you have a big investment here. Moreover, but this is a minor point, which I have mentioned before, several years ago, an earthquake made certain cracks in the building & damaged the entrance step.

I am not exactly rolling in wealth, but if you will supply milk & about five gallons of whale oil for the barn, I'll have the barn painted, without cost to you. Also, if you will have the roof of the school (including Lundy's portion) done—Mr. Drivin, Ed. Johnson.
July 13, 1943.

Rev. G. Forbes, O.M.I.
Principal, Kootenay Indian Res. School,
Cranbrook, B.C.

Dear Father Forbes:

I have your letter of the 7th instant with reference to the condition of the roof of the Kootenay Indian School.

I am sorry to learn that the roof of the engine room is not satisfactory. In a letter received from you in Nov. 1942 you stated that this roof was working properly.

As you were previously advised the amount of $1000.00 was included in the current year's appropriation for repairs and improvements for the Kootenay School.

In a letter of April 14, 1943 Indian Agent Irwin was instructed to forward to Indian Commissioner MacKay an account covering the cost of shingles and lumber which you purchased. We promised at that time that we would allow $500.00 towards the amount which you expended. As this account has not been submitted for payment apparently the Indian Agent has neglected to submit it to the Commissioner.

I note from your letter that we will likely hear from the Indian Commissioner's office regarding the roof. When this report is received it will receive careful attention. Possibly the condition of the roof is due to bad architecture. At the same time it must be realized that this building was built several years ago and in the meantime our records do not disclose any heavy expenditure on the roof.

Kind personal regards,

We hereby submit quotations on the necessary repairs to the roof and gutters on the Kootenay Industrial School at the St. Eugene Mission.

#1 Flat roof over Boiler Room 260.00

I am informed that the various roofs of Cranbrook Indian Residential School are in urgent need of repair as leaks have developed that are damaging the interior of the building. The flat roof over the boiler room is about 30 feet below the overhanging eave of the main roof on which icicles form in the winter and fall on to the boiler room roof with considerable force. An attempt has been made to overcome this by roofing this portion of the roof with metal but it has not been entirely successful as the pounding has broken the joints of the metal. Also, the felt on the rest of this roof has buckled pretty badly and needs attention. The cost of this particular job would amount to $260.00. It is also proposed to lay a wooden walk on the portion bombarded by icicles but this could be carried out by the school staff.

Various repairs to the chapel roof would amount to $98.00 and a similar amount for the repairs to the flat deck on the main roof, including flashing and painting. The main roof was constructed with deep valleys at both ends of the building and these accumulate snow that causes water to back up above the flashings and penetrate the building with considerable damage to the plaster, and will, no doubt, in time rot the roof rafters and trusses. Various attempts have been made to correct this trouble without success and apparently the only remedy is to reduce the angle of the valleys by making a false bottom. The cost of this work would amount to $655.00, or a total of $1,111.00 for the entire job which would be carried out by Messrs.
Patmore Brothers of Cranbrook under the supervision of Messrs. Fred. M. Beatty (Tremco Western) Limited, who are experts on roofing problems. I enclose herewith Messrs. Patmore Brothers' quotation and would request advice as to whether funds are likely to become available during the coming year for these repairs in whole or in part.

Dear Sir:

Although you know all the facts, I believe that the Department will appreciate it if I repeat the whole story.

1-The barn (Government-owned). When I came here over two years ago, I noted that the barn needed re-shingling, that the large doors in the loft were missing, that the window frames and panes were in bad shape and that the whole barn needed repainting. The Commissioner, the Inspector, Mr. Doucet and you agreed with me, unless I am greatly mistaken, that these things needed immediate attention as could be given them.

The roof has been reshingled and painted and the doors for the loft have been made here. New window panes have been put in but I have not had the money to attend to the window frames.

Father Anthony, a competent carpenter, did the above work with the help of some older boys as part of their manual training. He finds that the walls need to be repainted.

As the next item is of major importance, I think that we can do the rest of the work on the barn without financial assistance from the Department except perhaps for the paint which will cost about $200.00. It is quite possible that no assistance will be required in purchasing the paint (for the walls; the roof has been painted at no cost to the Department) but I am not absolutely sure of this. There is no charge for Father Anthony's work.

2-The School building.

A/The furnace, boiler and engine room. This is an addition to the original school building—a deep basement behind the school with a roof about 8' above the ground. It is no exaggeration to say that this roof leaked like a sieve last year, so that during a rain storm, water poured on the engines, etc. At my request, the Department had this roof repaired a little over a year ago at a cost of a little over $200.00. By Spring (1943) that roof was practically in as bad condition as it was before Mr. Lundy repaired it.

I showed the roof to Mr. Inspector Coleman and he suggested that I get in touch with the Tremco Co. as they are experts in roofs and as they examine roofs and offer their suggestions free of charge—although, of course, they appreciate being given the work. I mentioned the roof of the main building to Mr. Coleman but, evidently, I did not speak clearly and he appears to have been and to be under the impression that I was speaking only of the boiler room roof.

B/While in Ottawa, in the Spring, I called upon some of the members of the Indian Department and, in reply to a question about the condition of the School building, I mentioned—

The roof of the main building. I drew such a picture of this leaky roof and of the damage being done to the plaster in the dormitories (and likely to the rafters, etc.) that, if I understood the gentleman to whom I was talking, he said that this was a matter to which immediate attention should be given. As we could not plaster the dormitories while the pupils are here and...
as the roof is steep enough to shed rain, I decided to do nothing until the holidays.

A local man looked at the roof but was not interested. He said that the roof was constructed for the Coast and that, although he could put sheet metal in the valleys, he could not guarantee that this would stop the leaks.

The trouble is this. There are two main and four secondary valleys in which the snow lodges because they are deep. When the heat under the roof melts this snow, the water runs to the edge of the roof where the first of it freezes and forms a wall of ice from one to two feet thick over the edge of the roof. This is because the roof projects for two or three beyond the walls and the cold air under this projection freezes the melted snow. When another thaw occurs, the water runs towards the edge of the roof but cannot run off because it is blocked by the wall of ice. It, therefore, backs up under the metal shingles and runs down into the dormitories, wetting the plaster ceiling and walls and, also, I presume, rotting the rafters, etc.

As stated, Mr. Coleman appears not to have understood me when I mentioned this matter and believed that I was talking only about the boiler-room roof. However, thanks to him, the Tremco people sent two really good men who, with myself, went up to the roof where they spent between one and two hours examining the whole roof. They appeared to know their business because they suggested a solution: The cause of the trouble is that the valleys are too deep; the solution is to build these valleys up. To put sheet metal in the valleys would do no good because it would not prevent the wall of ice at the edge of the roof.

They found that the metal sheeting, used in place of metal shingles on two raised parts of the roof, had almost rusted through and needed renewing. They said that this was not extraordinary and was due to the age of the sheeting. They said that these new sheets should be painted with a special paint. (In fact, they said that the whole roof should be painted with this paint but added that this could be put off for a year and go into next year's estimates).

They found that the leak over the Junior girls' dormitory could easily be repaired but I forget the details. I believe that it is just a case of the wearing-away of shingles around one of the ventilators.

I saw nothing concerning this matter in the short itemized bill but they said that they would drive in the nails which have worked up (as nails do in such roofs) on the roof and that a new ridge board, on the top of the roof should be put in. (I forget who it was but someone told me that part of the trouble was that the nails originally used were too short. There may be some truth in that if we judge by the way in which the builders skimped on material in other parts of the building. However, I have seen nails drawn out of such roofs by the weather as, for instance, in the Cariboo School.)

And now, the same building but another roof. Ice formed on the chapel roof, this Spring, (that is along the edges), forced the melted snow back under the metal shingles and this melted snow ran down inside the walls. We have not opened the walls to see what damage was done to the wood inside the walls but part of this water escaped through the window casings into the chapel.

Either the Commissioner or the Inspector asked me to state which of these repair jobs I considered the most urgent and I replied that, if
we wish to save the wooden frame work or rather the rafters, beams, wood inside the walls, every item is urgent in so far as the roof on the main building is concerned. It is evident that it is urgent to keep a real, steady shower of rain off the furnaces, Lister and Otto engines, etc. (As stated, the main roof does not leak from rain, as the rain runs off, but the practically flat boiler-room does leak in the rain).

These two roofs need attention before the snow falls. The engines should be protected (boiler-room roof) and the children should be protected from a piece of plaster; a big piece of plaster, which may fall on them in their beds if more melted snow gets in and loosens these pieces more than they are loosened now. For the protection of the pupils and the engines, these two jobs are very urgent.

The chapel roof is urgent only in the sense that the wood work is being damaged. There is no danger to the children as the leaks are along or inside the walls. However, as this forms only a slight part of the bill, it might pay to have it done when the men are here.

The quotation given me:

1-Roof over engine room --------------------- $260.00
2-Roof of main building-
Two #1 (large) valleys and four #2 (lesser) valleys --------------------- $665.00
Sheeting and painting flat decks (i.e., raised parts of this roof) --------------------- $98.00

3-Chapel roof --------------------- $98.00

When the Tremco people figured out the cost, while they were here, I said that, if the work were done, as I asked, during the holidays, I would furnish board and room for two or three men. That would help cut down costs. As the pupils are now back, it may be impossible to furnish rooms but I might be able to let these men sleep in a recreation hall, all in the one hall. This may not be necessary as the Tremco people appear to have arranged with a local firm to do the work under the control of the Tremco Co.

Why was this not done sooner? I do not know. During my first winter here, there was little cold or snow and no leakage reported to me. A certain amount of leakage seems to have been expected. Last winter, my second, I noticed the considerable leakage and began asking for advice and costs.

I think that that is all except that it is not only the water from the snow in the valleys on the main roof which causes trouble but also the melted snow from other parts of the roof which drains into these valleys.

Yours truly,

P.S. I have not asked for a quote on plastering party of the dormitories (2). This should not be very expensive and it should be done during the holidays. If the department wanted it done immediately, I could move our dormitory at a time into a recreation hall.

You will recall that a Lister Diesel engine was installed in the Kootenay Residential School in February, 1941, at a cost of approximately $1500.00. A review of the correspondence indicates that the Principal at that time, Father Collins, did not want this type of machine, but about that time Father Forbes was placed in charge of the school and he accepted it. You will also remember that ever since it was installed we have had correspondence indicating that it was not satisfactory and quite recently we authorized an amount of $375.00 for repairs to the Otto engine.

Father Forbes is in Ottawa this week and Mr. Phelan interviewed him this morning and he again brought up the question of this engine. May I also quote from a letter recently received from Father Forbes:

"From the beginning there was trouble with the Diesel engine. I need not go into details. The company which installed it blamed the trouble ultimately on the fact that we had not used the oil ordered in their instruction book. That is true. We did not use that oil until after the first breakdown. We used it after that and have had breakdown after breakdown ever since. A year ago, after some appeals, I got permission to have an independent, competent man examine the engine. He found the cylinder had cracked. It was sent to Vancouver one year ago and we have received no replacement since. What I was told is true; you cannot expect Diesel parts until after the war."
It is difficult for the Department to understand why this machine has not worked properly. Possibly it is due to faulty installation or, on the other hand, it may be the fault of the school engineer. However, I feel that the matter should not be allowed to go on in the manner it has in the past two years. You should have a competent man examine this machine thoroughly and let us know exactly where the fault lies. Possibly Mr. Arnall could do this, but, if not, you may be able to arrange for someone else. Of course, the point to keep in mind is that it should be a person thoroughly familiar with this type of engine. We have had Lister Diesel engines installed at other schools and have had practically no trouble with them and in addition the cost of their operation is much less than that of engines operated by gasoline. I feel too that this is an opportunity for us to obtain definite information on the operation of this type of engine and consequently would appreciate your arranging to have a very complete report forwarded, so that we would have explicit information available in the event of this type of engine causing trouble at any other school.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Mrs. Haey:

I wish to thank the Department for the extra grant which I have just received from Mr. Justice S. Cannell.

I regret to state that, yesterday (11/4), four young girls (aged 9, 10, 11) deliberately tried to set the school on fire. Their only explanation is that they wanted to burn the school down. Great credit is due to two young pupils (Anthony Jacobs and Monica Nicholas) who, seeing the fire, immediately reported it. I had the big school bell rung and that brought three Indians (Pat and Melchior Barnaby and Philip Cassim) as well as the employees who were off duty at the noon hour. These men, the local Oblate, and the older boys did good, intelligent work and the
fire was prevented from spreading to the main building through a door from the woodshed which, with the wood in it, was fire.

It was a good fire drill and showed that the fire extinguishers on hand are inadequate to put out a fire that has a good start. We were able to use the hose (used for flooding the river) and this hose prevented serious damage.

The actual loss is about $75.00. For a time it looked as if we could not keep the fire building but we really hard & courageous work done by the staff, 3 Indians (older boys) saved the day.

Staff, 3 Indians (older boys) saved the day.

Unless it is not customary to do so, I would suggest that the department might express its appreciation to pupils Anthony Jacobs and Monica Francis for immediately reporting the fire.

A word praising the good work of the Indians would not be amiss.

Collective letter would do - They fought that fire.

In his recent report on the School, I believe that the Inspector of Schools has recommended a "long" bare t-shirt for the Indians.

Our "hose" was sufficient distance because pipes & couplings - Our "hose" was sufficient distance because the fire was noticed on time and because the extinguishers proved a real "first aid" test that is all.

Discipline was good. Those who actually engaged in fighting the fire remained at a safe distance. These young boys, fasting their battle, just on their drawers & got out of the building - The weather was very warm. I have been here 3 years and 2 days - For 3 yrs some day School was the strap.

Yours Truly, P. FOWLER

Memorandum For-
D. M. Mackay, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Vancouver, B.C.

Re: Engines Cranbrook Residential School.

In accordance with your request I made a careful examination of the engine and boiler room situation at Cranbrook Indian Residential School and concluded that practically all of the complaints received from the Reverend Principal are due to inadequate maintenance and faulty operation, and also pointed out to the Indian Agent, Principal and Engineer that the poor housekeeping in this Department created a serious fire hazard.

The equipment is as follows:

Boiler Room:
1-No. 1869, Left hand-60 H.P. wood burning hand fed.
1-No. 1870, Right hand-60 H.P. wood burning hand fed.
1-No. 44850, 25.3 H.P. Vertical Tubular.

Engine Room:
1-Old Otto horizontal gas engine (supplied with new parts recently.)
1-7 H.P. Petters Diesel Engine (recently overhauled in Vancouver.)
1-16 H.P. 2 cylinder Lister Diesel Engine (cylinder head cracked and engine out of commission for 13 months awaiting shipment of spare parts from England to Vancouver.)
1-10 KW Generator (on Otto or Lister Engines.)
1-4 KW Generator (on Petters Engine.)
1-Water pump. (on Petters Engine.)
1-15 H.P. Vertical Steam Engine (apparently not in use.)
1-Old Compressor. (apparently not in use.)
1-Set 110 Volt storage batteries.
1-Large cooling tank (on Lister & Otto.)
1-New lime shaft & hangers, (supplied 2 years ago at request of Principal and not yet installed.)
Numerous tools scattered over engine room and on bench.

(over)
Both the engine and boiler rooms were dark and in need of repainting. Exit is by a very small door in the engine room, and two small doors out of the boiler room, (one to the interior of the school and the other to the outside). Some of the electrical wiring is in poor condition and the light switch inside the entrance to the engine room was hanging out of the metal box. The floor of the engine room was oil soaked.

The Department had requested the Commissioner to have the above plant visited by a competent Diesel engineer and an effort was made to locate one in Vancouver, without success as these men are scarce and not available to devote nearly a week to visit Cranbrook. As one did not arrive I made local enquiry and found that a Caterpillar Tractor Company had recently placed a diesel expert in Cranbrook for the maintenance of their diesel equipment in the district, and he was highly recommended by those in the locality whose judgment could be expected to be reliable. I interviewed him with a request that he examine and advise us on the situation and his report of the 16th instant is enclosed herewith. (No copy has been given to the Rev. Principal.)

From this report it will be observed that:

1. He attributes the trouble with the engines to faulty maintenance.
2. Offers suggestions for the proper conditioning of the three internal combustion engines.
3. Suggests making all these engines alternately available by installation of an overhead line shaft.
4. Calls attention to the fire hazard due to oil on the floor.
5. Recommends a cleaning and painting up of the engine room and increased light and improve cleanliness.
6. Recommends periodical check of the plant by a competent person. With all of which I concur.

As there is a 25.3 h.p. boiler in use in the plant, and I understand Provincial Regulations call for an operator with Engineer's Certificate for boilers over 15 h.p., I questioned Mr. Townsend, the person attending to the engine room plant, as to his standing; in this respect and he advised that he held no such certificates, but that the Dominion Department of Public Works Boiler Inspector, Mr. Arnall had informed him that he did not require them and that he, Mr. Arnall, would assume any responsibility in the matter. In reply to my questioning Mr. Townsend stated that he was not the only person handling the boilers and if he was absent working on the school farm, which constitutes the bulk of his work, some other person was just as likely to start a fire in the vertical high pressure boiler, possibly after he had drained it, creating a serious explosion hazard.

(over)
I am informed that regulations do not permit of paying a fourth class engineer less than 50¢ an hour. The probability is that the school with only eighty-three pupils is not in a financial position to employ competent engineering help, or permit him to devote the minimum time necessary for the proper performance of his duties, thus endangering the school by both explosion and fire. In the event of loss of life due to the operation of this plant and lack of minimum Provincial requirements on the part of the operator the Department might incur considerable criticism. I am reporting separately on the school as a whole.

The recommendations in this connection are obvious and do not require summarizing.

Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Granbrook B.C.
February 16th 1944

Department of Indian Affairs:

Have been called in to inspect the Diesel equipment and other engines room installations being used to take care of the power requirements of this institution and report on their mechanical condition.

The two cylinder 15 H.P. four stroke cycle Lister Diesel engine which has been set up to drive the main load (10 KW Westinghouse generator) is out of order. This engine requires a cylinder head which I understand has been on order for 13 months. The true condition of this engine can only be determined by dismantling for inspection, but from interviewing the operator and talking with the mechanic who has been in close touch with this piece of equipment since delivery, I gather it has been idle awaiting repairs a great deal more than it has been working. Judging from the usual service these engines give under normal operating conditions together with the impression I have received from the appearance of the engine room and engines, I would offer to suggest that most of this trouble can be attributed to faulty maintenance either due to lack of time or knowledge and interest in this type of equipment. The results have been costly.

In order to put this engine back to work, it would be necessary to install the new head with all necessary gaskets and seals, check the condition of the fuel injection equipment for:

a. Proper fuel injection pressure.
b. Proper fuel injection timing for output of maximum H.P.
c. Check fuel filter system also proper handling of the fuel oil.

The entire engine should be thoroughly cleaned out, the main and connecting rod bearings checked for clearance. The proper lubricating oil should be put on the job and a periodical check made on the servicing of this engine by someone who understands how important it is to carry out instructions of maintenance laid down by the manufacturer.

A 7 H.P. Petters full Diesel is used to drive a water pump which is used to pump water from the river into a pressure storage tank for house use. A 4 KW generator is set up near this engine so it may be used in case of emergency. I understand considerable work has been done on this engine but at the present, the fuel injection valve seems to be cracked thus allowing considerable fuel to leak onto the surface of the cylinder head and run down on the floor. Considerable lubricating oil appears to be leaking by the main bearings and adding to the grease and oil on the floor. This engine is not used a great deal but would be in very good repair if cleaned up and the two items mentioned were fixed.

1-16 H.P. 2 cylinder Lister Diesel Engine (cylinder head cracked and engine out of commission for 13 months awaiting shipment of spare parts from England to Vancouver.)
1-10 KW Generator (on Otto or Lister Engines.)
1-4 KW Generator (on Petters Engine.)
1-Water pump. (on Petters Engine.)
1-15 H.P. Vertical Steam Engine (apparently not in use.)
1-Old Compressor. (apparently not in use.)
1-Set 110 Volt storage batteries.
1-Large cooling tank (on Lister & Otto.)
1-New lime shaft & hangers, (supplied 2 years ago at request of Principal and not yet installed.)
Numerous tools scattered over engine room and on bench.

(over)
Both the engine and boiler rooms were dark and in need of repainting. Exit is by a very small door in the engine room, and two small doors out of the boiler room, (one to the interior of the school and the other to the outside). Some of the electrical wiring is in poor condition and the light switch inside the entrance to the engine room was hanging out of the metal box. The floor of the engine room was oil soaked.

The Department had requested the Commissioner to have the above plant visited by a competent Diesel Engineer and an effort was made to locate one in Vancouver, without success as these men are scarce and not available to devote nearly a week to visit Cranbrook. As one did not arrive I made local enquiry and found that a Caterpillar Tractor Company had recently placed a diesel expert in Cranbrook for the maintenance of their diesel equipment in the district, and he was highly recommended by those in the locality whose judgment could be expected to be reliable, I interviewed him with a request that he examine and advise us on the situation and his report of the 16th instant is enclosed herewith. (No copy has been given to the Rev. Principal.)

From this report it will be observed that:

1. He attributes the trouble with the engines to faulty maintenance.
2. Offers suggestions for the proper conditioning of the three internal combustion engines.
3. Suggests making all these engines alternately available by installation of an overhead line shaft.
4. Calls attention to the fire hazard due to oil on the floor.
5. Recommends a cleaning and painting up of the engine room and increased light and improve cleanliness.
6. Recommends periodical check of the plant by a competent person. With all of which I concur.

As there is a 25.3 h.p. boiler in use in the plant, and I understand Provincial Regulations call for an operator with Engineer's Certificate for boilers over 15 h.p., I questioned Mr. Townsend, the person attending to the engine room plant, as to his standing in this respect and he advised that he held no such certificates, but that the Dominion Department of Public Works Boiler Inspector, Mr. Arnall had informed him that he did not require them and that he, Mr. Arnall, would assume any responsibility in the matter. In reply to my questioning Mr. Townsend stated that he was not the only person handling the boilers and if he was absent working on the school farm, which constitutes the bulk of his work, some other person was just as likely to start a fire in the vertical high pressure boiler, possibly after he had drained it, creating a serious explosion hazard.

(over)
I am informed that regulations do not permit of paying a fourth class engineer less than 50¢ an hour. The probability is that the school with only eighty-three pupils is not in a financial position to employ competent engineering help, or permit him to devote the minimum time necessary for the proper performance of his duties, thus endangering the school by both explosion and fire. In the event of loss of life due to the operation of this plant and lack of minimum Provincial requirements on the part of the operator the Department might incur considerable criticism. I am reporting separately on the school as a whole.

The recommendations in this connection are obvious and do not require summarizing.

Inspector of Indian Agencies.
March 17, 1944.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Your File 155-0-5

I have to refer to your letter of December 16, 1943, authorizing the employment of a competent diesel engineer to examine the engines at the Cranbrook Residential School.

Failing to secure the services required in Vancouver, I requested Mr. Inspector Coleman while in Cranbrook in connection with the status investigation of the St. Mary's Band, to make a careful examination of the plant and endeavour to secure the services of an experienced engineer in Cranbrook or district to look over the equipment for us and bring in a report. Fortunately, Mr. Coleman was able to arrange with Mr. A. G. Bayes, a diesel engineer in the employ of the Caterpillar Tractor Company and now stationed at Cranbrook, to make a careful examination of the plant. Mr. Bayes' report is enclosed herewith, together with a memorandum from Mr. Coleman on his own examination of the engines and boiler room.

It will be observed that Mr. Coleman maintains that practically all the complaints received from the Reverend Principal are due to inadequate maintenance and faulty operation of the equipment. The other points brought out by the Inspector may be summarized as follows:

1. Poor housekeeping in the engine room has created a serious fire hazard.
2. Absence of proper arrangements for the care of tools, these being scattered over the engine room.
3. A new line shaft and hangers supplied two years ago at the request of the Principal have not yet been installed.
4. Engine room badly in need of painting.
5. Floor of engine room oil soaked.

Mr. Coleman attributes much of the trouble to lack (over)
of qualifications on the part of the engineer and the fact that he does not spend more than one hour per day looking after the engines and boilers, being employed at various chores around the barn and buildings which take up the rest of his time. It will be found that Mr. Bayes' findings are in line with those of the Inspector and that he emphasizes that "most of this trouble can be attributed to faulty maintenance either due to lack of time or knowledge and interest in this type of equipment".

In my opinion, the proper care and operation of the power plant at this school requires the full time of a properly qualified man. If Mr. Townsend has not the experience and qualifications necessary for the position, he should be replaced at the earliest possible date. On the other hand, if this man is qualified and in a position to do the work required and could give the service the Department has a right to expect, provided he were free from other duties at the school, the necessary arrangements should be made to bring this change about and the Principal instructed accordingly. It is certainly disturbing to know that the trouble we have experienced in connection with the equipment at this school and the resulting expense to the Department are the direct result of lack of proper care and attention.

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Father Forbes:

You will recall that we have had constant complaints regarding the Lister Diesel engine installed in the Kootenay Residential School in February, 1941, at a cost of approximately $1500. The Department felt that this machine should work properly and we believed that the trouble was either due to faulty installation or, on the other hand, the fault of the school engineer. We further believed that the time had arrived when a thorough examination should be made of the machine and a decision reached regarding what the real trouble was. Accordingly we instructed Indian Commissioner MacKay to have this machine examined by a competent man and I enclose, for your information, a copy of his report. This report may be summarized as follows:

1. Poor housekeeping in the engine room has created a serious fire hazard.

4. Engine room badly in need of painting.

5. Floor of engine room oil soaked.

I feel certain that you will co-operate with the Department by correcting the conditions which quite evidently have interfered with the proper operation of the Diesel engine.

Dear Mr Hoey:

I would have replied to your letter sooner had I not had to take the place of a member of the staff.

In the first place, I would like to point out that, for almost three years, I have suggested that a competent and independent expert examine the Lister diesel and the Paterson engines as being no mechanic, I could not make out whether the engines, repairs to the engines, the installation or the operator were the source of our trouble. While not feeling that the operator is entirely free from blame, I am still of the opinion that he is not the sole or main source of the trouble.

You were kind enough to summarize Mr Bayes' report. I will make a few comments on the points you mentioned as the facts do not seem to have been given completely or clearly to Mr Bayes or to the Inspector of Indian Agencies. That, of course, was no fault of theirs. (A glaring example but a very unimportant point! Mr B. appears to have been told that the water is pumped from the river).

In the first part, I will deal more especially with the Lister diesel engine although some points refer to both engines.

1. Poor housekeeping.... The operator is certainly untidy but I do not think that that is the main cause of the fire hazard.

2. Tools scattered over the engine room.... or more correctly on, under and adjacent to a work bench. These two points will be attended to when the operator returns.

3. A new line shaft, etc supplied two years ago.... have not yet been installed. The facts are that the shaft did not come until several months after the hangers and, as we could not wait for the shaft, a temporary shaft with hangers was installed and used until it was recently taken down. Rightly or wrongly, I decided not to install the new shaft until the cylinder head, requested over a year ago, came. My plan was to have an outside man install the head and the shaft at the same time. Mr Bayes seemed to agree with me that it would be well to have a qualified man install the new shaft so that it would be perfectly in line. (What he said had nothing to do with the delay as I spoke to him only a few weeks ago).

4. Engine room badly in need of painting. That is perfectly true. This room and the furnace room are two deep holes in the ground with very little light or ventilation. While they will always be holes, a good paint job would improve them in so far as light is concerned as painting has greatly brightened the poorly-lighted laundry.

5. Floor of engine room soaked with oil. THAT is the real fire hazard in my opinion but it belongs to the next point.
The Petters engine was out of use when I came, and some time later, it was repaired in Vancouver thanks to the Department. Certain changes appear to have been made in Vancouver. Whether it is due to these changes or not, I cannot say but immediately after we got the engine back, the operator complained that this engine no longer had its former power and that it spewed oil on the floor. It is this oil which seems to be the cause of the fire hazard.

The information given to Mr Inspector Coleman is not entirely exact. While it is true that, from early April on to the Fall, Mr Townsend's main concern is with the farm, this is not true during the late Fall, Winter and early spring, that is during the time when the engines are most used. During the whole school year, he attends to the engines and boiler on Mondays (laundry) and Saturdays (both days). It is true that another person started a fire or had fuel added in the boiler, which was very dangerous and which was done without authorization. I do not think that it was done (and it will not be done again) after I spoke to that person.

I have asked the operator to take out papers and I believe that he could do so easily but he is very diffident and has a habit of putting things off.... I might mention that I have tried and am trying to get another man so that the operator can give more time to other work.

The Commissioner and the Inspector of Agencies have done their best to get parts required for the Lister engine, to have the Petters engine properly repaired, etc., but the Vancouver Company does not seem to have the parts or the proper staff.

I would suggest that Mr Bayes' suggestions be followed. The cost of repair parts for the old Otto engine was so high that I did not include the magneto, etc., as suggested by Mr Bayes.

When Mr Townsend returns from his mother's funeral, I will ask him to give me the names, sizes, etc., of pipe needed for fire-fighting equipment.

I have just re-read Mr B's report and note his explanation of the cause of the Petter's engine ejecting oil. He evidently knows his work but I find it strange that the operator and the really competent mechanic, whom I had come here to examine the engine when it returned from Vancouver and before it ran, did not find this. This mechanic (the manager of a large Cranbrook garage) was given authority to inspect the Lister engine but never completed his inspection. The reason appears to be that, after having the cylinder head sent to Vancouver, he was awaiting its return. While he is considered perhaps the best mechanic in Cranbrook he is not a Diesel man and any work should, I feel, be given to Mr Bayes as I understand that he is a diesel man. His suggestions co-incide, in many ways, with those of Mr Bayes.... As I see it, the real problem is to find a tidier and more interested man than the present operator. What I can do, I will do.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Memorandum for file:

On the Inspector's report file for the Kootenay Agency there is a lengthy report from Inspector Coleman regarding the Kootenay Indian Residential School. This report was forwarded to the Department under cover of Indian Commissioner MacKay's letter of April 28. In commenting on Inspector Coleman's report regarding the Kootenay School, Indian Commissioner MacKay wrote as follows:

"Fire Protection: The question of fire protection has already been reported on by the Surveys and Engineering Branch and any move to provide a service in this respect should be referred to them for attention.

"Kitchen: The three oven range referred to should be overhauled and repaired or replaced if the cost of repair and overhaul is excessive.

"Electric Wiring: Improvements to the electric wiring and fire alarm system at the school were carried out under Departmental authority 155-0-5 dated April 5, 1941, at a cost of $449.13. The work on completion was inspected by Mr. MacDonald, local Assistant Fire Marshal, and reported by him as satisfactory. The Agent will be requested to advise regarding the parts of the system referred to by Mr. Coleman which constitute a fire hazard.

"It would appear that the total cost of the various improvements listed as necessary at this school by the Inspector would run into a formidable sum and if we are to consider as well the cost of installing an adequate water supply for fire fighting purposes which the Surveys and Engineering Branch has estimated at $16,275.00 for a gravity system from St. Joseph's Creek, it might be well
before any great expenditure is incurred to survey the educational set-up in the Kootenay and Okanagan Agencies to determine whether the Residential School should be closed and replaced by Day Schools in the areas from which the Residential School pupils are drawn. School:

The usual activity prevails at the Kootenay Indian Residential School, perhaps a little more so now when seeding operations are in full swing. On the occasion of my last visit, the children under the direction of the Rev. Principal Forbes were busy planting a large number of raspberry and a few currant bushes, about 700 in all. These operations will be followed shortly by the planting of a School garden which will consist of illustration plots of vegetables and grasses. The seeding and developing of this garden is made possible by the action of the Department in supplying the necessary seeds, fertilizers etc. The seeding and developing of the plots will be carried on by the children under the supervision of the Agricultural Representative Mr. James Allan. The Rev. Principal Forbes and the Indian Agent.

The interior of this school is always kept very clean. The meals served are well prepared, composed of wholesome appetizing food. The children too in keeping with the general environment appear to be happily and certainly very clean.

The laundry rooms, never as bright as they ought to have been for lack of proper lighting, have been kalsomined a clean and cheery white which has the effect, despite poor lighting, of making them appear very bright.
