Dear Major MacKey:

As some of the items listed in the 1945-1946 estimates have become more important than items requested for the present year, I would suggest that the following order be followed and that as much as possible be done this year. The Department's file will show that practically nothing was spent on the roof until last year and what was spent then was out of a special grant. As you are aware, the contractor did only the most essential work and both he and I were under the impression that the balance of the work would be done this year. As very little money, if any, was spent on the roof, until last year, and as the remaining repairs are urgently needed (the wind loosened and nearly blew the ridge board off recently), I would suggest that the job be completed and that it be paid for out of a special grant. The cost is high but, as the building deteriorates, it will become higher.... This applies to the roof and other repairs on the building and is listed under #1.

1- Everything listed on enclosed "Requisition for Supplies," March 10th, 1944, page 1, #1- under the heading "Exterior."

2- Repairs to furnaces—estimated cost, under $80.00 including wages of competent men. (Patmore Brothers, Cranbrook, could do the work, and should be asked for an itemized quotation on the job. A new door for one of the furnaces is needed and several large tin or sheet metal pipes must be renewed as they are nearly burned out and will soon become a fire hazard).... Would you please instruct the Indian Agent to have Patmore's (or anyone else) inspect these furnaces? ... In view of what Mr. Warren said in report, two or three years ago, it might be advisable to have Patmore's check the plumbing. Mr. Warren's report states that the plumbing is old and will have to be renewed in the near future. At present it is giving only minor trouble but that may be just the beginning. I believe that Patmore's will be able to suggest an inexpensive way of installing fire-hoses in the building with no more water than we actually have. This solution is not ideal and, in the case of a serious fire, would depend on our being able to get to and start our water pump. This could be easily done provided that the fire was not in the engine or furnace room. The idea is Mr. Townsend's and I think that he explained it to Mr. Coleman. Until the water pump was started we would have only whatever water was in the storage tank.

3-Refrigerator—In a letter written yesterday, I suggested that you have Mr. Ward, Modern Electric, Cranbrook, report to you on this matter. I understood Mr. Ward to say that the refrigerator is so large and most unnecessarily so that our own engine, the Lister or the big Otto, would have to run 16 out of 24 hours a day to safeguard the batteries. This refrigerator is ruining the batteries and making it impossible for us to have adequate light. Mr. Ward should be asked for suggestions and the cost of alterations.

4-Radiators, necessary pipes, elbows, etc., needed, (second hand ones in good condition would do), for the two disciplinarians' rooms (about 4' radiators) and (one 12' or 10') for the Sisters' dormitory are needed. Two or three 10 to 12' radiators would be required for the attic if, as Mr. Inspector Coleman suggested when he was here, this be turned into a boys' dormitory. I can get no radiators or quotations here. There is a rumour that there are some radiators not needed at the Indian School at Lytton. (Hot water radiators.)

over.
5- Kitchen range FOR WOOD. On account of the way the kitchen is built and the chimney placed, there is no room for a stove over 10' long. It could be from 3 to 3½' in depth i.e., from front to back.

While here and in his report to the Department, Mr. School Inspector Fredrickson strongly urged that a small stove similar to one that an Indian family would have, be bought so that the girls learn how to use such a stove and to prepare meals for a few people. The Department will likely approve of this and take the money out of the special B.C. grant.

6- Until the roof was repaired, it leaked and severely damaged the plaster in parts of the dormitories. In one dormitory, the condition of part of the ceiling is dangerous. There are also several places where the plaster has fallen from the walls or ceiling. Would you please instruct the Indian Agent to have a plasterer inspect this and submit a quotation?

7- Lumber, nails, etc. for ordinary repairs (to be done as part of the boys' manual training), $125.00.

8- Material for Manual Training shop,- $100.00.

9- The Department expressed its surprise at Mr. Inspector Fredrickson's stating that we had not sufficient tools for the manual training shop. He did this, I believe, because he found that the public schools which he visits are much better supplied than we are. However, Mr. Inspector Coleman thoroughly inspected our shop and tools and I think that he will bear me out when I say that the tools requested on the enclosed list are needed.

10- I have some used lumber here with which I wish to build a blacksmith's shop.- We have none. A grant of from $100.00 to $200.00 would be appreciated for shingles, windows, nails, etc.

11- We have pigs but no piggery. About $800.00 would be required to build one.

Please note that, as part of their training, the boys would do the building, etc., in all cases mentioned above. They could not do the work on the roof or the plastering.

12- As the Inspectors have likely reported and as Mr. Leigh, of Tremoo, did, the foundations under the steps leading to the front entrance have collapsed or rotted away. The impression on visitors is bad (as is also the impression made by the long cement walks to these steps,- the cement is broken, the walks are uneven, etc.) Please see Mr. Leigh's report for details and the cost of repairs.

13- This, I believe, should be given special attention. We have an exceptionally well qualified and devoted nurse in the person of Sister Marion Clare. She has saved the Department a good deal of money not only by filling prescriptions (for which the Department used to pay the druggists) and by treating what should have been isolation or hospital cases here and by preventing epidemics (-a few months ago she treated two measles cases here and prevented them from spreading) but also in various other ways. She started a class of home nursing among the girls and drew favourable comments from outsiders. In order to improve on her classes of home nursing, she requested (as I believe the Inspectors requested for her) the necessary medical books. I regret to have to say that, except for a few words which cost nothing, the Department showed little lack of appreciation for her extra work whereas a tangible act of recognition and of encouragement was the least that she could expect. She is absent at present and I cannot find the list of books which she needs but Mr. Inspector Coleman may have the list as she gave a copy of the list to him... I need not point out that she gives her services not only to the pupils...
also to the other Indians and is at their beck and call at all hours. It seems to me that the Department has cause for shame: she has done and is doing so much for the Department and it will not thank or encourage her with a few books. As they will be used chiefly for her class, they could be paid for out of the special B.C.grant. A book on pre-natal care would be of service in case expectant Indian mothers wish to avail themselves of her offer to advise them.

14- On the enclosed list, Mr Leigh has given quotations near end of page two - on paint for other rooms. As there will likely be no money available, I do not mention or request this paint EXCEPT for the kitchen. The cost is $61.50. Most of the kitchen is underground and surrounding walls make it very dark. It is nearly as dark as the laundry was. Thanks to paint, the laundry is now light and cheerful.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd. G. Forbes,O.M.I.)

P.S. The gentleman whom Mr. Coleman brought here to inspect the engines, stated (see his report) that the engine room should be painted.(It has been cleaned). Tremco's quotation on this paint; Engine room: Tramlux white,-$59.25; Dodo enamel -$23.00 (all paint is less freight, I believe).

I presume I will hear further from you about this matter, as you state in Paragraph 9 of your letter that you have written to the Reverend Principal for the list which he neglected to forward to you.

St. Eugene Residential School.

As meetings of the St. Mary's Band were held in this building and an enquiry was made into the engine situation there was an opportunity of making a few observations in connection with the institution that may be of interest.

BUILDING:

The structure is of cement block into which evidently went some very poor construction and thereafter, until recently, very little intelligent maintenance, with the result that a great deal of work will have to be undertaken to restore it to reasonable repair. The building was reportedly shaken by an earthquake some time ago causing vertical cracks to appear in several parts of the walls which have never been pointed up.

FIRE PROTECTION:

Probably the primary need of this institution is a fire protection system. This has been surveyed at various times and estimated to cost from $1200.00 to $3,800.00. It will probably be some time before these funds can be provided, but meanwhile something might be done by way of a "first aid" scheme that would bring an incipient fire under control that might otherwise get out of hand.

The school "engineer" had a scheme whereby 1" or 1½" pipes would be installed at both ends of the building with an outlet and fifty feet of 1" hose at two stations on the ground floor or sub-basement, main floor, dormitory floor and attic. This should prove to be a fairly inexpensive installation, probably much less than $500.00 including hose. With an outside coupling it would give some protection to the outbuildings. It appears probably that it would deliver a stream of water for a few minutes while the pump was being started up to ensure a steady supply. A Forestry pump would be useful for the barn, manual training shop and outbuildings.

PLUMBING:

It is hard to say what is the more urgent of the numerous necessary jobs in this building. The Reverend Principal considers that plumbing should be surveyed by a competent man. This was a more extensive undertaking than I had time for. I would, however, suggest that more baths could be installed, the present three in the boys wash room appearing inadequate. I did not examine the girls room.

HEATING:

The Principal complained, with apparently good reason, of the shortage of radiators, particularly in the disciplinarians room and the Sister's dormitory. I understand that there is a surplus of radiator units at St. George's School (Lytton) and it is possible that this might be transferred to advantage and no cost other than freight.

PLASTERING:

With the continual leaking of the roof, which was recently repaired, the plaster in the dormitories was seriously damaged. Some of it can no doubt be repaired by patching the cracks, but other parts, such as in the ceiling of the senior girls dormitory, will have to be cut out and replastered or filled in with plasterboard, as the ceiling is fairly high and sooner or later the loose area will fall.

The plaster of this school is on expanded metal "lath" similar to St. George's school construction, except that the studding here appears to be on more standard center to center measurement. It has the common failure of this lath in offering
little resistance to the rough usage of a school with the result that some holes are in evidence. If a fire got into the wall space (possibly from small boys and matches) the staff would have a real problem on their hands. The remedy is patching holes as soon as they appear, with wood or wall board wainscoting on the lower part of the wall.

BASEMENT FLOOR:

It was stated that shortly after the school was built it was found necessary to cover the "concrete" floor with a wood floor as the pupils buried themselves digging it up with spoons. This floor is pretty weak in spots and when funds become available it would be advisable to take it up and cover the so-called concrete with a covering of strong fine cement and a surfacing.

I called the Rev. Principal's attention to a large electric motor in the laundry insufficiently protected.

ROOF:

The roof of this building is of metal. Owing to faulty design snow piled up in the valleys and melting and freezing worked up under the inadequate flashings seriously damaging the plaster in the dormitories etc. Considerable work was done on this in the early winter of 1943 and it is hoped that it is now leak proof. However, much of the metal roofing is rusting where bends fractured the galvanizing and to protect these points the entire roof over the main building, chapel and corridors requires painting with a metal roof paint.

The roof of the boiler house was in recent years covered with a felt roofing either poorly laid or in unsuitable weather and the buckles were taken out of this and protection was given to where it was subject to damage by falling icicles.

DAMP PROOFING:

To protect the stonework base of pediments, stone lintels over windows and canopy etc., from the inroads of frost and moisture, consideration should be given some time to damp proof treatment.

MAIN ENTRANCE:

The wide stone steps to the main entrance must have been laid on a poor foundation and they have sagged considerably in the center. They will eventually have to be taken up and re-set on a firmer support. There are eight treads 11" X 1'8" risers.

KITCHEN:

This is a three oven range, the fire box having burnt through into the first oven and I understand that the other two ovens do not function. The surfact of the range does not heat except over the firebox. The condition of this range is a serious matter with the number of pupils and staff to provide for and there is no doubt but that it should be overhauled and repaired at the earliest opportunity. The school "engineer" is an ingenious individual that can make a broken down engine run a little longer but whose tinkering can, in my opinion, upset the operation of an efficient machine, and I rather suspect that his operations on the draft of this range accounts for its failure to operate with the result that the kitchen staff have tried to force matters with a very hot fire and the aforementioned burn-out.

Interior Decoration:

The kitchen, childrens dining room, laundry, boys and girls recreation rooms, wash rooms on both sides and basement halls all need repainting badly, the latter also needing some plaster repairs, or better, replacement by plasterboard. The hall floors
the main floor and stairways are in need of an application of "Penetrem" or similar hard wearing varnish both for appearance and protection. This does not exhaust the interior decoration but covers the more urgent needs.

CAULKING:

It will be a matter of economy to have the window and door frames caulked with one of the modern compounds as this is a cold country in the winter and the cost will soon be saved in fuel—or added comfort. It is possible to see through some of these frames at present. Window frames and sash require repainting.

PREVENTORIUM:

On both the boys and girls sides there are separate porches opening out of the dormitories, each capable of holding four or five beds, that could possibly be utilized for the incipients if the existing window openings, which are now only screened with wire, were fitted with windows of the casement variety that could be opened wide in seasonable weather. Apart from this they would make a valuable sleeping space addition. There are ten window openings in these two porches (five in each).

ENGINE AND BOILER ROOMS:

I have reported separately on the necessity of these two rooms being painted, particularly the engine room, to improve the lighting and enable the staff to give better attention to the valuable equipment therein. There is also a need for changing the set up of the engines and installation of an overhead shaft that was supplied two years ago.

There are no openings in either the boiler or engine rooms to permit entry of machinery, the doors being ordinary 2'6" affairs, or less. Provision should be made some day for improvement of this access.

I noticed that some one had cut out one of the concrete supporting piers of the chapel that is at the end of the engine room in order to make room for the Peters Engine. If the engines are placed in line this supporting column should be repaired if it is possible to do so.

Some time ago the school removed the coal grates from the heating boilers to adapt them to wood burning to help out the Indians in the winter by purchase of wood, which is now regretted as the school has the greatest difficulty in securing its needs. The Agency residence and office has had to secure its fuel from whites.

ELECTRIC WIRING:

Like most of these residential schools that I have seen, there is a great need for checking over the electric wiring as in spots it was a considerable fire hazard.

GENERAL REPAIRS:

The Principal advised that a grant of about $125.00 for lumber and nails for general repairs would be very helpful, but I am unable to give details.

MANUAL TRAINING SHOP:

Under the direction and work of Father Anthony an excellent Manual Training Shop has been constructed over an old concrete floor. The old part of the floor is in good shape but the mixture or material in the new floor was very poor and can be scraped up quite easily. This portion should be repaired with a strong surface finish of sand and cement and the whole floor...
covered with "Mulsomatic" or some similar concrete floor treatment to abate the dust nuisance. The floor area is 1150 square feet.

It would improve working conditions, light and appearance if the wood walls and ceiling were painted with a light coloured paint, as well as assist in preservation of the material. The outside also should be painted against the weather and to reduce fire hazard. Presumably these costs could be a charge against the B.C. Special Vote.

There is only one children's bench in this building, two others being adult size and too high altogether for the children, for whom it is obvious they were never intended. At least three benches of regulations size and construction should be provided for the children. There is also a need for proper tool cabinets (which could be constructed on the job by the older pupils) and some blackboard.

The housekeeping in this room is pretty well along the lines of the engine room and a great deal of space is taken up with what appeared to be pure junk that should be cleared out into some outside storage. More will be said of this later under "Instruction".

PIGGERY:

The Principal spoke of the necessity of a piggery, the present accommodation being rough hovels. I would be more inclined to discuss the necessity if I were more certain that the agricultural training at this school was an organized endeavour.

BARN:

The school has a very large barn which has recently been re-roofed by Father Anthony with the help of the older pupils and they appear to have done a thoroughly good job, painting the roof with used engine oil (regarding which I hold no opinion). The interior of the building was fairly clean for winter, but a spray of whitewash would improve the appearance and hygiene of the dairy section. A track was installed in the building for a little carrier but has apparently been out of use for some years. In the interests of health I would like to see it put into use again with a properly protected manure pit away from the barn. Apart from the health question, it is poor training to pile it up outside and the losses by this method would soon pay for a proper ply.

The record of production of the cows was not very impressive. I did not inspect the animals but from the record sheets it would appear that a weed, breed and feed policy with all that it implies, could well be put in effect as the dairy is probably in the red if the feed etc., were charged against the milk and cream.

CEMENT WALK:

From the main gate to the main entrance is a very "Jerry-built" affair, broken up near the main entrance and quite dangerous. Should be repaired.

PROVISION FOR ADDITIONAL ACCOMMODATION:

There is ample room in the attic on the boys side for a dormitory for possibly 20 beds which could be inexpensively developed by use of plasterboard. If this is done some insulation should be used, particularly on the ceiling. At one time fire escapes were in place at the rear of the building on both boys and girls sides. If the attic is developed for a dormitory either they should be replaced or a fire door installed on the stair well as was done on the girls side in recent years, otherwise the children could be trapped by a fire or hot air coming up the stair well. The part of the attic on the girls side is used as a Sisters' dormitory. A fire door equipped with "Corbin" panic bolts...
on the women's side of the door could be put in the separating wall so as to give access down the girls fire escape in case of necessity.

GENERAL REBUILDING:

The foregoing covers only the more obvious items needing attention. A careful and detailed examination of the structure would doubtless indicate a great deal more that needs attention.

The need in most of the Residential Schools visited, including this one, is for the Indian Agent to make a careful detailed examination of the buildings once a year, before compiling his estimates, and budget for the carrying out of essential maintenance. If this were done consistently the Department would be saved a considerable sum by the spasmodic hit and miss method of lean years with the occasional splurge. Agents generally, do not appear to appreciate their responsibility in connection with the government owned structures.

OPERATION:

The care of the children appeared to be excellent in every respect and probably on a higher physical level than in most of our schools. The children are happy and, in my opinion, well fed with a well balanced diet. They were able to stand up to hard and continuous exercise without undue exhaustion. The female staff are the Sisters of Charity of Halifax and are an exceptionally fine type of women. They are much more efficient, enthusiastic and hard working than the male staff.

ACADEMIC:

As this was covered by Inspector Frederickson's inspection I made no attempt to explore the teaching ability of the Reverend Sisters, but I have considerable confidence in his ability to evaluate the quality of their work and offer valuable suggestions for improvement. Being a Catholic he is entirely sympathetic with the objects of the institution and very anxious to elevate its work to a standard comparable with the best white institutions in his inspectorate.

The class rooms are in operation for the mornings only and I doubt whether the work of the afternoons is organized to the extent it should be and keyed to an actual educational programme. Some of the Sisters complained that half a day in the classroom did not give them much opportunity to push the class room work as much as should be done. The class rooms were clean and appeared to be well organized.

MANUAL TRAINING:

The Manual training instructor is Mr. Barre, apparently a French Canadian. His work in this capacity is practically valueless, and the Reverend Principal did not appear very satisfied with him. He apparently takes the boys four at a time in the afternoon. When I saw them the four receiving instruction were working at one small bench, very much littered up, attempting to lay out a small cut out figure for some project or the other. I doubt very much whether the boys are getting a progressive course of study on the handling and care of ordinary tools and performance of basic operations.

If the course and work charts were followed making sure that the pupils understood each item there should be no difficulty in their acquiring a reasonable degree of skill by the time they graduate out. I doubt whether this is being done.
I questioned the Instructor regarding the time actually spent on manual training by him and he gave this as four hours a day (I believe 2½ hours would be more accurate) and that the rest of his time was spent in maintenance work around the school (no doubt at the expense of the B.C. Special Vote).

If a competent Instructor was employed I would like to see the training include such metal work as would be involved in repair of farm machinery.

Attached is an inventory of tools on hand and a list of additional tools that the Reverend Principal considers should be supplied. It will be noticed on the inventory that they have an excessive number of some items such as Jack Planes and ¼" wood chisels. Some of the items on the "tools required" list are obviously an effort to charge general maintenance to the B.C. Special Vote. These I have marked, and apart from the items commented on the list is quite a reasonable one.

AGRICULTURAL INSTRUCTION:

It is my opinion that all residential schools with farms, such as this, in this Province are passing up a real opportunity of service to the Indians by their failure to give the pupils something along the lines of agricultural instruction. Mostly they are regarded as so much free help around the place to help with the chores, pitching hay etc., which would do no harm if it was part of a definite organized training with special consideration of the problems and type of farming incidental to the section of the province from which pupilage is drawn, or need this be confined to the boys. Such a plan should include class room work, weed and plant collections etc. It is anticipated that many of the pupils would leave school anxious to operate their lands rather than fight shy of them as at present. Standards could be set up by stock judging competitions, affiliation with "Boys and Girls Clubs" etc.

I endeavoured to lay a small foundation for work of this nature in trying to induce the Agent and Reverend Principal to operate a small "Illustration Station" on the school grounds for the benefit of St. Mary's Reserve and the pupils, to be operated under the direction of the local Provincial Agriculturist, who was quite keen on the idea.

MEDICAL:

The health of the pupils is well taken care of by Sister Marion Clair, R.N., a graduate nurse, and Doctor Greene of Cranbrook. Sister Clair also attempted to conduct classes among the girl pupils on First Aid and Home Nursing, stating that her application for a copy of the Canadian Red Cross book on "Home Nursing" was refused by the Department, which is not understood as it is most inexpensive, and these classes would have assisted in reducing hospitalization when the girls graduated. However, I am securing for her a copy personally. Considering the small cost of 25¢ per copy, I am of the opinion it would be a good investment to supply each girl in the class with one for personal use. The Reverend Sister would also like to be furnished with a "Chase" Model doll (baby model). She has a set of baby scales. These items should be a legitimate charge against the B.C. Special Vote, as the training would be, at least, as valuable as the routine academic work. No doubt Doctor Greene would be pleased to examine the classes at the close of the terms. The final classed could not doubt be examined and certificated under the auspices of St. John's or the Red Cross.
Medical Cont'd:

The nurse also asked if the Department would provide a few essential reference books for the use of herself or her successors, listing these as follows:

Elesson, "First Aid in Emergencies"
Emerson, "Essentials of Medicine"
Jeans & Road, Essentials of Pediatrics"
Pillebury, "Nursing Care of Communicable Diseases" (McGraw-Hill Publishers, Toronto)
Woodward, "Obstetrical Management and Nursing".

Presumably the two "Essentials" are nurses publications and not the medical students quiz books.

To these I would add a good text on essentials of every day diet and Lipencott's "Quick Reference for Nurses" (Montreal).

None of the above texts except Lipencott's are familiar and they may be those in use in the Nurses School in the Massachusetts General. Presumably equivalent Canadian Texts would be acceptable.

While this may be a departure from the Department's usual practice, I would point out that during the past two years this nurse has given considerable nursing care on the Reserve outside of the school and the gesture of forwarding all or some of these publications with the Department's appreciation would yield good dividends, as there is a feeling in the institution that the Department has been somewhat indifferent to the extra institutional activities of the nurse and staff in the medical field.

MUSIC:

Excellent work is being done with some pupils in pianoforte by the Reverend Sister Henry, in addition to her other duties. She is desirous of taking two or three to Nelson for the Conservatory of Music examinations, and asked if the Department would agree to defray the travelling costs of herself and the pupils and examination fees for this as she thought it would be helpful to the school to secure these credits. If I remember rightly it was a matter of a total of about $25.00 or $35.00. The school finances does not permit the expenditure.

ART:

This is handled mostly by Sister Superior Mary Louis. It is good in the orthodox school manner but the pupils are capable of much better work given a lead in the direction of originality. I attempted to give some advice and demonstration intended to be helpful, but this very fine Sister is a trifle too old fashioned to make any drastic departure from the methods of some years ago.

SEWING:

The girls appear to be well instructed in sewing and allied arts by Sister Catherine Mary. The children are better clothed than at some of the residential schools in the Province.

The remaining Sisters not mentioned are Sister Bernice, who takes the grade 4 to 6 class room; Sister Cephas, Kitchen and Diet and Sister John Anthony, Laundry. The Reverend Principal is, of course, Father Forbes, O.M.I., assisted by Father Anthony, excellent both as a carpenter and an individual, also the young missionaries. The lay staff are the "engineer" ranch hand and jack of all trades, Mr. Townsend and Mr. Barre, the Manual Training Instructor.
FINANCIAL:

Past audits and that about to be made will show that the school is being carried by the Oblates, cost of operation apparently being in the red to the extent of two or three thousand dollars annually. I have not taken the time to make more than a cursory examination of the school's finances as the Department's audit will show this clearly, but the position appears to be that the pupilage is out of all proportion to the staff necessary to handle an institution of this size in the matter of square feet floor space. The grant earning pupilage of 83 is no more than some of our two room day schools. With some utilization of space available, at the cost of small expenditure, the pupilage could undoubtedly be increased to the 110 pupils the Reverend Principal considers necessary to pay cost of operation.

The school has taken in almost every available pupil in the Agency and some from the Okanagan. The Okanagan quota could no doubt be increased from those reserves without day schools such as Westbank and the Similkameen Reserves. The trouble, of course, is that a residential school was built in an area with only small day school populations and the institution's attempts to make ends meet by paring operation expenses has actually made the Department spend more money on some items, such as the engines, than fully paid efficient labour would have received.

GENERAL:

The needs of this school can be summarized as follows:

(1) Increased pupilage to improve finances and general administration.

(2) Overtaking of arrears in maintenance.

(3) Improved fire protection.

(4) Improved manual training and adoption of an organized agricultural training.

(5) A little brush up by the teaching sisters in modern methods.

(6) These would make it an outstanding school.

On the credit side might be mentioned among other things:

(1) The prevailing high tone among the pupils and staff and their relations with each other. It is a happy school.

(2) Excellent care by way of food, clothing & health of the pupils.

(3) Apparent lack of exploitation of the pupils' labour despite the financial problems.

J. Coleman,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Having been asked by Mr. A. Irwin, Indian Agent, for a report on the Sanitary conditions in regards to the Plumbing, etc., at the Kootenay Residential School, St. Eugene Mission, we hereby make the following report:

Practically all Plumbing Fixtures date 1912. There are Fifteen J.L.Mott Toilets, Suspendo type, with Flushometer and Tank action. Also Nine Mott Compacto floor type with same flush action. While the porcelain pans or Bowls are mostly in good shape the Flushometers on all the Toilets are due for replacement, also it would be necessary to replace many seats that are broken and patched up, as the Toilets are flushed by seat action.

There were originally 36 Basins in boys and girls Dormitories and wash room. Any that have been broken have been taken out or left on wall without any replacement.

The Waste pipes for all these Basins, four batteries of nine each, are in the outside concrete wall. Iron Pipes with Lead Stubs through plaster and wainscoting. The traps soldered on to the lead. No Cleanouts available. Numbers of these Lead Stubs are leaking behind the wall and running on the floor. To repair would mean (and in many places have already been done leaving an unsightly appearance) cutting out wainscoting and plaster and cement. Would advise accessible wastes with proper Cleanouts.

Nine Urinals are in filthy condition, often plugged, (as I found them all at time of writing) making cleaning difficult.

Bathing facilities are three five ft Leg Tubs, no partitions, in each of Boys and Girls Dormitories, to serve approx. 45 Boys and 45 Girls.

Three Showers in each of Boys and Girls Basements have been out of commission for years and are obsolete. Mostly gone. If put in condition would greatly add to bathing facilities.

You have a report by Mr. Warren on the Domestic Water supply, three years ago. This water not being Automatic the pressure varies from nothing up to 100 lbs. The Toilets of the Flushometer type need a good pressure for flushing. Consequently when pressure gets down the toilets being used and not flushing properly, leave a very unsanitary condition.
In this regard, Self Closing Taps should be used, or installed on all Wash Basins used by Pupils, as when water pressure is down the Pupils leave the taps open and when the water pressure is pumped up again it causes numerous floods from Basins overflowing. Installing the above Taps would save a great deal of pumping. All these old taps with the exception of a couple pair, are over Thirty years old and due for replacement.

In the Laundry all new Taps are needed and some repairs and replacements to Traps.

The Domestic Water Supply is very hard water and they have tried most of the known water softeners on the market without success. Soap will absolutely not lather. The best they can get white Sheets and under clothing is a very dirty grey, with a very bad odor. There is a soft water line from St. Joseph's Creek (Typhoid Water) which used to be in use for the Washers only but this being an old 3" wooden pipe needs renewing. Alternative would be to pump water from St. Mary's River, both being equal distance, approx. 600 ft.

There are numerous Toilets, Basins, and baths needing new Brass Parts which are available, also Toilets of type that can be replaced by Canadian Goods. While all the Moot Toilets being American, parts are not available.

The Domestic water is heated by a steam Jacket in Summer, Steam being supplied by a high pressure boiler which is used for Laundry purposes. This means that unless high pressure Boiler is in use there is no hot water. This steam Jacket has been in a number of years and was badly Alkilled, but by the use of Acid we have managed to clean it good enough for the coming year, when a replacement or other means will be necessary for Domestic Hot water.

There is a Two inch Coil in one Hot water Boiler which heats the water during the firing season. This coil will need renewing shortly.

In Summary, the Plumbing is in very poor condition. Any inspection by Government Official will find this not to be an exaggerated report.

We have not touched on the Heating. The Expansion Tank in attic does need relining. Smoke Pipes need attention. It is far from a good heating System.

Yours Respectfully

Patmore Bros.

per. A. C. Hayden

Electrical Merchandise and Contracting

CRANBROOK, B.C.

Oct. 6 1944.

Mr. A. Irwin, agent,
Dept. Indian Affairs,
Cranbrook.

Dear Sir:

I regret the delay in quoting on the repairs to the wiring at the Kootenay Residential School. This matter was overlooked in the rush of other business.

The hallway extension and the minor repairs to existing hazardous electrical fittings would be twenty-three dollars and thirty cents.

Regarding the refrigerator changes it must be borne in mind that ample power must be available at all times if this is to work satisfactorily on an automatic pressure control. At the present time this equipment is turned on manually and apparently only when the batteries are well charged. Cutting the box down in size will allow good refrigeration with no more increase in current consumption than is being used by the manual method. We cannot however assume any responsibility for successful operation if trouble occurs due to erratic power supply.

Yours truly,

John A. Ward.
MR. A IRWIN,
AGENT
DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CITY.

Dear Sir,

We quote as follows on repairs to the lighting system at the KOOTENAY RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL:

Install eight drop lights in dining room complete with metal shades and pull chain sockets to replace existing unsatisfactory fixtures.
Install two additional lights complete with shades in classroom also duplex convenience outlet.
Replace hazardous wiring in upper hallway with metal raceway complete with drop light.
Install bracket light in bathroom in metal raceway and seal off open conduit ends.
Repair defective hall light fixture.
Extend wiring in attic over to store room complete with drop.

The cost of the above electrical work including labor and materials would be Eighty seven dollars and thirty six cents (87.36)

I have examined the refrigeration equipment at the KOOTENAY RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL in an effort to devise some means of reducing the running costs. I wish to report as follows:

The capacity of the condensing unit is such that it must operate a total of sixteen hours out of each twenty four in order to produce a temperature of 36-37 degrees in the cooler. This is a quite satisfactory running time and will give a closely regulated fixture temperature. The unit will require however something in excess of ten kilowatts per day for normal operation.

If, in order to conserve current, the running time was decreased the case temperature would rise. Also this temperature would fluctuate considerably between the on and off cycles of the machine. Either or both of these conditions would be very detrimental to proper food storage and would defeat the purpose for which the equipment is intended.

The size of the cooler could be reduced one third and effect about twenty five percent saving in current consumption. If however this was done it would be imperative that foodstuffs placed in the cooler be so arranged as to provide adequate air circulation around them. If this is not done stagnation will produce food spoilage regardless of the case temperature. The cost of building in a six inch insulated partition, installing tapered door opening, and fitting refrigerator door and hardware to the new partition would be Ninety three dollars. (93.00)

If the reduced cooler space would still be adequate for the school requirements, and, the current savings warrant the expense then the move would be a good one, otherwise it should not be considered. The cooler in its present size is engineered by the manufacturer to give maximum results.
At the present time this equipment is not always operating automatically. The unit is quite often shut down in order to build up the battery charge. If the size of the cooler is reduced (as above) the closer confinement of the food would make it imperative that the unit be left connected at all times, and, that adequate current be available to handle the refrigeration load.

The motor now on this unit is not operating properly. The shunt field is apparently open and the motor is racing as a series type motor. It is erratic in speed and the brushes are arcing badly and the commutator pitted. The service switch blades are burned beyond repair and the entire switch needs replacing. The wiring associated with the condensing unit motor, automatic controls and service switch is in a very dilapidated condition and should be completely renewed.

The refrigerant charge in the system should be adjusted, the automatic expansion valve set for proper superheat and the automatic controls reset to maintain a proper temperature in the cooler. This latter work should be done regardless of whether or not the size of the cooler is altered. The cost of this overhaul work would be $73.25 (Seventy Three Dollars and Twenty Five Cents).

Yours Truly

[Signature]

MODERN ELECTRIC
Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

Re: File No. 215-5-5697

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 6th ultimo with reference to minor electric wiring changes required at the Kootenay Indian Residential School as well as to the system of refrigeration.

The enclosed, from Mr. J. A. Ward, explains itself. The alterations and repairs to the lighting system at this school are very urgently needed. Regarding the refrigeration system, the Rev. Principal Forbes is satisfied that if reduced in size as recommended in the report of the Modern Electric there would still be sufficient space to accommodate the requirements of the school. Under existing conditions the greater part of the refrigerant is lost so that fresh vegetables, meats, butter, cream etc. cannot be kept for any length of time, thus nullifying the purpose for which the system was installed.

I need hardly say that Mr. Ward has the reputation of being a very dependable workman, but as his letter states, he is not prepared to assume responsibility for failure should his proposal fail to give satisfaction due to any trouble that might arise from an erratic power supply, which, during the past two years has resulted in a great deal of trouble at the above named school.

Andrew Irwin,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

I enclose herewith Mr. Indian Agent Irwin's letter of October 7th and reports from the Modern Electric in Cranbrook covering additional repairs required to the wiring at the Kootenay School and alterations and repairs to their refrigerator. The Company's report dated October 6th covers repairs to the wiring which are considered absolutely necessary and I would recommend that authority be granted for an expenditure of $23.30 for this purpose.

The alterations and improvements to the wiring outlined in their report of August 30th are not essential and should be left in abeyance for the present.

It would appear advisable to reduce the size of the refrigerator and make the necessary repairs at a total cost of $166.25, and I would recommend that authority be granted to have this work done.

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Mr. A. Irwin, Indian Agent, Cranbrook, B.C.

The Department is in receipt of a letter from the Principal of the Kootenay Residential School, in connection with the water supply and I enclose an extract from his letter marked "No. 1." I also enclose two other reports regarding the water system at this school, one of which was made in 1931 and the other in 1941 by officials of the Surveys & Engineering Branch. The Department would appreciate your giving this matter some study and possibly you could confer with Father Forbes and let us have a report. We are under the impression from Father Forbes' letter that no change is necessary in the drinking water supply. However, it can be inferred from Father Forbes' letter that replacement of the pipe about which he speaks would give an adequate supply of water for washing and fire protection and the expenditure in this regard would probably not be extremely heavy. However, the suggestions made by the Surveys & Engineering Branch, both in 1931 and 1941, apparently involve a very heavy expenditure. There is also the question raised in their reports that taking water from the river would affect certain people who secure water from the same source for irrigation purposes. I wish you would clear up this particular point as well as any other facts in connection with the water supply that you would like to bring to our attention. An early reply would be appreciated.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Extract from Mr. W.C. Warren's report, dated June 29, 1941, on Proposed Fire Protection and Repairs to Domestic Water Supply at the Kootenay Indian Residential School.

WATER FOR FIRE PROTECTION

There are only two possible sources which will provide water in sufficient quantity for fire protection purposes without large capacity storage. These sources are St. Joseph's creek and St. Mary's river. Both streams are contaminated by sewage and a supply for fire protection purposes secured from either would require facilities independent of the works existing for domestic service.

A gravity supply from St. Joseph's creek through a pipeline about one mile in length, would provide sufficient water at 45-lbs. hydrant pressure for fire protection. Such an installation although meeting certain requirements better than any other, probably cannot be considered on account of the high cost, estimated to be $16,275.00 with complete fire equipment.

Although St. Joseph's creek passes close to the school it would not be a desirable source for a pumped supply. There would be difficulties of an assured supply during the irrigation season and probably during the winter months.

A supply obtained from the St. Mary's river by pumping would cost approximately $8000. A suitable installation would provide water under 65 lbs. hydrant pressure at a rate of 500 gallons per minute.
Mr. R. A. Hoey,
Sept. W. Ward & Co.,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Our school supplies for the current year have not yet arrived, and we are out of several items. We are doomed to blame. I asked the Sister Superior, who does the ordering, to send in the requisition at the end of the year but failed to tell her that I referred to Dec. 31st, not to the end of the school year.

As you advised me, Mr. Nelson came and examined the plumbing. There seems to have been some confusion in the matter as, a couple of weeks before, a local plumber did the same. Mr. Murray & I believe, submitted his report. As Mr. Warren foresaw, when he made his report, a little more than three years ago, there is a great deal more than three years ago, there is a great deal to be done and, while certain things might be done now, the only time to do the main part...
Of the work will be when the pupils are on their holidays in July & August. I presume that the report will mention that (why, Heaven only knows) a certain amount of the plumbing was imbedded in or below cement floors or in cement walls. I hope that the report will strongly recommend that the boys' shower baths & rooms be repaired. They and the girls' shower baths have not been used for years. There are only 3 baths for all our boys. I would not recommend that the girls' shower baths be repaired. The Sisters & the Indians do not favour girls taking shower baths.

I hope that the following point will be stressed. The water from the Creek is unfit for drinking (it contains sewage) and, therefore, the Department installed a new water system some years ago. While the new water supply gives good drinking water, it is so hard that it is practically useless for washing purposes — no matter how much soap, etc., we use, we cannot get the clothes clean. We have, therefore, piped this new Creek water (unfit for drinking) directly into the washing machines. Unfortunately, the pipe, which brings this water from the Creek, is a very old wooden pipe and it has burst grated in places on many occasions.
Oceans - It is now beyond repair and a new pipeline is needed. I do not wish to exaggerate; this pipeline is, at the moment, supplying us with the water we absolutely need for our laundry (and barn). The horses readily drink the water without evil effects) but it has been patched & cemented etc. So often that it may become useless at any time - last winter, it broke twice and could not repair it until the spring - as a result, the road was flooded twice and dangerous - In a word: please renew this pipe-line as the water is really needed for our laundry.

I am very pleased to be able to report that, as usual, our relations with the Indians depart well. The Indians are excellent. The "spirit" of the pupils is good - in more than 3½ years, I have never seen them once, — and it was deserved. It was when the same pupil tried & incited 3 others to try to burn the school down.

We have just erected an honour roll. Although this agency has few Indians, there are about 40 names on the roll, — names of those who volunteered for active service. Of these, two have been killed in action & several have been wounded. One was in a serious accident. Two women, a white man (who got a jail term) & drunk were found in barracks.
I encourage the pupils to write to the wounded & their mothers appreciate the letters.

The pupils' health is good.

Yours Truly,

[Signature]

Re: St. Eugene Indian Residential School,
Water Supply

In reference to your memorandum of the 9th instant, your file 452-32, the matter was referred to Mr. Webb and from his reply the situation appears to be as follows:

The list of projects accompanying Dr. McGill's memorandum of September 29, 1943, contained an item of $27,527.00 for water supply and fire protection based on Mr. Warren's report dated March 4, 1931. This estimate was referred to Mr. Webb to be revised to meet present conditions and he increased it by 25% bringing it to $34,375.00, roughly $35,000.00, although a portion of the work was undertaken in 1932.

Regarding the proposals to be considered under the post-war programme, Mr. Webb states as follows:

"In the 1941 report the gravity fire protection service only is estimated at $16,275.00 using wood stove pipe and excluding all other attendant developments".

(It is assumed that the gravity supply from St. Joseph's Creek will be generally in accordance with the proposal outlined in the 1931 report as estimated to cost $16,275)

"The possibilities of supplying water for fire protection by means of pumps were outlined therein, in brief as follows:

(1) To supply 500 gallons per minute by pump indefinitely from St. Mary's River at a cost of $8,800.00

(2) To provide some degree of fire protection with the existing plant chiefly by means of new engine and inside fire outlets to cost $1,200.00.

(3) Alternative to (1) - Provision of high level domestic storage capacity (25,000 gallons) and stepped up pump capacity (100 gallons per minute) to provide a supply of 500 gallons per minute for one hour duration. To be undertaken when renewal of present domestic equipment is indicated. Estimated to cost $9,900.00.

"To all these estimates of course 25 percent should be added.

(Over)

R.A. Hoey, Esq.,
Acting Director,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.
"It was pointed out that the present domestic system was nearing the end of its life and that renewal cost would approximate $4,100.00 so that by adopting No. 3 this renewal would be accomplished for the amount estimated, whereas renewal would have to be undertaken at a future time if No. 1 was adopted.

It could be assumed that the question of the type of fire protection service to be installed at St. Eugene School depends in some respects upon the cost. I believe, however, that a gravity system should be employed for fire protection here if at all possible and so obviate to some extent dependence on mechanical equipment. Such equipment very often suffers from lack of proper care, and in consequence is costly to maintain.

There would appear to be no reason for the expenditure of $35,000.00 for any installation for fire protection purposes at St. Eugene School".

(Sgd) T.S. Mills,
Chief Engineer.
Philip Phelan, Esq., Chief, Training Division, Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Re: File No. 155-0-5.

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 26th ultimo with reference to a letter you received from the Rev. Principal Forbes requesting pipe line replacements to carry an urgently needed water supply from St. Joseph's Creek to be used for laundry purposes and fire protection at the School.

The present system requires many replacements of pipes, taps, etc., toilets, plumbing should have immediate attention. A report by Mr. W. C. Warren under date of June 29th, 1941 states that the present water works equipment has been in service for about twenty years and may require complete renewal within the next five or ten years. Three and a half of the five years mentioned have past and the pipes should be renewed. Some of the pipes are buried in the cement walls or under cement floors, which makes it extremely difficult to find and repair leaks.

The present water supply while satisfactory for drinking is impossible in the laundry. So very hard that no amount of soap and rubbing will get washing clothes. Water unfit for drinking but satisfactory for laundry purposes is brought from St. Joseph's Creek carried by an old wooden pipe line that was put in over thirty years ago. It is about 500 yards in length with its intake about that distance south of the School. It is rotted through in several places and not worth repairing. If a new pipe line is laid and connected with a one inch pipe of about 300 feet, water would be available for the laundry, urinals, toilets and fire protection as well.

Principal Forbes and his Engineer, Mr. Townsend, have called my attention to the fact that where the intake is located about 500 yards south of the School, the creek is about 30 feet above the ground level of the School or just above the level of the second floor, which would afford considerable pressure in bringing the water down. Mr. Townsend suggests that, and when the main pipe is renewed and connected to one or two hydrants at each end of the School and one or two more near the barn with a portable booster pump placed on a cart with sufficient hose, would assure an adequate supply of water at all times.

(over)
The taking of water from St. Mary's River would not in my opinion interfere with the irrigation rights of anyone because of the fact that the Department appears to have the only irrigation rights on the river in this area. As for St. Joseph's Creek, from the intake to its confluence with St. Mary's River is bounded on both sides by property owned by the Department and the Oblate Fathers.

As stated in the Principal's letter the need of a new pipe line is urgent, otherwise a continuance of an adequate supply of water for laundry and other purposes is contingent on the condition of the present old wooden pipe line which has already stated is nearing a condition where it can no longer be repaired.

Andrew Irwin,
Indian Agent.

I also note your statement that there are certain pipes, taps and toilets which require early replacement. I wish to enclose herewith quotation in duplicate from Patmore Bros., Cranbrook, amounting to $382.45 covering the cost of labour and repairs needed for the furnace at the Kootenay Indian Residential School. I may say that part of this work is already done. Mr. Patmore was asked on several occasions to check on the repairs needed and submit a quotation and when at last he got down to the School the Rev. Principal Forbes urged him to get busy immediately on the job.

The teachers and children were catching cold for want of heat. Because of a volume of work with which Mr. Patmore can not cope for want of help, the Principal insisted on his starting on the job when he had a few days to spare, believing as he did that he would have a lot of hospital cases on his hands if the School remained any longer without heat.

Andrew Irwin,
Indian Agent.
Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C.
P.O. Box. 70, Vancouver, B.C.

I enclose letter dated 29th. Ult. addressed to you by Mr. Irwin with reference to repairs to school furnace amounting to $382.45.

I have interviewed Father Forbes and apparently the breakdown in the furnace had not been anticipated and occurred during the middle of the Winter, and had to be carried out immediately.

The remedy for occurrences of this kind is a thorough check over of the school installations at the close of the school year, in order that necessary replacements may be anticipated and provided for. I have advised Father Forbes accordingly, and also that work of this kind must not be undertaken without first referring the order to this office. It is possible that the Department may wish to hold the account until the end of the Fiscal year.

The above would also refer to the enclosed quotation for $38.40 for parts supplied to the furnace, brought to your attention by Mr. Irwin on the 29th. Ult., his letter being enclosed herewith. I am asking Mr. Patmore to furnish me with an account in this connection. It will be noted that I have had Father Forbes endorse the quotation as having received the material.

Following Mr. Phelan's letter of August 31st authorizing the purchase of a new kitchen range for the Kootenay Indian Residential School, we have had considerable correspondence with the late Indian Agent and the Principal of the School with a view to establishing the definite need for a new range. Replying to your letter of the 19th instant, file 155-0-5, with reference to the replacement of the kitchen range at the Kootenay Indian Residential School, I would advise that the writer has just returned from Cranbrook and while there checked over the present installation, discussing it with the Reverend Principal and the Reverend Sister in charge of the kitchen operations. The Reverend Principal, while not very definite, was inclined to the opinion that the range in use functions satisfactorily enough for their requirements with which opinion the Reverend Sister was definitely in disagreement. After looking over the unit while in operation, I am of the opinion it is not functioning properly but that the cause lies outside of the range itself. On the other hand, the unit is getting pretty old and it will only be a matter of a year or two before it requires replacement.

Much of the trouble at this school with mechanical and other installations is that their maintenance and arrangement is entrusted to an individual, Mr. Townsend, described as the School Engineer who, in my opinion, usually succeeds in impairing their usefulness by his "improvements" on the original design, and that this is what has given rise to the continual difficulty with the school engines and the range. In this instance, he has "improved" on the manufacturer's design by installing an auxiliary chimney and also ventilating a very large canopy into the chimney itself, thus crippling its draft.

I am of the opinion that the range suggested by you, No. 224-1, General Steel Wares, is large enough for the purposes of this school and would recommend that it be supplied
conditionally that it be installed by a competent person outside of the school staff and that the canopy be ventilated through one of the windows which could be effected by replacing one of the window panes by a sheet of galvanized iron with a hole cut to permit the pipe passing through and extending about a foot or 18 inches beyond the opening. As the school is of concrete construction, there would be practically no danger of fire. A right hand stove would be preferable to the left hand suggested, if this is obtainable. Stove pipe may be required but could be made up locally if necessary.

For D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

My object in authorizing the Sister to make the purchase was because I thought she could make a selection that would meet her requirements better than I could.

Dear Mr Phelan:

I had always paid for the license for the school radio until last year when the Department sent one free of charge. In the tenth or eleventh month of the preceding fiscal year, the Department sent a license but I had paid for one long before. This is not a request for a license. Would you please let me know whether one is being sent this year so that I may know whether to procure one or not?

Mr Inspector of Schools Frederickson has kindly given me a copy of his report. I consider it a very fair report and would not comment on it were it not for one statement which might very easily be misunderstood. Under "Fire Protection," Mr Frederickson states that the fire extinguishers are "not subject to inspection." This does not mean that he was not permitted to examine them but that, as he explained while he held one in his hands, since the school is not insured, the extinguishers are not subject to inspection by those men whom an Insurance Company would send were the school insured.

There are one or two other very minor points which, likely because I did not mention or explain them, are not quite accurate: for the last two years, the boys have faithfully kept a daily record of egg production; some boys have threaded pipes (i.e., before the inspection); a daily record of milk production was kept by the boys until this winter when the milk fell off badly. Yes, the cows were in poor condition. Like others in the district, our hay crop was a complete failure and it was very difficult to get any hay let alone good hay. As you are away, the Agent had to ship in hay for the Indians and, poor as the hay was which we got, I think that it was considerably better than that which the Agent was able to obtain.

With regard to the remark about home nursing classes, they have been discontinued although they were going well and serving a useful purpose. The nurse asked the Department for necessary supplies, which would have cost under $20.00, but her request was turned down. May I renew her request?

Two days ago, I went to see Mr Acting Agent Caldwell to ask him to make sure that the necessary work on the furnaces, plumbing, pipeline, etc. be done while the pupils are away in July and August. As soon as I mentioned the first point, he showed me the 1945-1946 requisition which does not mention these matters. That greatly surprised me especially as the Department had two men make reports on this....which shows that I had asked that the work be done. (A very little of the most urgent work was done). What surprised me even more was that the requisition asked for things that were not only requested in the previous year but were supplied by the Department last year. I have written at length on the matter to the Acting Agent.

All are in good health.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B. C.

In reply to your letter of the 29th ultimo, file 5-11-3, I beg to advise that I have discussed the matter of repairs to the Kootenay Indian Residential School with Father Forbes and beg to enclose a list of requirements at the school.

(1) Water in Basement.

Water is coming into the basement from some unknown source and until this is remedied it will not be possible to fire the furnaces as it is coming up under both furnaces. Father Forbes says the water only recently started to come into the basement and for a few days was about a foot in depth. At the time of my visit most of the water was being carried away by the drain pipe, but there was quite a stream of water going through the basement. It appears to me that this water water is likely coming from the old pipe line from Josephs Creek, which formerly supplied the old school and which is used in the lumber yard stable at present. This pipe is badly installed many years ago and is in very bad condition. Mr. Warren's report of June 29th refers to this pipe line having been installed previous to 1923. I would suggest this be referred to the Dominion Water Power to determine the source from which this water is coming and means of correcting.

(2) Plumbing.

In very unsanitary condition. See Mr. Patmore's report. Tender enclosed.

(3) Caulking windows and filling cornices.

Further to our memorandum of the 2nd instant, the estimate of cost of repair work to the plumbing system at the above has now been received and, accordingly, the following comments are submitted for your information:

In accordance with instructions from this office, Mr. Snelson, who carried out the inspection, has grouped items to show repairs he considers should be carried out at once and others which are of secondary importance.

We have no Indian Affairs Record Drawings or Specifications of the School and, therefore, have no information regarding the extent or quality of the existing system but, from Mr. Snelson's report, it would appear that the plumbing installation is in need of almost complete renovation. The items which have been described as immediately necessary embody replacements of self-closing basin taps, compression faucets, toilet bowls, urinal and toilet flush tanks and fittings, toilet seats, seat operated flush valves, renewal of traps, waste lines, vent lines and floor drains. Repairs and replacements are necessary for a number of shower and bath tub fittings and several new basins are required. Mr. Snelson also considers that a specially built scullery sink and several kitchen type sinks with drain board are required at once. If carried out independently, this division of the work is estimated to cost approximately $2,200.00.

Other plumbing work which Mr. Snelson considers necessary, but which is described as being of secondary importance, includes new piping for the water supply to washing machines in the laundry, cleaning out of coils and other piping in laundry machines and provision of a 500 gallon storage tank with an emersion type indirect water heater for laundry hot water supply, the provision of a small steam line to a grease trap and new piping to a sink in the school dairy. These secondary plumbing items are estimated to cost approximately $800.00.

In this connection, an excerpt from Mr. Snelson's report reads:

"Would like to have 1 - 500 gallon tank to heat wash water by means of an inside steam coil."

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, ONTARIO.

We interpret this to indicate that inclusion or omission of the item is optional. If the tank and heater were omitted, the estimated cost of $800.00 for secondary plumbing work, according to Mr. Snelson's figures, would be reduced by $650.00.

In his report, Mr. Snelson comments separately on the condition of the domestic hot water supply. He states that the present water heater which is supplied with steam from the high pressure boiler, and, therefore, only operative when that boiler is in use for laundering, has become plugged with lime encrustation and is not of very little value. He recommends the installation of a new jacket type domestic hot water heater which could be used independently with a much less expensive type of fuel. The cost of this piece of new equipment, with piping and accessories, completely installed, is estimated at approximately $154.00. We believe this item should be included when considering other plumbing items of secondary importance.

An analysis of Mr. Snelson's enumeration of replacements for fittings to plumbing fixtures indicates a high quality and expensive type of material which, we assume, is similar in manufacture and operation to the existing equipment. It is doubtful if replacements for such articles as seat-controlled flush valves can be obtained without considerable difficulty under present conditions, but to attempt conversion to other types of flush control might necessitate replacement of the complete toilet unit and add greatly to the expense.

Mr. Snelson's estimate of cost for repairs and replacements has been analyzed and, under the circumstances, appears reasonable.

Since so large a proportion of the total cost is for work requiring immediate consideration, we feel that the most economical procedure would be to carry out all work referred to in the report at the same time.

Under these conditions, to cover the cost of materials, labour and supervision, an amount of approximately $3,500.00 should be made available by the Indian Affairs branch. If it is not considered necessary to install the storage tank and heater for laundry operations, this amount could be reduced to $2,850.00.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

I received your letter some time ago but am replying only now as the Kitchen range has just been received. I had to pay a freight bill of $193 because the range was sent via Vancouver (it takes a passenger train two nights & a day to return from Vancouver) whereas it should have been shipped via Lethbridge to save time & considerable expense. Our old range smoked terribly in spite of our efforts to repair it, so not only I but especially the pupils, are very grateful for the new range.

We officially closed the school on June 30th but had to keep 7 children for cases until yesterday. We got 5 excellent books for the course in home nursing from the local hospital at half price, about $10. The new hospital baby will cost more than the remaining 10% grant but I believe that what the older girls & Indian women will learn will justify the added cost.

As usual, the health & conduct of the pupils have been very good. Would you gentlemen men an Indian school?

Over 4 years without raising the strap on the boys once! That is my record.

Dear Mr. Barre:

I know that the Department does not, as a rule, pay bills contracted by Principals unless the latter have been given authority to contract those bills. I know, also, that the Department wishes Principals to do their utmost to prevent a fire especially in Schools where there is practically no fire protection. I would, therefore, request that the Department pay the bill which will be submitted by Mr. MacKay.

Some time ago, some boys and I rushed into the School as, judging from the dense column of smoke issuing from behind it, we feared that there was a fire in the School. Fortunately, it was no more than a rather serious chimney fire which started in or backed up into the long, large pipe from the kitchen range to the chimney. On several occasions, I had spoken to a man, who should be competent in this matter, about the advisability of having the chimneys cleaned. He said that there was no need of this because they were so large and had such a draught that soot would not collect in them. He mentioned also that they had never been cleaned in so far as he knew. Moreover, were there any need to clean them, the Department would have seen to it, when the School was built, that there were clean-out places in the chimneys. There are none.

Some time before and after the chimney fire occurred, the old kitchen range smoked badly. I had three men examine it and I had it thoroughly cleaned but the smoke continued to fill the kitchen. They could not understand this as the draught is very strong. Then, recently, I heard that Mr. MacKay was in town and I asked him to try to help us. He found so much soot in the pipe from the range to the chimney that he said that it had not been cleaned for 10 years. He refused to believe me when I assured him that I had had it properly thoroughly cleaned. He cleaned it and the stove, and it still smoked. He cleaned the stove again and, when he looked at the pipe he had cleaned, a few days before, he was amazed at the amount of soot that had already gathered. He then found the cause which I understand to be this: When the pipe was put in, how many years ago I cannot say, it was not put into one of two flues but was misplaced so that instead of the smoke and soot going into one of the flues, they struck the partition between the two flues so that the smoke and soot recoiled and blew back into the pipe leading from the range. Some of the soot had lodged at, below and above where the pipe entered the chimney. There was also a great deal of smoke in the laundry and there was difficulty with the stove there although these pipes (like others) had been cleaned and renewed. Part of the cause was improper connections of the pipes into this other chimney and part was that, before I came here, someone had made alterations or repairs and had left the loose bricks in the chimney flue. There was considerable soot in this chimney.

I felt that had the Commissioner or any other Official been here and had he known of the chimney fire and had he heard what the chimney sweep, Mr. MacKay, said of the situation, he would have ordered me to have the work done immediately. I am having it done because I am sure that the Department wants to prevent a fire as much as I do. I have asked Mr. MacKay to
inspect all chimneys and to do whatever work is really necessary. This will involve some work on the old kitchen range which we have to use until alterations are made to the new one and part received. The matter was recently brought to the attention of the Department. It will involve, also, a little work on the laundry stove....Mr. MacKay has made clean-outs in the chimneys. He has been here for about a week and has had a helper part of the time.

I did not consult you officially because I felt that you would have to take the matter up with Vancouver and perhaps Ottawa and I wished to have Mr. MacKay do the work before he left town because I had heard, rightly or wrongly, that the local chimney sweep is at times careless.

Yours truly,

(sgd) G. Forbes, O.M.I.
Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B. C., P. O. Box 70, Vancouver, B. C.

Please find enclosed a letter from Reverend Principal Forbes, together with voucher #185 in favour of Mr. George MacKay, chimney sweep.

When I inspected the fire extinguisher equipment at the school, I inquired about cleaning of the chimneys and suggested that this work should be done before the winter.

Soon afterwards Father Forbes hired George MacKay, who discovered that the chimney needed alterations and proceeded to do the work.

I did not authorize this work, however, on inspection of the work done by Mr. MacKay, I found that it was required.

The pipe from the kitchen range ran into two flues (as shown in diagram 2, marked in red), as a result soot and smoke recoiled into the pipe. It was, therefore, necessary to tear a new hole for the pipe to fit in the one flue and cement the other, which connects with a fire place in a room upstairs. I should add that this chimney had no clean-out and one was made, the necessary parts being obtained from Patmore Bros. I understand that Patmore Bros. will submit an account of about $9.00 for clean-out, canopy pipes, etc.

Diagram 1, marked in blue, will show the alterations made to the laundry stove pipes. The twenty-eight foot length of stove pipe was obstructed by loose bricks and soot and therefore required cleaning. All connections were made secure by means of stove bolts. The stove used for heating irons was moved from the ironing room into the laundry room, about fourteen feet from the hot water stove and direct connections made to that pipe. The stoves were both in use at the time of my visit and operating satisfactorily. I should add that the chimneys were also cleaned.

In view of the circumstances surrounding this case, the fact that the work done would undoubtedly been approved by the Department on acquaintance with this fire hazard, and the early replacement of Father Forbes as School Principal, I would recommend that the enclosed voucher be approved and paid through this office.

I am enclosing a second letter with reference to the work still required for the new kitchen range.

J. M. Barre,
Acting Indian Agent.

Ottawa, Ontario
