Dear Sir:

Having been appointed Principal of the Kootenay Indian Residential School, Cranbrook, B.C., I wish to report on conditions as I find them upon entering my term as Principal.

I have made a thorough investigation of the school and find conditions extremely bad. I beg of you to take serious consideration of the following observations and authorize immediate action.

Living conditions are a disgrace to the Department. The building gives a fair impression from the outside but the interior is most unfavourable. Due to faulty plumbing a very unpleasant and disgusting odor prevails throughout the house. This is more pronounced in the section reserved for the boys and for a very obvious reason. Forty-six boys are limited to the use of one toilet, that is, one individual toilet bowel. All the toilets in both lavatories at the disposal of the boys are out of order except one. All the urinals are blocked and cannot be used. The odor of them surpasses description. The wash-basins in the boys section are for the most part out of order. The waste pipes are encased in the wall and cannot be opened or cleaned. The taps are out of order. It is impossible to expect forty-six boys to properly use one toilet. When it ceases to function, and indications are that that will not be far distant, what are we to do? Personally I would say it were better to leave the children at home than to subject them to the unsanitary conditions of their present quarters. At home, some of them at least, would have the partial decency of 'outdoor plumbing'. Here they have much worse.

The boys are limited to the use of three bath-tubs, placed end to end without partitions or separations of any kind. These tubs are antiquated and should be replaced. There is not one shower in the whole house, either for the boys the girls or the staff.

I think it is agreed that it is part of our duty to teach hygienic methods, decency, and cleanliness. How is it possible to do so under these conditions. Instead of learning hygiene and cleanliness they are subjected to learn immorality of the basest kind.

The toilets in the girls section of the building are in a better repair but still leave much to be desired. The basins and
Kootenay Indian School
Cranbrook, B.C.

Taps are in need of repair.

I understand from the disciplinarians in charge of the dormitories that it is the order of the Dept. that the dormitories be locked at night. I do not take objection to that but the order does not provide for toilet facilities during the night. The toilets cannot be reached directly from the dormitories but only by the use of the corridor, which corridor cannot be reached when the doors are locked. This condition prevails in both the boys and girls dormitories. This necessitates the use of chambers during the night. A number of these are placed at the disposal of the boys and girls. Picture a dormitory of forty or fifty being subjected to such a public, indecent, and filthy practice. When the doors are unlocked in the morning the odor is thoroughly disgusting. Practically every night one or other of the chambers is overflowed or upset. The dormitory floors and the ceilings below tell the rest. The disciplinarians are not at fault. They are doing their duty under most trying conditions. The layout of the building is at fault. The dormitories must give access to the toilets during the night. Surely this is only common decency.

I know that all this has been investigated by the proper authorities. I see from reports on file that for a number of years back requests have been made regarding the toilets and baths in this institution and yet nothing has been done. I have contacted the plumber recommended for work here, Mr. Patmore of Cranbrook, requesting that he do something if only of a temporary measure to give the necessary facilities that we may carry on and he says nothing can be done with the present system, all must be renewed. What are we to do while waiting for the necessary action on the part of the dept.? There is a situation here which is a positive discredit to the Dept. and places the children in an unhealthy and unsanitary environment.

The building has neither adequate ventilation or insulation. I have not yet spent a winter here but every member of the staff whom I have interviewed and I have interviewed them all has complained of the lack of heat during the winter months. Judging from the cost of the fuel in the past and the size of the building it would seem that heat was being lost through lack of insulation. I have already read reports of the unsatisfactory condition of the boiler-room, the heating plant and the water system. Four times in the past week the water system has been out of order.

The engineer informs me that a new set of batteries is necessary for the present lighting unit. The present batteries will not hold a charge over night sufficient to give light in the morning. The power unit has to be kept going the greater part of the day in order to keep up a supply of electricity and this is very costly as it burns.
gasoline. I have been informed that a Lister engine was installed but that it proved unsatisfactory. At present we rise in the dark or with a very faint yellow glimmer from the imperfect lights. Surely you do not expect a staff of teachers to live under such conditions.

The laundry is not what it should be. The clothes are washed in hard water. The washing machines are out of date. The steam drier works very imperfectly. The ironing is done by flat irons heated on a stove. Separate equipment is not provided for laundering the clothing of the staff. Surely we are not expected to have our laundry mixed with that of the children and yet no provision otherwise has been made.

There is no scullery. The dishes are washed on tables in the corridor between the kitchen and the refectory. Picture a number of girls with dish pans washing the dishes for almost a hundred children. It hardly impresses them with modern kitchen methods.

I understand that a new stove was granted to the school during the past year. It is in the kitchen but not in operation. A stove with a water jacket was requested. One was sent minus the jacket. There is no hot water in the kitchen except what is heated on the top of the old stove by the use of kettles. Dish water has to be heated in this improper and unsatisfactory manner.

Similar conditions prevail throughout every part of the building. I am aware that Mr. Coleman gave it a thorough inspection last year and has reported on it. I also know that our present Indian agent realizes the unsatisfactory living conditions and that he is just as eager as I am to have them improved.

One of the basic steps in improving this institution is to provide adequate electrical power. That would be the foundation to eliminate much of the trouble. A power line is within reasonable distance and yet we are denied its advantages.

I know that this school has been severely criticised for its lack of development in agriculture but I beg you not to expect any improvement in this regard until the unsatisfactory living conditions as outlined above are eliminated. Give us decent living conditions and modern equipment and I pledge my word that we will give in return not only an adequate agricultural course but an entire school program second to none in the province.

Trusting that this report will receive your kind attention and just consideration,

I remain,

Sincerely yours,

The Dept. of Indian Affairs, Federal Government.

Having been asked by Mr. A. Irwin, Indian Agent for a report on the Sanitary conditions in regards to the Plumbing etc., at the Kootenay Residential School, St. Eugene Mission, we hereby make the following report:

Practically all Plumbing fixtures date 1912. There are fifteen J.L. Mott Toilets, Suspendo type, with Flushometer and tank action. Also nine Mott Compacto floor type with same flush action. While the porcelain pans or bowls are mostly in good shape the Flushometers on all the toilets are due for replacement, also it would be necessary to replace many seats that are broken and patched up, as the Toilets are flushed by seat action.

There were originally 36 basins in boys and girls Dormitories and washroom. Any that have been broken have been taken out or left on the wall without any replacements. The waste pipes for all these basins, four batteries of nine each, are in the outside concrete wall. Iron pipes with lead stubs through plaster and wainscoting. The traps soldered to the stubs. No cleanouts available. Numbers of these lead stubs are leaking behind the wall and running on the floor. To repair would mean (and in many places have already been done, leaving an unsightly appearance) cutting out wainscoting and plaster and cement. Would advise accessible wastes with proper cleanouts.

Nine Urinals are in filthy condition, often plugged, (as I found them all at time of writing) with no cleanouts available making cleaning difficult.

Bathing Facilities are three - five foot leg tubs, no partitions, in each of boys and girls Dormitories, to serve approximately 45 boys and 45 girls. Three showers in each of boys and girls basements have been out of commission for years and are obsolete. Mostly have been out of commission and are gone. If put in condition would greatly add to bathing facilities.

You have a report by a Mr. Warren on the Domestic Water supply, three years ago. This water not being Automatic, the pressure varies from nothing up to one hundred pounds. The Toilets of the Flushometer type need a good pressure for flushing, consequently when pressure gets down the toilets being used are not flushing properly, leave a very unsanitary condition. In this regards, Self closing Taps should be used, or installed on all washing basins used by the pupils, as when water pressure is down the pupils leave the taps open and when the water pressure is pumped up again it causes numerous floods from basins overflowing. Installing the above taps would save a great deal of pumping. All these old taps with the exception of a couple of pair, are over thirty years old and due for replacement.

In the Laundry all new taps are needed and some repairs and replacements to traps.

The Domestic Water supply is very hard water and they have tried most of the known water softeners on the market without success. Soap will absolutely not lather. The best they can get white sheets and clothes, although is a very dirty grey, with a very bad odor. There is a soft water line from St. Joseph's Creek, (Typhoid water) which used to be in use for the washers only, but this being an old 3" wooden pipe, needs renewing. Alternative would be to pump water from St. Mary's river, both being equal distance, approx. 600 feet.

School: The Kootenay Residential School was inspected before the school opened with reference to added fire extinguisher protection. Dear Sir:

For some years past we have supplied and installed electrical equipment in the Kootenay Residential School. This equipment, for the most part, was used for generating electrical energy. Despite the fact that only the finest equipment was supplied, and that every effort was made to complete a first class installation, results have been very unsatisfactory. You have requested that we make a survey of this situation and give you a report on the condition of the equipment as it stands, and, if possible, the best solution to the problem of supplying adequate electrical energy to the Kootenay School.

Our report is as follows - and no attempt has been made to mince words.

The batteries are in deplorable condition. They show every evidence of being operated for long periods in a discharged condition. The high sediment deposit is now partially short circuiting the plates and is due to the fact that they have several times been subjected to reverse current from the charging generator. In short, if anything like economical operation is to be obtained they will have to be replaced. No battery manufacturer ever designed a battery to operate under conditions to which these batteries have been subjected.

The condition of the Lister Diesel engine is truly disgraceful. This fine piece of equipment has been so maltreated that it could not possibly give proper service. In fact it is doubtful whether the necessary repairs to this engine would be an economically sound investment. There is scarcely a part on the entire machine that does not show evidence of careless abuse. The large ten kilowatt Westinghouse Generator, while in operating condition, is not the most suitable unit for use with the existing switch board equipment. This unit and panelboard is far from modern in design and when carelessly operated will at times reverse itself to the detriment of the batteries as noted above.
The four kilowatt generator, which was connected to the Petters Diesel engine, is in such a dilapidated condition that it will not even operate. Both rotor bearings are ruined and the armature is so covered with grime that only removal for shop test would determine its condition.

From the foregoing you can readily see that your department has on its hands a considerable amount of equipment in very poor condition even though in the last decade it has spent thousands of dollars in an effort to provide electrical facilities to the school in question.

You requested that we submit our solution, if any, to your problem. We feel we have a solution and submit it after considerable thought. We have in it nothing to sell, or, are we in any way connected with those that may have. We offer this recommendation in the full knowledge that its acceptance would remove a definite condition, which has been such a continual expense to the department and such an aggravation to the operators of the school.

In reasonable proximity to the school building there is a source of hydro electric power. In our opinion, every effort should be made to obtain electrical energy from these lines. Despite the fact that a somewhat larger initial cost would be involved, the department would rid itself of purchasing and maintaining electrical generating equipment.

Much stress has been placed of late by both Provincial and Dominion Governments on the need of extending electrical facilities to rural outlets. The Kootenay Residential School is definitely a rural outlet and nowhere does there exist a greater need for an abundance of electrical energy than at this school.

Your department saw fit to install electric refrigeration in this building some years ago. Since its installation this refrigerator has been in service less than fifty percent of the time, for the simple reason that there has seldom been sufficient electric current available to operate it. In an institution of this kind, refrigeration is vitally necessary yet the operators of the school are denied this facility for lack of adequate power.
The water system in this school is operated by an engine driven pump manually controlled. No water can be obtained until some person operates the pump. If there was sufficient electrical energy available, the system could be motorized and automatically controlled, thus supplying an abundance of water at all times. With normal water pressure the toilets, etc., could be operated satisfactorily.

We believe your present problem is a matter of deciding whether or not to spend a considerable sum of money in restoring to operation, a local electrical system of known inadequacy and limited life or soundly investing in an abundance of hydro power for the future. We trust we have given you the information you desire.

Yours truly,

MODERN ELECTRIC

Dear Sir:

In 1939 or 1940 I had some correspondence with Father Collins then Principal of the St. Eugene Indian Mission Schools and Mr. Walker, Supervising Engineer - Department of Mines & Resources, Banff, Alberta and also in 1941 with Mr. Irvine Indian Agent of Cranbrook, B. C. regarding the supply of power to the Kootenay Indian School, as it is apparently now called.

It may be possible that you can refer back to this correspondence and you will then have a fair picture of what was involved in this case. I will give you a brief outline on the situation.

First, the Transmission Line to the Kimberley Airport and transformer supplying it, is owned by the Department of Transport and they feel very rightly that their power supply to the Airport must be protected. Therefore, we cannot supply the school with power without first the Department of Indian Affairs coming to an arrangement with the Department of Transport.

Second, the question of rates would also have to be settled with the Department of Transport. If we could be advised that the two Departments are agreeable to cooperate, then we would be glad to give you revised estimates of the cost of the line and necessary equipment. The last costs I have on this proposed line as made up in 1940 were $6,200.00 but there have been increases in labour and material costs since then that would make a revised estimate as much as 20% higher.
The length of line, according to my records, is 3½ miles but this would have to be checked by actual survey.

We would have to be granted free Right-of-Way for the line through the Indian Reserve but this should not be difficult as you would own the line yourselves in any case as your consumption being small does not produce sufficient revenue to carry the cost of the line.

When I have an opportunity, I will drop in and see you at the school but in the meantime, if you can do anything through your department towards obtaining permission to use the Department of Transport transformers and line, and arrive at a decision as to what your power costs from the Department of Transport would be, then I suggest that you do so as soon as possible.

Your File 155-0-5

I have your letter of December 18th in which you advise that the matter of securing power from the East Kootenay Power Company Ltd., for St. Eugene Indian Residential School, Cranbrook, has again been brought before the Department.

In November last I had an opportunity to visit this school, being in the district in connection with the competition being held to fill the existing vacancy on the Kootenay Indian Agency establishment, when this question of supplying electrical energy to the school from the power lines of the above-noted Company was discussed at some length with Reverend Principal Kelly.

It will be recalled that this matter was before the Department in 1941, but the cost was considered prohibitive at the time with the result that a Lister 16 H.P. diesel engine and a set of batteries were supplied, the cost of the engine and batteries being $2042.75.

The school experienced difficulty with this engine from the outset, whether this was due to lack of proper care and attention on the part of the school engineer or some weakness in the unit itself when supplied, we have not been able to definitely determine.

Following complaints made in December, 1943, by Reverend G. Forbes, then Principal of the school, regarding this plant, I arranged for Inspector Coleman who was in the district in connection with a status investigation, to visit the school and report on the situation. Inspector Coleman secured the services of Mr. J. Bayes, an engineer in the employ of the Caterpillar Tractor Company, to look over the plant and submit a report. Mr. Bayes' report, together with that of Inspector Coleman were forwarded to the Department with my letter 215-5-2047 dated...
March 17th, 1944, so that the Department has been kept informed with respect to the power situation at this school.

At the request of Acting Agent Barre, Mr. J. A. Ward, of the Modern Electric Company, which firm supplied the Lister engine and batteries in 1941, recently examined the plant and his report on his findings is also enclosed. It will be observed that Mr. Ward is satisfied that this problem at the school can best be met by connecting up with the East Kootenay Power Co. Ltd.

Rev. Father Kelly approached the East Kootenay Power Co. Ltd., in October last regarding the supply of power to the school and was informed that the cost to connect the school with the nearest power line would be in the neighborhood of $7,000.00, and further that the scheme would be contingent on the Department being able to make arrangements with the Department of Transport and accepting responsibility for the maintenance of the line.

I may say that even should the Department approve of the purchase of power from the East Kootenay Power Co. Ltd., which I think is desirable, and would in the long run be much more economical than to continue purchasing expensive equipment to develop power at the Kootenay School, it is unlikely that funds could be made available until the 1946-47 fiscal year and in any case it would take considerable time to complete negotiations with the Department of Transport and the East Kootenay Power Co. Ltd. The first move, of course, would be for the Department to approach the Department of Transport in the matter and secure their consent to the use of their transmission line and transformer supplying it, which equipment is owned by that Department.

In the meantime provision should be made to keep the existing plant in operation. The old Otto engine and the present set of batteries cannot be relied on for any length of time and consequently it will likely be necessary to purchase new batteries and have the Lister engine repaired.

I am satisfied that the only permanent solution for the trouble at Cranbrook will be to procure our power requirements from the East Kootenay Power Co. Ltd., and any arrangement we make now to put the existing plant in good condition can, after all, be only regarded as a temporary measure.

D. M. Mackay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Mr. Boys:

I find it necessary to take up with you the difficulties we have been encountering during the past few months with the water pump in this school.

Since November of '45 we have had three serious breakdowns including the present one. I am advised by Mr. Hayden of Patmore Bros. and Mr. Knight of Cranbrook Auto Wreckers that it is beyond repair and so we have on our hands a serious emergency.

Before giving what information I have regarding it I would like to point out that the light, heat, and water facilities of this school all directly depend on the proper functioning of this pump. This is so because the engine used to operate the generator necessitates a constant stream of water passing through its cooling system during operation. The heating system is hot water and hence the water pressure must be maintained or else the furnace will be burned out. As the pump in question is both a suction and pressure pump we have to depend upon it for drawing the water from the 5000 gallon reservoir and maintaining it under pressure in the pressure tank. Hence you will see the predicament we are in when it fails us.

Our most serious breakdown was on Saturday November 24th. From Saturday morning until Monday afternoon we had neither water, light, or heat. With the temperature below freezing that is a serious matter. We had the necessary repairs made at our own expense. The base of the water chamber was found to be so deteriorated with rust that it was
almost impossible to weld it. However I had hoped that it would last until time for the yearly requisitions at which time I intended to mention it. As the matter of installing more satisfactory lighting equipment was on hand at the time of the breakdown I preferred to delay the question of a new pump until later. Since then we have had two more breakdowns and our present position is desperate. It is found that two of the pistons are cracked thus rendering it impossible to insert the packing so as to prevent water escaping. At the present time one of the pistons is entirely out of order and the water pumped by the other two escapes through the third and pressure cannot be raised or maintained.

The local firms mentioned above both say that this is the original pump installed in the school when it was built in 1912. I cannot find here any record of its installation but there is probably a reference to it in the Vancouver Office. If, as I am told, it has been operating since 1912, some thirty years, it is not surprising that it has ceased to function.

A name plate on its side gives the following information. Manufactured by Goulds of Seneca Lake, N.Y., and supplied to Fairbanks Morse Ltd. with offices in Vancouver and Winnipeg. There is no indication as to its capacity but Mr. Hayden of Patmore Bros. estimated its capacity at 2000 gallons per hour. It is manually controlled, belt driven from a 7 H.P. Petters Diesel Engine. It draws the water approximately a quarter of a mile and raises it not more than 15 feet in that distance. The water is drawn through a 3'' pipe. Its action is by three pistons, 5'' in diameter and 18'' in length, mounted on a crankshaft. Each piston has a separate intake and exhaust valve.
Due to its antiquity and the lack of records here that is about the sum total of the information I can supply regarding it. On the matter of its urgency I do not feel that I can say too much and the facts are here to back up what I say. Were it possible to do so I would gladly wait until the annual requisition for supplies and equipment but the present situation is an emergency. I have enquired locally as to the possibility of renting or borrowing a pump to keep us going until a new one could be shipped in but none of the local firms carry equipment sufficiently heavy to meet our needs.

I trust you will understand the seriousness of this situation and give us your immediate cooperation in the matter.

Assuring you of our constant support and loyalty in the cause for which we are working, I remain,

Sincerely yours,

G.F. Kelly,
Principal.
Cranbrook, B.C.

Dear Mr. Phalen:

I am in receipt of your letter of January 31, and wish to thank you for the direction given therein. I will endeavour to follow your advice in making up our next quarterly reports and henceforward.

I appreciate your allowance of supernumerary grant for the extra pupils we have at this school. In undertaking some minor repairs and improvements which I felt were urgent as well as purchasing some winter sports equipment, such as toboggans, ski-suits for the girls, and hockey gear, I have incurred a few expenses which the added grant will take care of very conveniently. I feel very keenly the need here for more sports, pro-rec., and P.T. training as I am a great believer in keeping them busy. A great deal of the indolence and lack of initiative which we see on the part of the young men who have graduated from here in past years seems to me to point to a lack of organized sport and recreational facilities. I do hope that we will be able to continue developing our school along these lines.

During the months which have passed since September we have seen some very good improvements in our plumbing. Much of the work that was requisitioned has been completed and some is still in progress. We are still lacking repairs to the flush-action toilets but I understand this is unavoidable as the parts cannot be obtained. I hope they will be able to get them before next month or else that the allowance for the work can be extended.

I hope some progress is being made in the matter of more adequate power. Some months ago I reported on the need of the Kootenay Power to replace our present set-up. I have read with great interest all the correspondence of the past years regarding this question and besides being a source of constant conflict between the Principals and the Dept. I would judge that it has been a very expensive affair. What has been spent in the past ten or fifteen years on batteries, the Lister Engine, the generators, and the old Otto gas engine would go far in installing proper A.C. current. And in spite of all the expenses we stand today in a very precarious position not knowing from one hour to another whether or not we will have light. From the school one can see the Kootenay Power line crossing at the end of our farm and still we are denied the benefits of its use. Coupling that with all we are hearing about rural electrification from both the provincial and federal govts. one can only conclude that here is a first class opportunity.
to put into action a program which would not only interest the rest of the community in electrification but would also be, in a matter of a few years, a definite saving to your Dept.

During Major McKay's recent visit he promised to urge this matter to the best of his ability. While I know such an installation can't come overnight I hope it has not just been filed and forgotten. Why should the equipment of this school be the laughing stock of every repair-shop in town? They all think it a great joke that so much has been spent here on Diesel and gas engines and still we are in never-ending trouble. Their attitude to the equipment is extended to the whole school program, and while we should have an institution that would merit the admiration of the community, we have instead one, which, like our Indians themselves, is only tolerated.

There is no need for such a condition. We have the opportunity here to give these children an education and training which will elevate them to their rightful position in life. I have pledged myself to this task and take my word for it, Mr. Phalen, I will see it through. Give us the cooperation we need and we will give in return a school at which no man can point his finger and say it is inefficient.

There is a great scope here for development. These children need not only class training but vocational guidance in agriculture, carpentry, and the trades. This is an extensive program and it will take time, but already we are getting it under way and I assure you that when you again have an opportunity to visit us we will show you that our purpose has not been in vain.

I have had the good fortune of employing a farm instructor who has had experience at other schools of the Dept. and the deplorable conditions spoken of in Mr. Coleman's recent report are being gradually but definitely converted. We are making use of the services of the National Film Board to give scope to our education and I intend in the near future to petition the Dept. to supply us with a projector of our own so that we may more extensively use this modern and practical means of education. I have delayed asking for it in the hope that we would have the Kootenay Power to operate it instead of another individual power plant such as is used in rural areas.

To return for a moment to the matter of the pupilage grant. Some months ago I sent a request that our pupilage be raised. As you know we are at present over our pupilage allowance. While we appreciate the supernumerary grant I feel we could accommodate more children. With certain minor adjustments in dormitory space, which I have discussed with the Indian Agent, we could accommodate up to one hundred and ten. As you know one of the big drawbacks here for a number of years to any program of improvement, even to the maintenance of a qualified staff,
has been financial embarrassment. The added grant for fifteen or twenty pupils would give us encouragement to make our school what we would like to have it.

When building material becomes more available I hope to draft plans for a recreational centre that will give us some opportunity for training. A recreational hall 27' x 30' is hardly adequate for the pent up energy of forty-five or fifty boys. There is a tendency to kick the walls out. We have no gymnasium and hence cannot have basketball, badminton, boxing or wrestling. As a result we have a group of round-shouldered, under-developed, and effeminate looking boys instead of the type of young manhood we like to see.

A few weeks ago we had to put in a request for a new water pump. I don't know whether or not that request reached you in Ottawa but if it did be assured that it is genuine and urgent. We have had a series of breakdowns during the fall and winter and some expensive repairs made by local firms. They all say the same. It is worn out and finished. I had hoped that it would last until the end of the school year but right now we cannot get pressure up and it is only working spasmodically. I have been expecting to hear from Major McKay on it. It is the original pump supplied to the school in 1912 so it is not surprising that it is giving trouble. If it comes to your hand please help us out.

I hope I will see the day when these material concerns are put in order so that we can settle down to the real business of conducting the school program. To date I have spent more time either working with the engineer trying to keep things in operation or seeking repairs in Cranbrook than I have in attending to the proper concern of a principal. I know you are not to blame for such a condition but anything you can do to help remedy it will be appreciated. In return we will try to give the best of our ability and time to the work on hand.

Please excuse the length to which this has developed. Be assured of our cooperation and accept our sincere thanks for favours received.

I remain,

Sincerely yours,

G.F. Kelly
Principal.
Cranbrook, B. C.

Dear Father Kelly:

I have your letter of the 12th instant, with reference to the situation at the Kootenay School.

You refer in your letter to the matter of more adequate power for the school. Our information is that it would cost in the neighborhood of $7,500.00 to connect the school with the East Kootenay Power Company, and further, that the scheme would be contingent upon the Department being able to make arrangements with the Department of Transport and we would also be required to accept responsibility for the maintenance of the line. You will realize that this is a very heavy expenditure, and in view of the many demands upon our appropriation, it is simply impossible for us to consider it at the present time. However, on the recommendation of Commissioner MacKay, we have requested our Purchasing Branch to secure a new set of batteries.

I was interested in noting the many improvements that you have made and intend to make at this school, and I trust that one of these improvements is the employment of an engineer who will properly look after the mechanical plant. While you are in no way responsible, the correspondence that we have received during recent years indicates that much of the trouble at the Kootenay School with the mechanical plant has been caused by the engineer in charge not having the necessary ability to handle the plant properly. This statement is further instanced by the necessity for supplying new batteries at this time. The last set of batteries was supplied in 1941 and ordinarily should last for seven years. As a matter of fact, at schools where batteries are properly cared for, they have lasted longer than the term mentioned.

I have to refer to my letter of January 29th in connection with the overhaul of the 4 kw. generator at the Kootenay Indian Residential School, and previous correspondence regarding the supply of new batteries.

I shall advise you on receipt of any further information and in the meantime would request that action be taken to supply the new batteries required as soon as possible and that authority be granted to overhaul the 4 kw. generator referred to.

Welfare and Training:

The Kootenay Indian School under the efficient leadership of Reverend Gerald Kelly, O.M.I., has made very steady progress during this quarter. The pupils are making rapid progress in their classroom studies, domestic science, and manual training. The tubercular patients have shown very satisfactory improvements. There has been little or no sickness in school during this quarter except for five cases of measles, one reported on December 17th and four on December 29th. Antimesas serum was used on the contacts and it is hoped that this epidemic will reach no great proportions. The pupils are well nourished and their health is carefully looked after by Sister Marion Clare. The pupils were vaccinated against smallpox, and will be vaccinated against typhoid as soon as the measles is over. The school is well supplied with milk, eggs, vegetables and fruit.

This school carries eight pupils in excess of its quota. Three Auld children, who do not belong to the reserves, will be returned home as soon as the quarantine on measles permits; however, this still leaves us short of space for twelve pupils from the Columbia lake and Shuswap Reserves who should be returned to school, not only for their own good but as a matter of discipline. This matter has been referred to the Department and I am awaiting a reply before taking any action.

The fire extinguishers requisitioned for the school were finally received, and fire drills are held as per regulations. One unscheduled rehearsal was held at 5:00 o'clock last morning when the new fireman and night watchman inadvertently pulled the fire alarm. This proved to be a good and successful fire drill. In addition to the night watchman and fireman, Rev. Father Kelly has hired a new farm manager, who has good recommendations.

On my last inspection it was noted that good work had been done in reconditioning the girls play room, several chairs having successfully been re-upholstered with bright materials. Kindergarten tables and temporary chairs as well as other objects have been fashioned in the Manual Training department. The domestic science department does excellent work in cooking under the direction of Sister John Anthony and Sister Catherine Mary's sewing classes produced very good work. The pantry and hallway near the father's dining room has also been redecorated.

The situation with reference to the plumbing at the school is still bad, even though some of the toilets were temporarily repaired, flush actions, etc., are so far unobtainable. One urinal near the boys dormitory was put in working order and all taps were replaced.
The situation with regard to power is worse, the Lister engine has not been in operation since it was repaired, having run only for two weeks; the Peters engine, which is used to pump water, recently broke down, the fuel jets being gone. It is now undergoing emergency repairs. This leaves us entirely dependent on an old Otto engine which through Father Kelly's ingenuity was "rigged up" to pump water. This engine consumes gasoline at the rate of nearly a gallon per hour! So that between pumping water and charging batteries which will not hold their charge, it is pounding away from morn till dark. The Peters engine should be repaired in two or three days but the present situation emphasizes the gravity of the situation with reference to the electric generating plant as this school. At my request, Mr. John Ward of the Modern Electric recently submitted a report on this situation and copies of it were forwarded to the Commissioner's office. The water pump has recently caused quite a bit of anxiety, it was leaking so badly that it had to be primed before each pump. It is a very ancient and heavy contraption and it is feared that the base is so corroded that it may give out altogether for the time being it has been packed with oakum, but it may become necessary to call in a welder to weld on a new base.

As a result of Commissioner MacKay's visit, authority was granted to install a new sink unit near the children's dining room. This will prove to be more sanitary and a great improvement for which we feel very grateful.

Rev. Father Kelly has given sporting activities more meaning in this school and he has recently purchased skates and toboggans which the children are enjoying.

J.M. Barre,
Acting Indian Agent.

Welfare & Training:

At the Kootenay Indian School continued progress is being made both in and out of the classroom. The children are well cared for and have an excellent record of health. A number of replacements have been procured for worn out beds in both the boys' and girls' dormitories. A program of cleaning and painting in the lavatories and several changes in plumbing have made for better hygiene, but a continued project for redecoration of the basement passage ways is urgently needed, because it was found impossible to procure replacement parts, the toilets on both sides of the school are still awaiting repairs to seats and flush actions.

The school is carrying several pupils above its dormitory quota, but more pupils could be accommodated comfortably if some small low-cost changes were effected. This would make possible acceptance of a number of school age children from Columbia Lake and Shuswap reserves upon whose parents pressure is being applied to have them send their children to school.

Much trouble has been experienced in recent weeks with lighting and pumping equipment at the school. A series of breakdowns has necessitated repairs to all three power units, overhaul of the emergency 4 k.w. three generator, replacement of water pump and batteries, at considerable cost to the Department and to the discomfort and inconvenience to the residents of the school. The Principal and many of the staff laboured for days with some outside help to restore services to normal. From time to time representations have been made to the Department to have an installation made, connecting the school to the east Kootenay Power Line some two miles distant. Further to my letter of May 23rd concerning the leakage in the water pressure tank at the Kootenay Residential School, I wish to advise that temporary repairs have been attempted with only partial success.

Mr. Draper of Pioneer Motors, experienced in pressure tanks, and formerly engaged in the construction of submarines, informs me that a replacement is absolutely necessary, in which opinion Mr. Hayden, of Patmore Bros., concurs.

The old tank is rusted around its seams and around the rivet holes. Some welding has been done, making it possible, with frequent spells of pumping, to maintain a supply of water. But, for safety's sake, it has been deemed prudent to send for a safety valve to be installed in the pumping system to obviate danger of explosion in the tank, which remains uncovered.

A new tank will have to be built to specifications with tappings as shown in the attached sketch. The present tank 5' x 36' is of approximately 2830 gallons capacity. Mr. Draper is of the opinion that a new tank of 5' diameter or 2000 gallons capacity would be quite large enough. It is proposed to leave the old tank in the ground, fill it with earth and set the new tank on top of it, bringing it endwise so that its end is flush with the inside of the concrete wall of the engine room. In this manner the manhole and water guage would be available from within the engine room itself and a complicated piping system would be eliminated. It would
still be covered by a sufficient depth of soil that there would be no danger of freezing.

This letter is submitted in duplicate to facilitate explanation to the Department. It is hoped that the order may be filled with despatch because of the uncertainty of the temporary repairs.

JVB/DD

Mr. Coleman's report of last year found our dairy barn here in very poor condition and he urged that something be done to improve it. During Major McKay's visit last autumn he directed me to do some necessary work to bring our barn up to modern standards in equipment and layout. The installation of this equipment would give us the opportunity to attend to our dairy cattle as they should be attended to and at the same time teach our boys modern, sanitary, and efficient care of stock. As you know from your own inspection the present state of the barn leaves much to be desired and an agricultural program of any worth must have as a foundation the proper care of stock. With a properly equipped barn we can give our boys a good grounding in this but in its present state we are greatly handicapped.

Re: Kootenay Indian Residential School,
Cranbrook, B.C.

In compliance with the request in your letter of June 18th, Mr. Nelson made an inspection of the pressure tank at the above school, on June 25th.

The tank lies horizontally with its top 9.5 feet, and its bottom 14.5 feet below the surface of the ground. The end of the tank nearest the building was exposed for a length of some 8 feet.

The tank was installed in 1913; is badly rusted around the rivets and seams and has been leaking. Efforts to stop these leaks by welding were not successful due to the age and condition of the metal.

I would recommend that:

(a) The old tank be removed entirely from the excavation.
(b) That a new tank, 5'-0" in diameter by 25'-0" long, of sufficient thickness of metal to stand a working pressure of 100 p.s.i., be installed on the same bed as was occupied by the old tank, except that the end of the tank nearest the building and containing a manhole, 3" holes for pipe connections at top and bottom of the manhole end, and 1¼" holes for air volume control and gauge glasses, be moved into the boiler-room through a hole to be cut in the boiler-room wall so that after the tank is in place and the wall cemented up, the end of the tank mentioned above will project at least 6" into the boiler-room with a clearance between the bottom of the tank and the boiler-room floor of 9".

This tank is to be painted with a suitable rust-preventive coating.

This tank will have a 2100 Imperial Gallon water capacity between a maximum of 100 p.s.i. and a minimum of 20 p.s.i.

ESTIMATE OF COST

1. Removal of old tank $200.00
2. New tank 5' x 25' F.O.B. Cranbrook, B.C. (tax included) $1,600.00
3. Hauling, placing and covering new tank $250.00
4. Plumbing and connections $150.00
5. Supervision, Engineering, Incidentals $200.00

$2,400.00

Re: REPLACEMENT OF WATER PRESSURE TANK
AT KOOTENAY RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

I am enclosing a letter received from Rev. Father Kelly re above.

During a visit to the Residential School I inspected the tank in question and am in agreement with Father Kelly that the water supply will be unsatisfactory when school opens on Sept. 3rd. Keeping sufficient water pressure requires constant attention and in the event the old tank fails it would create a major hazard as to sanitary conditions.

Due to the position of this tank and the major excavation problem of its replacement, I consider it advisable to complete work on this project before the Fall frosts set in.

I wish at this time to recommend the installation of an automatic air compressor with this unit; the present manually-operated compressor is unsatisfactory in that there is a tendency on the part of the operator to overcharge the tank with air on one hand and in the course of his many duties allow the pressure to fall below a desired point.

J. S. Dunn,
Indian Agent.
Kootenay Indian School,
Cranbrook, B.C.,
August 14th, 1946.

Mr. J. Dunn,
Indian Agent,
Cranbrook, B.C.

Dear Mr. Dunn:

I felt it my duty to request you to point out again to the proper authority, the urgent necessity of the replacement of the water pressure tank in this School. I know that materials and labour are scarce, but this question has been open since early in the month of June and replacement was to be made during the summer vacation. With the opening of the School only nineteen days away our situation is very serious.

The maintaining of pressure in the present condemned tank with a manually-operated hand pump is almost impossible. I don't need to go into details regarding the difficulty of operating the School without water. That is self-evident.

Anything you can do to convince the suppliers of the urgency of this matter will surely be appreciated by us.

Assuring you of our continued co-operation,

I remain,

Sincerely yours,

"G. F. KELLY" O.M.I.,
Principal.

Re: Urgent Repairs for Cranbrook School
Attention: Mr. Phelan.

My dear Mr. Phelan:

The last school which I saw during my British Columbia visit was Cranbrook. This is quite a large establishment, capable of accommodating at least 120 children, although at the present moment, the attendance is not up to that point. In fact there has been a drop from last September's attendance to this year's. This is due in part to some children from Penticton not returning. Of course, there may be a chance and the attendance may yet reach considerably over the hundred.

The Principal says that he could easily secure children from the district around Mission and wishes to know if this would be acceptable to the Department. As you know, there must be at least 150 children in that part of the country who have no school and who might be glad to attend the one at Cranbrook.

The general condition of the school is quite good, but like most schools, it requires a good deal of painting. There is one improvement though which must be attended to immediately.

The pipe which brings soft water to the school must be renewed without any delay. The enclosed sketch shows the distance from the intake to the school, measuring 1650 feet. I am informed that Major McKay recommended its renewal and that at that time, he secured an approximate figure of $3,000 for excavation and necessary equipment. You will notice from the sketch that soft water could be secured from St. Joseph's Creek at a much closer point than the proposed one, but the present line was chosen in
order to give it sufficient head. In fact, it might be possible by taking it at that particular point, to force it to the roof of the school by gravity. This would create in itself a very appreciable fire protection.

The water situation, due to the breakage in the soft water line, is so serious that it is damaging all the plumbing in the school and if not attended to in the immediate future, it will force the Department to renew a great many of the fixtures. For instance, the Principal tells me that he has had to replace the kitchen jacket heater three times in the last year.

This is an improvement which is essential for the proper management of the school and I hope that you will include it in next year's estimates. As prices have gone up considerably since Major McKay had it estimated, it would be better to include the sum of $5,000.00 in the budget.

When the school was built, the specifications called for granite staircase for the front of the school but it was poorly set up or laid. It is now in fairly poor condition and should be reset. I believe that $500.00 would take care of this improvement.

There are other improvements of a minor nature which the Principal will proceed to effect and for which he will send, in due time, accounts to the Department.

Thanking you in anticipation I remain,

Very truly yours,

J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.

Reference is made to our notation of September 14th on Mr. Mills' memorandum of September 13th and of your reply thereto of September 23rd relative to the above.

On receipt of your memorandum of September 23rd, the matter of fully automatic control of the water supply was looked into further and it is estimated that the cost of installation of equipment necessary to make the supply of air and water to the pressure tank fully automatic when the motive power is a 7 H.P. Diesel Engine with generator and storage batteries would be of the order of $1,000.

In this connection however it now appears from information just received regarding the layout of this plant that automatic controls to the 7 H.P. Diesel Engine and Air Compressor would seriously complicate the maintenance and operation of both the water supply and electric power systems.

Diesel engine operation requires frequent attention and inspection by the operator and consequently this engine was not previously equipped with automatic start and stop equipment. Apparently the plant layout was not planned for fully automatic operation and it is felt that the partly automatic air controls...
which it has been intended to install with the new tank will render satisfactory service until such time as electric power at 110/220 Volts is available for pumping.

In view of the foregoing, including the large expenditure of $1,000 that would be necessary, the proposal to make the water system fully automatic is not recommended.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Com.

Dear Major MacKay;

I am wondering if anything further can be done to impress upon the Engineering Branch the urgency of replacing the water pressure tank at the school here. As you know it burst last Spring and was temporarily repaired for a maximum pressure of sixty pounds. It was subsequently condemned by the Engineer for the Dept. but to date nothing has been done. With the advent of winter the situation is very serious. The tank had to be uncovered in order to repair it and now it is exposed to the frost. Excavating it was a big task as it is fourteen feet under ground. We did the excavation at no small expense without receiving any remuneration from the Dept. I would not mind that if we received any cooperation in its replacement but now it seems as though we will have to fill it in again to protect it from the frost. If I thought it would stir up any action with the engineering branch I would like to leave it exposed and have it burst so that they would be forced to give us some consideration. What would you advise?

At present in order to keep up pressure we have had to employ a man to start the pump every hour, watch it till it reaches sixty pounds pressure, and then stop the engine. This is a full time occupation from six in the morning till eight at night. When I employed him in Sept. I thought it would be for a week or two till they made an installation but now it has gone on for two months. What about his salary? Don't you think it should be paid by the Dept.?

Sincerely yours,

"G.F. Kelly, O.M.I."

I respectfully submit the following report on the general administration of the Kootenay Agency for the quarter ending September 30th, 1946, and have endeavoured to cover all points of vital interest to the welfare of the Kootenay Indians and the Indian Affairs Branch.

WELFARE AND TRAINING

Fire drills are carried out per regulations. I tried to point out the importance of these drills and the need of taking a more serious view in this important matter. Those in charge were inclined to treat this form of protection a bit too lightly.

In general the utilities at this school are inadequate. The water supply is a source of continual worry and requires constant attention in the pumping of a supply and in maintaining the required air pressure. The water itself is very hard and deposits a heavy scale on all heating surfaces cutting their efficiency to a minimum. There is great need for the proposed additional water system from St. Joseph's Creek, this additional water supply as proposed would not only give the necessary fire protection but will provide soft water for the laundry and boilers. The lighting plant at this school is working well, but it is running at capacity most of the day and is definitely overloaded at the peak hours in the evening. The plumbing is in need of attention, authority has been granted for this work to be done, but unfortunately the supplies necessary for this important work are not available.

I respectfully submit the following report on
the general administration of the Kootenay Agency for
the quarter ending September 30th, 1946, and have en-
deavoured to cover all points of vital interest to the
welfare of the Kootenay Indians and the Indian Affairs
Branch.

WELFARE AND TRAINING

After one months operation after the summer
holidays, the Kootenay Indian Residential School has
settled down to an orderly routine. There was considerable
delay in the first two weeks of the new term due to the
tardiness of several of the pupils, with the greatest
difficulty occasioned in the rounding up of pupils who
were in the U.S.A. with their parents. In general the
parents have co-operated very well in sending their
children to school, but there remains an undercurrent
of dislike for the method of education, they object to
the method whereby the children spend only one-half of
the day in school with the remainder spent in vocational
training or general chores about the school. They also
object to their children being away from home for ten
months at a time.

My first visit to the classrooms in operation
was a delightful surprise, the rooms were exceptionally
bright and cheerful, the pupils neat and tidy with their
hands clean and their faces shining; the teachers ap-
peared very efficient and their control of the pupils'
department very satisfactory. A new plan has been ins-
tigated this term and the pupils of the two junior
grades are receiving full time instruction and their
teachers are well pleased with this improvement. I am
not in a position to say that the curriculum in this
school will compare favourably with our city schools,
but writing and neatness of the work done in the junior
grades particularly would give credit to any school
and the pupils themselves were very proud of their
work.

The spirit of the classrooms was not so evident
among the children under vocational training. The parents
objection to their children doing chores about the school
was reflected in the lackadaisical way in which the chil-
dren did their respective tasks, and it is unfortunate
that this important phase of their training cannot be
made more attractive.

J.S. Dunn,
Indian Agent.

Reference your letter of November 8th, 1946, File I.A. 1767-2.

1. This office wired the Patterson Boiler Works on November 12, asking them to advise us when the pressure tank would be shipped to Cranbrook. They replied on the same day, that they expected to ship the tank on November 18th.

3. On November 27th, I wrote to Major D.M. McKay, Commissioner of Indian Affairs at Vancouver, to the effect that the tank had not yet arrived at Cranbrook and that due to the existing weather conditions it would be a difficult and expensive undertaking to throw out the ground, excavate material covering, remove the old tank and install the new one, and that I would strongly recommend that the permanent installation of the tank be deferred until next spring. I stated that if it was imperative that the new tank be connected up as soon as it was delivered to the school, then it might be necessary to (a) place it on the ground surface in a small heated building, or (b) as a cheaper alternative, between wooden retaining walls covered entirely with about two feet of sawdust, roofed over and heated by a small steam pipe through the tank.

On December 4th, 1946, Major Mackay, in a letter to this office stated "With reference to your letter of November 27th, I have been in communication with the Principal of the Kootenay Indian Residential School who is of the opinion that it would be better to carry on with the old tank until spring if possible as it is thought that the cost of installing a new tank under present weather conditions would exceed the cost of maintaining pressure in the present tank. With reference to your letter of November 30th, the tank was spotted yesterday (Monday, December 2nd) and was unloaded and delivered to Kootenay Indian Residential School the same afternoon by a local hauling contractor on his truck and trailer. In conversation with Rev. Father Kelly re possibilities of continuing with the old tank for the remainder of the winter, there appears little likelihood of any local contractor taking on the installation of the new tank at this time. An excavation 30' long by 10' wide and 15' deep at this time of year would be very difficult. There is considerable inconvenience in the matter of pumping water as at present but Father Kelly suggests that providing the old tank holds out they would prefer to carry on with the present installation.

If the old tank does fail, the new one can be placed in the adjacent garage and temporary fittings connected. I will endeavor, as far as possible, to prepare for such an eventuality and therefore, wish to recommend that due to excessive costs of excavation at this time of year, the matter of installing the new Hydro Pneumatic tank at Kootenay Indian School be deferred until spring with the hope that the old tank does not fail us in the meantime.

Major D.M. McKay, Commissioner,
Indian Affairs,
Vancouver, B.C.

Dear Major McKay:

I have a very serious transportation problem on hand and would like to solicit your advice. As you know we are seven miles from town and there isn't any bus service out here. Our only means of transportation at the present time is a two-ton truck and that is not very convenient for local calls. I am faced with the necessity of buying a car but present finances are on the wrong side of the ledger. If you have seen the auditor's report as made in September '46 we have a deficit of some twenty-seven hundred dollars. Our present position has not improved.

The attached quotations are in the lower priced field and I would like to present our case to the Dept. for the purchase of such means of transportation as they deem necessary. That we must have some transportation is beyond question. Placed as we are off the main highway we have no mail delivery, no bread delivery or transportation convenience of any kind. There are a number of calls every month with sick children. The expense of calling a taxi for these has become quite an item and I always feel it is an injustice for us to have to pay such expenses from the per capita allowance. Were we in good financial standing it would not be so serious but in our present straightened position it can not be overlooked.

I am not asking that we be allowed travelling expenses such as are granted to Indian Agents. If the Dept. would supply us with the vehicle I
feel sure we could meet the expenses of upkeep. However I do hesitate to burden myself with debt by taking on the purchase of it from our present funds.

There is moreover the question of supplying transportation to the Cranbrook High School for some of our more worthy pupils. If the necessary arrangements can be made with the Dept. I am sure we can have five or six here for next year who would like to continue High School. It seems a pity not to encourage them for we certainly need some intelligent development among these Kootenays. If the Dept. will allow their continuing in residence beyond the age of sixteen we could accommodate them here and transport them to Cranbrook each day for their classes. In the event of this arrangement influencing the purchase, a station wagon would be the more practical.

I will be pleased to have your recommendations on the matter,

Sincerely yours,

G.F. Kelly O.M.I.
Principal.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

I am enclosing a copy of a letter dated January 28th from the Reverend Principal of the Kootenay Indian Residential School, together with enclosures referred to therein in connection with the proposed purchase from appropriation of a Station Wagon or Car for use at the School.

Although I am aware that it is not the Department's policy to provide such vehicles from appropriation for Indian education, Father Kelly's letter is forwarded for your consideration. The Principal's suggestion that pupils over the age of sixteen whose academic standing warrants further educational opportunities be permitted to remain in residence at the school and attend the high school in Cranbrook is worthy of consideration and might be considered an argument in favour of the supply of suitable transportation facilities.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Mr. Dunn:

You will remember from our conversation of last week that I mentioned having trouble with the Petters Diesel Engine which drives the water-pump.

At that time we had the Diesel mechanic from the Cranbrook Auto Wreckers examine the engine and he sent the fuel pump and injector to the B.C. Equipment Co. in Vancouver. When they were returned the engine still wouldn't operate. Further examination shows the piston, rings, connecting rod, and main-bearing quite worn and in need of re-boring or replacement.

This work can only be done in Vancouver as the local firms have not the fittings for a Petters engine. It means sending all the engine except the wheels and base to Vancouver. The B.C. Equipment Co. states that it will take from two to three weeks for this re-building. From past experience we may expect that this will be considerably longer.

In the meantime what are we to do for power to operate the water-pump? The old Otto Gas Engine is not in condition to maintain a supply of water. It was condemned some years back as the expense of repairing it was considered too great. Do you think it feasible to get a small gas engine or a diesel on loan to keep us operating while the Petters is being repaired. I do not need to emphasize that our need is urgent as trying to carry on without a supply of water is a desperate situation.

Considering the expense that the Petters has incurred during the past and we may trust that the cost of now re-building it will be
quite considerable, I would like to put in a request for a replacement. At best it is an old engine that has given a number of years of service, just how many years I am not in a position to say because I have been unable to find any record of its installation. I am writing the B.C. Equipment Co. asking for a statement of the estimated cost of repairing it, which estimate I have asked them to submit to you and to Major McKay. I told them not to proceed with the work until the estimate was approved.

I trust you will give this matter your attention and try to secure for us some means of power with the least possible delay,

Thanking you,

I remain,

Sincerely yours,

G.F. Kelly O.M.I.
Principal.
Cranbrook, B. C.,

As I already informed you by telephone our Lister Engine for supplying power developed a serious oil leak last week and I wired to Major MacKay for authorization to have it repaired. Thirty dollars was allowed for the work and the attached invoices for twenty-one seventy-five shows the work complete in so far as they were able to fix it. It is still leaking slightly around the main-bearing but the Cranbrook Auto Wreckers, or any local firm have not the equipment to make the repair. However this leak is not serious as yet and the engine is again in operation.

I was with the mechanic while he was working and as he found the interior in bad condition I had him make the attached report as to his findings. Just how long it will continue to operate no one can say but it does look as though we will have more trouble with it in the near future.

Approximately a year ago this engine was overhauled by a Vancouver firm and since that time we have followed to the letter the instructions as to type of oil, times of changing, and the filter system. Knowing from past correspondence that this engine has from its first instalment been unsatisfactory I have taken every precaution since its last overhauling that it has received the best of care and attention. If as it seems from the mechanic's report we are again to have trouble surely we are entitled to a means of power more satisfactory than this has been. I would be very pleased if you would give this matter your support.

Sincerely yours,

May I draw to your attention the condition of the Cranbrook school transportation. For quite a while there never has been a car that actually belonged to the school. The school made use of a car that was purchased by the Bishop for the Indian missions. Now that the Indian missions car has been transferred elsewhere rather belly is in need of something in the way of a station wagon to transport the children of the school who are likely to attend the public high school. He also needs this wagon for transporting the commodities of life as well as the mail, which has to be brought
in several miles from the town.

I would confirm my telegram of the 31st ult. as follows:

"PRINCIPAL KELLY CRANBROOK INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL REPORTS SCHOOL WITHOUT WATER AND LIGHT OTTO AND LISTER ENGINES BROKEN DOWN AND REPORTED BEYOND REPAIR PRINCIPAL RECOMMENDS IMMEDIATE PURCHASE INTERNATIONAL THIRTY-FOUR HORSEPOWER DIESEL ENGINE TO MEET NEEDS THIS ENGINE NOW AVAILABLE AT CRANBROOK FOR IMMEDIATE INSTALLATION COST TWO THOUSAND TWO HUNDRED AND FIFTY DOLLARS PRINCIPAL KELLY CONTACTING DEPARTMENT BY PHONE TOMORROW SITUATION AS REPORTED TO THIS OFFICE INDICATES PURCHASE OF NEW UNIT SHOULD BE MADE."

As the Department is aware, this school is served by three power units, an "Otto" horizontal gasolene engine that has been obsolete for many years and now, reportedly, beyond repair; a Petters diesel which has been under repair in Vancouver, which has taken care of the pumping needs of the school for some years; and the Lister diesel.
and the supplied by the Department about five or six years ago, a great deal of the time out of action awaiting repairs and now reportedly completely broken down. There is no doubt whatever but that the maintenance of these units has not only been extremely poor prior to the school being taken over by the present Principal but that the so called engineer ruined them by a combination of tinkering and neglect.

The Petters now in Vancouver undergoing repairs shows evidence of great abuse since it was completely overhauled about two years ago.

The present situation is that the institution is without water and light, twenty-seven of the pupils are ill, two of them having been admitted to the hospital with pneumonia. That the local health authorities have not ordered the school closed down until services are restored indicates that they are not yet aware of the situation.

From the information received none of the engines can be restored to service without delay and it would appear that our only alternative is to install the most suitable plant immediately available locally, this being the "International" 34 H.P. diesel, costing $2,250.00, and I would so recommend.

Dear Mr. Neary:

Further to our conversation of a few hours ago I thought I should add a few words of further explanation as to the situation. My action in phoning you was probably somewhat unorthodox but I am sure if you were here and could see our present predicament you would understand that some drastic action had to be taken. We are in the midst of a serious flu epidemic with some cases developing into pneumonia. Today we have twenty-seven patients in bed. Saturday and Sunday we had neither light, heat, or water. The old gas engine used for water pumping refused to run and of course without water we couldn't have the furnaces on. The Doctor came here Sunday and was ready to take this thing to the highest authority he could find. Our nurse and staff were naturally unable to cope with the situation and the whole affair was pretty drastic. We were able to get temporary repairs for the old gas engine and get some water but we still had no light. Attending these patients in the dark was a bit too much.

I had hoped that we could keep the equipment operating until the appropriation went through for what we should have, the East Kootenay power. But the line can't be built in a day and so I felt the only thing was to get the available unit. The engineers are here now installing it and by evening they say they will have it running. Deo Gratias.

When the breakdown came Saturday morning we wired Major McKay and the reply was that he could do nothing without further specif-
ications. That was a bit too much for me and I suppose I said a few things to him when I got him on the phone that he didn't like to hear but I felt we had taken it on the chin just about long enough. If his home was two and a half miles for the Power Line I am sure it would long ago have been connected up. If the Dept. had done that ten years ago enough money would have been saved to pay for all the engines and repairs that have been necessitated in that time and many of the disagreeable situations that have arisen between Principals and the Dept. in that time would have been avoided. I know that you understand that as well as I do and I do feel sorry that at this stage when we were assured of the proper power within two years this situation had to arise and necessitate a new engine installment. However in an emergency one has to do what seems best and meet the future when it comes.

For some time I had been considering sending you a detailed report on the conditions of this institution, not only the matter of power, but the whole set-up of the school and the reserves which we are attempting to serve. I am following with great interest the Bulletins which you are publishing and I have set my heart to bring this institution up to what it should be. The ignorance, lack of initiative, and in some cases evident misunderstanding on the part of the Indians of what we are trying to do for them, is quite appalling here. I would say that our Kootenays are about fifty years behind the coast Indians and the radical views of some white so-called citizens are raising a situation which if not soon remedied will have serious results. The urgent need is housing, encouragement, and education. The radical ideas of some of these poor fellows, who really don't know what they are talking about, is astounding. As Mr. Hoey said to the Committee examining the Indian Act
in their session of March 6th, "There is no doubt but that we are working in the right direction, but are we working fast enough".

I had hoped that during the recess last summer some of the members of the Commission would have paid us a visit. There are enough issues here to fill a book. We are not in the class that they term the 'Bush Indians' and yet we are not with those upon whom white civilization has had a good influence. The white influence here is for the greater part the bootleggers. The citizens of Cranbrook just don't accept them at all. And in the present state of the Indians that is understandable. To bring them to their rightfull place will be a long task but we must get started without further delay.

With my sincere appreciation for your assistance in the matter discussed this morning and kind cooperation on many past occasions,

I remain,

Truly yours,

G.F. Kelly O.M.I.
Principal.

Memorandum:

To - C. M. Walker, Esq.,
District Engineer,

Installation of Hydro-Pneumatic Tank
Kootenay Indian Residential School
Cranbrook, B.C.

I arrived in Cranbrook at 5 P.M., April 18th, and drove out to the school after dinner. I found that the excavation had been completed to the bottom of the old 30 foot tank, but on one side only. The other side of the tank was partially covered, and this cover was all that was preventing the earth under the south end of the garage from caving into the excavation. A part of the foundation earth under the northeast corner of the garage had already caved into the excavation. Cracks in the adjoining earth, some six feet on the north side of the excavation at the west end of the tank, indicated that a serious cave-in might occur as soon as the old tank was lifted and its support removed from under the earth wall supporting the garage. Earth was beginning to run into the excavation from under the church foundations on the south side of the excavation.

It was therefore deemed advisable to let the old tank remain in place and set the new tank in the excavation parallel to, but with its centre line some four feet south of the centre line of the old tank and with the elevation of the bottom of the new tank some two or three feet above the elevation of the top of the old tank.

To make this installation would necessitate filling the excavation up to the proposed elevation of the bottom of the new tank and not installing the new tank in position until the filled in earth had become well settled. It was estimated that one or two months should elapse before this settlement was satisfactory, and deemed necessary that in the meantime the new tank be pulled into the garage building and connected up to the water system.

The above method of procedure met with the approval of Mr. Dunn, the Indian Agent, and Father Kelly, the principal of the school. The latter pointed out that the time of installation of the new tank should be deferred until the end of the present school term, some time near the end of June, as at that time with only the staff in attendance, the loss of water pressure for the day or two necessary to make the tank change over, would not be so inconvenient as if made when the school was full of students.

On Saturday April 19th the new tank was pulled into the garage, placed in position and most of the connections made.

On Monday April 21st, the connections to the new tank were completed and a bulldozer, hired from a Cranbrook firm, filled the excavated earth back into the excavation, over and around the old tank, and up to the elevation for the bottom of the new tank plus 20% shrinkage.

Dear Sir:

With reference to my visit to the Kootenay Indian Residential School, I find that the present methods of handling the milk supply from the farm are very inadequate.

As you are no doubt aware, the milking is done, under supervision, by the Indian students, and whilst this may appear satisfactory, in all likelihood the dairy cows are probably not supplying all the milk that can be expected of them. This could be due to excitement caused by inexperienced milkers and also by lack of thorough stripping. In any event I would strongly recommend the installation of a milking machine, which in turn will necessitate a power line being brought in to the school.

After milking the milk is brought over to the kitchen, in the basement of the school, filtered into cans and put into a storage containing milk, vegetables, etc. As you know milk will readily adopt any adjacent flavours, especially warm milk, and even though the milk is placed in a cold storage it takes a considerable time to cool down to a temperature which prevents the normal growth of bacteria. No facilities are provided other than the above, and it is a remarkable thing to me that, under these circumstances and the method of milking, no serious outbreak of disease has occurred at the school.

With these facts in mind I sincerely recommend the construction of a suitable farm dairy of sufficient size to accommodate the daily milk supply, which at present is approximately 50 gallons per day, in which case a milk house with inside dimensions of 12' x 14' would be quite suitable. I am forwarding Dairy Circular No.5 under separate cover, issued by the Provincial Department of Agriculture, which includes information and a plan for such a building.

With regard to costs it is very difficult to give an accurate estimate for such a building, but providing labour can be provided the probable cost of material would be in the neighborhood of $150 to $200. In addition the following equipment would be required—a suitable boiler for providing live steam and heat, a double sink for washing and rinsing utensils, a steam cabinet for sterilizing, a surface cooler with water pressure connection, and a suitable rack for cans, pails, etc.
It would, of course, be highly desirable to pasteurize milk used in such an institution, and in which case an extra room would be required in the milk house. In any case a milk house of some description is highly essential and it is with this in view that I am also forwarding Dominion Department of Agriculture Bulletin No.165 on Cooling Milk on the Farm and our own Dairy Circular No.36, the Care of Milk on the Farm.

Trusting that my observations and recommendations may prove of some value in improving the milk supply at the school, I remain,

Yours very truly,

G. D. Johnson,
