Aug 8, 1947.

Ex'd A.

Re: Kootenay Indian Residential School,
Cranbrook, British Columbia.

During the course of other work being carried out at the above, the attention of W.H. Snelson of Mr. Walker's office was directed to the heating boilers. He reports that approximately 40% of the tubes of one boiler and 20% of the tubes in the other boiler were leaking seriously, and that repairs were imperative.

We requested Mr. Walker on May 6th last, to have the Cranbrook Foundry examine the boilers and quote on the necessary repairs. We have just received a telegram from Mr. Snelson dated August 7th, which reads as follows:

"Survey and Engineering Branch Dept., Mines and Resources Ottawa Cranbrook Foundry can repair boilers at Kootenay school for approximately $1500 using second hand tubes in good condition. STOP New tubes unavailable in west STOP Work could commence week of August 11 STOP Wire Indian Agent Cranbrook Authorization"

This Service has no choice other than to recommend that the repairs be carried out immediately on the basis of the foregoing telegram.

It is recommended that Indian Affairs authorize execution of this work by the Cranbrook Foundry, to be carried out under the responsibility of the Indian Agent. No supervision from this Service will be required, and upon completion accounts certified by the Indian Agent should be forwarded directly to the Indian Affairs Branch for payment. The Cranbrook Foundry should be asked to provide a guarantee that the new tubes will give satisfaction for at least three seasons.

J.M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,

INSTALLATION OF HYDRO-PNEUMATIC TANK AT THE KOOTENAY INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL, CRANBROOK, B.C.

Re: my letter of April 25th, 1947.

Mr. Nelson, of this office arrived in Cranbrook on the evening of August 3rd.

August 4th - Rented bulldozer, shaped bottom of excavation, pulled pressure tank out from temporary location in garage, and pushed it down into place in excavation.

Plumbers made necessary arrangements to connect piping from tank to house lines.

Bulldozer started pushing earth cover over tank.

Aug. 5 & 6 - Some difficulty was experienced in cutting a hole through the 54" basement wall into the boiler-room. Two different firms were kind enough to make the attempt with small electric concrete drills. This met with no success as the drills were not powerful enough.

August 7th - A portable air compressor was finally located at a gypsum mine near Wardner that was, at the time, not operating. The man in charge hauled the compressor and hammer to the school arriving at noon. By 4:00 P.M., this powerful equipment had made a 6" diameter hole through the wall.

Aug. 8 & 9 - The local plumber and helpers made all necessary piping connections. Father Kelly, principal of the school, said that he would have Indians fill up the small hole remaining next the building. At 6:00 P.M., August 9th the tank had been filled to the H.W.L. and all equipment was functioning satisfactorily.

Re: St. Josephs Creek Pipeline
Kootenay Indian Residential School,
Cranbrook, B.C.
Your letter of July 22nd, 1947.

A preliminary estimate of cost, for a pipeline approximately 1400 feet in length, to convey water from St. Josephs creek to the school building, amounting to $5,000.00, is attached hereto.

This scheme would make no use whatever of the old pipeline which leaks in so many places that it would not be economical to attempt to salvage any part of it.

The Hypo-chlorinator would be placed on that portion of the line that would convey water to the laundry. It would be proportional and would operate only when the laundry was in operation. It is not considered necessary to chlorinate that portion of the water supply that would be used for the boilers, stock-watering, or irrigation.

The water surface in the proposed forebay in St. Josephs creek would be 25 feet above the ground surface at the school building or 30 feet above the basement floor where the laundry machinery is located, or 28 feet above the large laundry tube.

The proposed 6" pipeline would, therefore, deliver 450 U.S. gallons per minute, or approximately 1 c.f.s. to the Laundry; or 400 U.S. gallons per minute for irrigation purposes at ground level. Static pressure at the laundry would be approximately 12.0 p.s.i.

The above estimate is based on the assumption that a power shovel could be obtained locally to do the excavating and back-filling work, and on pipe prices as obtaining in July 1947.

Recent advices from wood pipe manufacturing firms in Vancouver quote six to eight months for date of delivery after receipt of order. It is recommended that the materials required be ordered immediately and that local firms having ditching shovels be contacted to insure that the work could be done immediately upon receipt of the materials.

J.S. Dunn, Esq., Indian Agent, Cranbrook, B.C.

Re - Telephone Communication -
Kootenay Residential School -

Replying to your letter of the 18th inst., requesting assistance for the Kootenay Indian Residential School in the reconstruction of the telephone line, I would advise that you appear to have overlooked my telegram of July 25th last as follows:

"Retel school management should arrange for repairs telephone line their expense with possibility of securing reimbursement from department if our responsibility established."

The maintenance of this line is definitely the responsibility of the school, and if a grant additional to the school funds should be required, it should be treated the same way as any other special assistance, provision being made, of course, in the estimates.

As you are aware, the estimates for the current year provided for a refrigeration unit and repairs to farm buildings at a cost of $2,400.00. However, the Department found it necessary to spend $2,265.79 for a diesel engine and faced an expenditure of $2,400.00 in connection with the installation of a hydro-pneumatic tank. They also approved of an expenditure of $850.00 for a dairy building and an additional amount for the water supply line. When you add to this the $1500. for boiler repairs you will see that the original provision has been considerably exceeded, at the expense of other schools.
Under the circumstances I am of the opinion that the Department will be unable to meet this additional demand, and if the school is unable to maintain the line, I can only suggest that they abandon the telephone.

If funds were available, the lack of detail in your submission would have made it impossible to secure authorization without referring it back to you. Detailed estimates, including labour, are required.

This telephone line was apparently installed by the C. P. R. during construction of the Crows Nest Pass Railroad in connection with hospitalization of their construction crew at the old St. Eugene Mission Hospital. The line was taken over when our Kootenay Indian Residential School was constructed after being abandoned when the St. Eugene Hospital was moved to Cranbrook.

The Kootenay Telephone Company at present is unwilling to estimate cost or undertake repairs but made a survey of the situation. Mr. D. Miller, Local Manager, reports that at least 30, No. 3, butt-treated poles at a cost of $4.00 each will be necessary; other poles will be satisfactory if reset.
Obviously communication between the School, St. Mary's Reserve and the City of Cranbrook is a service that should be maintained. The operators of the school are naturally loath to meet this major expense, which may cost between $400.00 and $500.00. In the meantime this telephone service is threatened with every heavy wind.

The attached Voucher No. 411 in favour of Patmore Bros. covers repairs to No. 1 heating boiler at the Kootenay Indian Residential School. Some two years ago Mr. Patmore was asked to renew a burnt out elbow and tee joint but was unable to complete this work due to lack of material.

When it became apparent that renewal of tubes in No. 2 heating boiler would be delayed until after opening of school for the fall term, Mr. Patmore was pressed by this office to complete the repair work on No. 1 boiler. An early cold snap developed before this work was accomplished and the Rev. Principal was unwilling to fire up No. 2 boiler, which was undoubtedly in poor condition but capable of heating the school. Fortunately, warmer weather developed after two or three days and No. 1 boiler was repaired by Mr. Patmore before another cold spell.

Repairs to No. 2 boiler have since been completed by the Cranbrook Foundry and with the renewal of main arch and brickwork is now operating efficiently. Dear Mr. Neary:

I have been corresponding with Father Flourde regarding this year's estimates and particularly the building of the East Kootenay Power line. He said the chief obstacle was the fact that a new Diesel was installed here last Spring at a cost of twenty-two hundred and some dollars and that it was the mind of the Dept. that we should use it for at least another year. When I asked for its installation I knew it would be a stumbling block to the introduction of what we should have but in the emergency what else could we do? However the Dept. need not lose any money on the installation. I am prepared to pay the full cost price of the Diesel if it can be released any time within the calendar year '48. These engines are in great demand among the lumber companies here and I have the promise of a local operator that he will take it off my hands any time within the next year. On the other hand I hope to have a saw-mill operating here within a short time and could put it to use ourselves. Naturally if the engine runs much over a year the Dept. is going to lose money on deterioration but if this matter can be kept in this year's estimates the above offer stands.

This would reduce the price of the power line from eight thousand two hundred to six thousand which should be sound business. If it will facilitate matters I will be glad to draw up a contract to the above effect immediately because I know I can dispose of the Diesel engine without suffering loss and at the same time dispose of the major headache of this whole set-up. I am sure there is no need to rehearse what has already been said many times that our whole program of school activity is being hampered by this lack of substantial power. Your excellent publication, The Indian School Bulletin, encourages us to introduce extra curricular activity and to bring our school up to modern standards in every phase of education but who can do that under such an antiquated system as we have here? Children who are burdened with ironing clothes with sad-irons, peeling potatoes, polishing floors by hand, milking cows by hand and the other host of manual duties which we now have in the maintenance of the institution, have little time for real education. Give us a supply of A.C. power and we will give in return a school second to none in the Province.

Do you think it would help matters if I sent an offer to buy the Diesel engine, as stated above, direct to the Treasury Branch? If you would advise it, to whom should I address the letter? I would be very pleased to hear from you on this matter.

Sincerely yours,

G.F. Kelly O.M.I. Principal.
Ottawa, November 25, 1947.

Dear Father Kelly:

We received your letter of November 12th and have carefully considered its contents.

Even if we approved the sale of the diesel engine that we supplied during the current calendar year, to the Kootenay School, the proceeds could not be used for building the power line. Such action is contrary to Treasury Board regulations.

At the present time I am not in a position to state when we will have funds available for installation or an electric line to the Kootenay School.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Rev. G.F. Kelly, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Kootenay Indian Res. School,

Kootenay Indian Residential School:

Plans are well advanced for the installation of fire hydrants and hose in the school. The present fire protection consists of pyrene and foamite dispensers which are not considered adequate.

It is expected that pipe will be on hand before frost is out of the ground for the installation of a renewal of the old soft water line from St. Joseph's Creek. A chlorinator will be installed on this line to counteract any contamination that may enter the creek.

The boilers at the school have been overhauled during this quarter and are now giving satisfactory and efficient service.

Materials to repair toilets in the boys' lavatory have proved unobtainable and four second-hand overhead tank units have been installed. This temporary installation has proved satisfactory.

The Rev. Principal has installed, at his own expense, an electric potato peeler and an electric mincing machine, which have eliminated many hours of tedious work for the pupils.

Material is now on hand for the construction of a modern dairy building of hollow cinder brick construction with steam boiler, can washing and sterilizing equipment. The old method of milk handling in the main school building being considered unsanitary by Provincial Dairy Inspectors.

Power facilities are inadequate at this school and it is hoped that arrangements for the acquisition of nearby hydroelectric power will be made in the near future, that the utilities of the school may be placed on an efficient basis.

Re Sale of House at Cranbrook to Indian Department

Dear Mr. Phelan,

On the occasion of my visit to your office in February in the company of Rev. Fathers O'Grady and Mulvihill I mentioned to you the willingness of the Oblate Fathers to sell the Department a house on the Oblate property at Cranbrook, which the principal of the school wishes to have moved onto Government property at the rear of the school for the purpose of housing workmen.

Will you kindly put the matter before the proper authorities in your Department for their consideration.

The dwelling in question is situated on Lot I Kootenay District owned by the Order of the Oblates of Mary Immaculate, copy of Title 319K as registered in land registry office, Nelson, B.C.

This house is a four room bungalow with unfinished attic. It is finished inside with lath and plaster and wall board covered with paper. The floors are B.C. fir and are in good condition. The roof is shingled and stained and has given no trouble. Until recently it has been occupied by a man and his wife employed at the school and so has been kept in good repair.

It is the wish of the school principal, Rev. Father Kelly, that the house be moved from its present location to the school property a distance I would estimate at not more than one-quarter of a mile. His reason for moving it and having it purchased by the Government is to use it for single men. In its present location it is not practical for single men during the winter months when it has to be heated. By placing it at the rear of the school building, between the school and the barn, the men can use it very conveniently and will take their meals in the school. It could accommodate an engineer, manual trainer and farm manager. Hot water and light could be installed from the school plant if the Department saw fit to do so. Its present location is too remote for these facilities.

Father Kelly estimates that the move will cost from $175 to $200. This would be the use of a caterpillar tractor. Most of the other equipment, jacks, skids, etc., they have on hand at the school and he says that he will gladly give the use of men and time for the project.
Ottawa, March 30, 1948.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan

Dear Mr. Dunn:

Repeated requests have been made over a number of years for a unit to supply hot water during the months when the furnaces are not in use. With the advent of Spring we are again faced with this handicap which is a very serious one. While the furnaces are in use water for bathing and domestic use is heated by a coil in the firebox of No. 1 boiler. However when this boiler is not fired, and in a few more weeks this will be the case, we are left without any hot water.

What we need is a coal-burning hot water jacket capable of heating the five hundred gallon hot water tank. This tank is a vertical one installed beside the present furnaces. It is well insulated and fitted with the necessary outlet and intake valves. The installation of the jacket would be a very simple matter which we will gladly do ourselves. However I don't feel that we should be called upon to purchase it out of school funds as it is a necessary part of the school set-up. At the same time we cannot continue under the present arrangement. Bathing children in cold water is both unsanitary and dangerous to their health. When that water is both cold and hard it becomes an ordeal.

If at all possible please rush this matter through so that by the middle of April when we no longer have need of the furnaces, we will have a unit suitable for our hot water supply.

Sincerely yours,

(sgd) G. F. Kelly, O.M.I.
Principal.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR, LANDS AND DEVELOPMENT SERVICES BRANCH

Kootenay Indian Residential School, Cranbrook, B.C.

District School Inspector Davey's report on the above Residential School has just been received here. He makes the following comments with regard to the physical condition of the school:

"WATER:
"The present system is inadequate and the water is hard. It is understood that a new system is to be installed as soon as the materials required are available.

"SANITARY CONDITIONS:
"The automatic flush toilets in the school are defective in almost every case. The Principal informs me that he has had a plumber out at the school on a number of occasions but only a very temporary improvement was accomplished.

"The kitchens, lavatories, boiler room, etc., were clean. The boys playroom was rather dirty and the floor in this room required repairs. In one spot the floor had given way.

"MAINTENANCE OF BUILDING:
"In addition to the repairs to the floors in the boys playroom and the repair or replacement of the flush toilets previously mentioned there are two major requirements in the maintenance of the building. The exterior walls of the building have cracked badly, apparently..."
due to an earthquake which was experienced in this area several years ago. These cracks should be pointed with a water proof material immediately in order to prevent the seepage of rain and water from melting snow which will cause irreparable damage. The stairs which form the main approach to the building are in such bad condition that they are almost unusable. These should also be replaced this year. The window casings have in many places shrunk away from the walls causing a serious loss of heat and draughts in the rooms. When the cracks in the walls are pointed, the gaps between the window casings and the walls should be caulked.

The Principal reports that the power plant at the school is most unsatisfactory and hopes that at some time in the near future it will be possible to connect up with the power company line which will be running a few miles distant. In view of the considerable amount of repair work which the present school plant has required in the last year this would undoubtedly be the ideal solution. In addition to the cost factor it would supply the type of power for which the standard electrical devices are built to handle."

We realize that your engineers have done considerable work at this school in the past year and that more is planned for next year. Therefore, we are bringing these matters to your attention so that they can be advised of the present condition of the school.
DEPARTMENT OF MINES AND RESOURCES

Dear Sir:

A few days ago I wrote you to acknowledge the receipt of my final cheque on my retirement as Medical Officer in the Indian Department.

I am now asking for information to whom I should address a letter in which a request is made to supply the Industrial School at The St. Eugene Mission at Cranbrook with an efficient electric supply, or perhaps you would be good enough to direct this letter to its proper destination.

I understand that Father Kelly who is in charge at the School has already introduced the subject.

At the present time the school generates electricity by a Diesel machine. It is inadequate and obsolete.

A high tension line stretches from the power plant at Bull River to Kimberley and passes about a distance of three miles from the Mission.

In an interview here with the Power Commissioner I learn that to take electricity from this source direct to the School would require the outlay of an expensive transformer equipment. The Commissioner suggested it would be more feasible to obtain electricity from the City of Cranbrook which also gets its supply from the East Kootenay Power Company.

The St. Eugene Mission is about five miles from Cranbrook. An efficient supply of electricity to the School would in many ways be a tremendous asset to the School. It is
not necessary for me to go into detail.

It is my sincere hope that the Department will realize the full importance of this undertaking and within the very near future make arrangements with the East Kootenay Power Company to supply the School with electricity.

Hoping you will accede to my request to forward this letter.

I am,

Yours very truly,

[F. W. Green]

Memorandum

Re: Kootenay Indian Residential School, Cranbrook, B.C.

In accordance with a request from this office, one of our western representatives inspected the domestic hot water services at the above and his report may be briefly summarized as follows.

Owing to progressive deterioration of some items of heating equipment, the school has no satisfactory means of heating domestic hot water for summer service. In the report a number of items relative to the heating and plumbing systems were noted.

Since the Donald Inspection Company have been charged with making a complete survey covering all phases, it is felt that no action should be taken with reference to the mechanical services in general, until their report and recommendations are received, except for the work required to provide a method of heating water for domestic purposes.

It is recommended, therefore, that a high test jacket heater be provided and installed in accordance with the following specification as soon as possible.

One only high test cast iron square sectional jacket heater having a capacity to heat 1200 gallons of water per hour through a 25° temperature range. Heater to be constructed for a working pressure of 75 lbs. per square inch, and to be provided with a pressure relief valve and gate valve located on the cold water line to the existing domestic hot water storage tank. Connect heater to existing storage tank with piping full size of heater tappings. If necessary, tank tappings shall be increased in size to take this pipe. This heater shall be equal to Dominion Radiator size H-1-Wall.

It is estimated that the above heater and the installation will cost in the neighbourhood of $600.00. This equipment could be purchased through the Department for delivery to the school, and there is nothing involved in connecting it up that could not be handled by the Indian Agent.

Upon receipt of a report from the Donald Inspection Company, it will likely be found that numerous other items will be noted which will require that more or less extensive revisions to mechanical services will be necessary.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,

CITTAWA June 25, 1948.

Under date of June 21st, we have received the following from our Banff office:

"Re my letter of the 10th instant.

"I am enclosing herewith tender submitted by the Corporation of the City of Cranbrook for digging, pipe laying and back fill of the St. Joseph's Creek Pipe Line.

"You will note that they have submitted a price of $1.16 per lineal foot for the above excavation, pipe laying and back fill work. As the estimated length of the excavation to be made is some 1400 Lineal Feet, the total amount due them at $1.16 per lineal foot would be approximately $1,624.00 - which is well within the estimate submitted for this work in the above letter referred to. The difference of some $576.00 can be used to complete such work close to the building as they are unable to do with their shovel.

"I would recommend that this tender be accepted and authorization be forwarded to us immediately, with a copy to Indian Agent Dunn to proceed with this work in July."

July 8, 1946

Mr. R.F. Davey, Inspector of Schools,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Vancouver, B.C.

Dear Mr. Davey:

At the time of your visitation we discussed the necessity of further class-room space and additional dormitory space for this school. As at that time the junior class-room had an enrolment of fifty-six pupils and prospects for next year are that we will have from fifteen to twenty new pupils, we will need extra space for the coming year.

You are aware how hard it is even to get a contractor to give an estimate on any job to say nothing of doing it and these parts are no exception. However I was able to get the attached estimate from Mr. Lundy, a private contractor in Cranbrook who has a reputation of good work. A few years ago he was employed here by the Indian Affairs branch to re-roof the school and his work was quite acceptable. The attached estimate is to complete the third floor dormitory in the boys end of the building in the same manner as has been done in the girls in former years, plus a few alterations in the existing unused classroom, particularly the installation of blackboards. Mr. Lundy has promised to do this work next month and to have all in readiness for Sept. 7th.

This estimate does not provide for a toilet in the boys new dormitory, nor for desks in the classroom or paint for both rooms. As for the toilet I would suggest a sum of fifty dollars for its installation as we have on hand a tank and toilet bowl which can be used. There is no need of washbasins in that dormitory as all can come to the common wash-room on the second floor. As for desks we should have thirty-five suitable for grades four and five. An allowance of twenty-five dollars for paint should do both rooms. If the paint is provided we will gladly put it on ourselves.

Our plans for the coming year, that is opening in Sept., are that the junior class-room retain grades 1, II, & III, the new class-room accommodated grades four and five, and the senior class-room grades VI, VII & VIII.

Dear Mr. Arneil: Re 5-11-3

Many thanks for your letter of recent date regarding proposed alterations in dormitory and classroom space in this school. I am pleased to report as follows. When this school was built the third floor was left unfinished. In 1940 this floor was finished in the girls side of the building thus giving ample dormitory space. The proposition at present is to do likewise in the boys end of the building. As to the extra classroom the original plans called for this room to be used for manual training however as it is directly across the hall from a classroom it was found to be causing too much noise and hence a separate building was erected for manual training.

The proposed dormitory will give 9,600 cubic feet of space, which according to the requirements would provide for 19 extra pupils. The proposed classroom would give 10,500 cubic feet of space, which would accommodate 21 pupils.

Our present allowance is for 100 pupils. With the alterations we could accommodate 19 or 20 more and by adding the third classroom could give a more efficient course of study as we could thereby have more of the children in school for the full teaching day.

Trusting this information will be satisfactory and hoping to have a favorable reply at your earliest convenience as I would like very much to have this additional space available for the opening of school in September.

Sincerely yours,

Dear Mr. Dunn:

Further to our conversation of this afternoon I would like to take up the matter of proposing certain changes in the paint contractor in conjunction with the Kootenay Paint Co.

I understand that their contract called for definite work on the exterior of the building plus painting the storm windows. On the basement floor of the building these windows fit on the outside and thus being exposed to the weather need this attention. However on the first, second, and third floors these storm windows fit on the inside of the present windows and not being exposed to the weather hardly seem in need of attention. You will remember from our examination of them that they are in good condition and the varnish stain on them does not show any serious signs of deterioration or checking. There are in all one hundred and two of these windows.

The proposition I discussed with the manager of the Kootenay Paint Co., and which I would be glad if you would take up with the Dept., if you deem it advisable, is to have interior painting done instead of doing the storm windows. The manager of the Paint Co estimated the labor involved in doing these one hundred and two windows and said he would be willing to apply a coat of sizing and two coats of paint to the main corridor of the building which measures 96 X 10 X 8 feet instead of doing the windows if such was agreeable to the Dept. He figured that the labor on either job would be approximately equal. You are acquainted with the present condition of the main corridor and I'm sure will agree that it is definitely in need of attention. I understand from members of the Staff who were here at the time that it was done in '38 or '39 with Murexco and has not been touched since. As the Murexco can not be washed it has in that time taken on a considerable coating of dust and disfigurements of various kinds.

Memorandum:

The Director,
Lands and Development Service Branch

Re: Kootenay Residential School - Donald Inspection Company Report
Ref. your I.A.1767-2 of November 23

This report has been studied here, and it would seem that the following action is indicated:

(1) Walls - The cracks are capable of local repair with plastic caulking material.

(2) Heating - It would seem that consideration will have to be given towards the replacement of the present wood heating system with either coal or oil.

(3) Lighting - This would seem to be the main problem in this institution. We intend to have Hydro brought into this building next year and to replace the present direct current system.

However, a visit from an Electrical Engineer will probably be required as plans and specifications will be required for a complete change in the wiring system.

(4) Water System - It is presumed that your own engineers have noted the comments made in recommendations 1 and 4.
(5) Out-Buildings - The replacement of the garages which are a fire hazard and the root house would seem to be items which can be handled by this Branch.

In conclusion, I would again like to recommend that this report be the subject of a discussion in the near future between officials of your Engineering and Construction Service and of our Education Division.

Acting Director.

Dear Mr. Dunn: Re: Replacement of heating coil for domestic hot water supply.

The following has been received from Mr. Cornish in connection with the completion of the above project:

"As mentioned in my letter of December 6th, it was evidently the original intention to use an existing line to convey soft water through the school building to the laundry. This proved to be impossible without polluting the domestic supply. Consequently a new 4" line will be required across the building. Since the available head is low and since the chlorinator requires an operating pressure of 10 p.s.i., it is necessary to use 4" pipe rather than a smaller diameter which might be quite satisfactory apart from the high friction loss.

"I am attaching hereto the original of a tender received from Patmore Bros., Cranbrook, covering material and labour for the plumbing and pipe fitting work within the school. This firm has done all the recent plumbing work at the school and is familiar with the maze of pipework in the building. If their bid is accepted they will start work approximately two months after date of acceptance as they expect to obtain the material in that time. From enquiries made, it is very doubtful if we could get delivery on our own order before the end of the fiscal year. I recommend that Patmore Bros. tender for the work be accepted.

DEPUTY MINISTER.

For some years past, we have provided an amount in our estimates in order to make an allowance towards the salary of night watchmen at certain of our Indian Residential Schools which we consider are not fireproof. The usual allowance is for a period of seven months at $60. a month.

We recently received a request from the Principal of the Kootenay Residential School for an allowance towards the salary of the night watchman, effective 1st January, 1949.

For several years past we have been allowing a grant towards the salary of a night watchman for the period October to the following April at those Schools where we considered a definite fire hazard existed. The schools at which this allowance is being paid were selected some years ago, and no recent additions have been made to the list. As a matter of fact, we are not making any allowance towards the salary of a night watchman at any of the Government-owned Residential Schools in the province of British Columbia.

When we received the Principal's request, we submitted a memorandum to the Deputy Minister asking his opinion regarding the payment of an allowance towards the salary of a night watchman. His reply was as follows:

(1) Allowance must not be paid to a present member of the staff.
(2) Allowance must be paid only to schools which are certified by an engineer as subject to special danger by fire.

In the case of the Kootenay Residential School, I note the following statement contained in the report submitted to us by Donald Inspection Limited in connection with their inspection of the Kootenay Residential School on 11th September, 1948:

......2
"In addition to this, there should also be an elevated water tank of not less than 20,000 gallons capacity. At present a small air pump pumps pressure to a tank which has been buried in the ground. So long as it is only used for domestic purposes there should be no trouble, but should you have a fire and any quantity of water is taken from this tank, the pressure is dropped and no water will be available for fire fighting purposes."

In view of this report which was made by an engineer, it would appear that the Kootenay Residential School might be considered as one at which an allowance could be made towards the salary of the night watchman during the months mentioned in the first part of my letter.

However, when we allow a grant for a night watchman at one school, we generally receive similar requests from other schools, and consequently before replying to the Principal of the Kootenay Residential School, we would like to have your comments and at the same time, you might state if you consider there are any other Government-owned schools in British Columbia at which any such allowance should be made, keeping in mind the conditions laid down by the Deputy Minister.

"The only proposed uses of unchlorinated creek water not covered in the report are for feeding stock in the barn and for cooling milk in the dairy. Untreated creek water is now used for these purposes. I understand that there is no objection from a public health point of view to use polluted water for feeding stock, that is, no pollution can be carried from the drinking water to the milk. However, such water should not be used for cleaning cows and precautions will need to be taken on that point. At present there are several exposed taps in the barn and these are to be eliminated if possible otherwise reduced to the essential minimum size marked. The troughs for cooling water should have covers with holes through which the milk cans are inserted so that there is no exposed water surface. It should be borne in mind that the installation to supply creek water to the barn and dairy are to be made by school authorities and that this Division will not be responsible for such work."

Indian Affairs are advised to see that the recommendations of Mr. Perry and Mr. Cornish are carried out in order that the contaminated water from St. Joseph's Creek shall not be used in its raw state in a manner which might affect the health of those using it.

The attached account from Patmore Bros. to installation of new Heating Coils, Domestic Hot Water supply at the Residential School.

When these coils first burnt out it was impossible to shut the control valves to coil or hot water tank. The coil was only replaced last week due to extreme cold weather prevailing and uncertainty of sufficient heat while the boiler in question was down. On examination the control valves were found to be beyond repair and two new 2 inch Brass Gate-control valves were installed in this emergency.

I trust you can concur with the action taken in this regard and recommend that this account be paid in full.

J. S. Dunn,
Superintendent.

Re some recent accounts forwarded from your office, the voucher shows higher expenditure than the application on the Purchase Order issued by you.

While the Treasury has not turned any of these back, they sometimes ask why the account is bigger than the Purchase Order. If it does not inconvenience you too much we would appreciate if the amount of the Purchase Order would coincide with the account.

MEMORANDUM

Re: Kootenay, Alert Bay and Sechelt Indian Residential Schools, British Columbia.

Further to our memorandum of February 24th, you are advised that we have had a discussion with officials of the Indian Affairs Branch in connection with proposed inspections of the above schools.

It was pointed out to the Indian Affairs officers, that our program of work includes commitments not only on Indian Affairs work, but Northwest Territories, and National Parks Service projects as well, which will require the services of our heating engineer here in the office, until such time as these items are well along the way to complete development.

It is difficult at this time to state when our officer can be assigned to carry out the mechanical inspections requested for British Columbia, but we will endeavour to arrange our program of work so that these inspections can be made at as early a date as possible.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Chief Engineer.
